title: ~(으)나마 [(eu)nama] (At least, even if only)
short_explanation: Used to express the modest amount of what you can do or accept.
long_explanation: '~(으)나마 [(eu)nama]' is a grammar point used in Korean to express that even if the quantity or degree is modest, it is at least that much. It can have a sense of consolation or slight regret, but also a feeling that one can be satisfied with that small amount in a given situation.

examples.kr: 나는 일이 바빠서 많은 시간을 할애할 수는 없지만, 하루에 한 시간이나마 공부하려고 노력하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun iri bappaseo maneun siganeul hal-aehal suneun eopjiman, harue han sigan-inama gongbu-haryeogo noryeokhago isseumnida.
examples.en: I'm busy with work and can't devote a lot of time, but I'm trying to study at least one hour a day.

examples.kr: 이번 달에는 돈이 조금 부족하지만, 세밀한 계획을 세우면 10만 원이나마 절약할 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon dareneun doni jogeum bujokhajiman, semilhan gyehoegeul se-umyeon sipman won-inama jeolyakhal su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Money is a bit short this month, but if we make a detailed plan, I think we can save at least 100,000 won.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아프다며 자주 훈련을 빼먹지만, 남은 시간이나마 최선을 다하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun apeudamyeo jaju hullyeoneul ppaemeokjiman, nameun sigan-inama choeseoneul dahago isseoyo.
examples.en: She often misses training because she's sick, but she's doing her best with the remaining time.

examples.kr: 우리가 떨어진 것은 사실이지만, 좋은 친구로서 너와 이야기하는 시간이나마 가질 수 있으면 좋겠어.
examples.romaji: Uriga tteoreojin geoseun sasilijiman, joeun chinguroseo neowa iyagihaneun sigan-inama gajil su isseumyeon johgesseo.
examples.en: The fact that we broke up is true, but I'd like to have at least the time to talk with you as a good friend.

title: ~(으)니까 [(eu)nikka] (Because, so)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the cause or reason; 'Because', 'So'.
long_explanation: '~(으)니까 [(eu)nikka]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate the cause or reason why something happens or a certain situation exists. It is similar to 'because' or 'so' in English. It is most often used in casual conversations and can be used both for positive and negative statements.

examples.kr: 비가 오니까 우산을 가져가세요.
examples.romaji: Biga onikka usaneul gajyeogaseyo.
examples.en: Because it's raining, take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 지금 너무 늦었으니까 우리 내일 다시 만나자.
examples.romaji: Jigeum neomu neujeosseunikka uri naeil dasi mannaja.
examples.en: Because it's too late now, let's meet again tomorrow.

examples.kr: 오늘 피곤하니까 일찍 집에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul pigonhanikka iljjik jibe gasseoyo.
examples.en: Because I was tired today, I went home early.

examples.kr: 운동을 많이 했으니까 힘이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul mani haesseunikka himi eopseoyo.
examples.en: Because I exercised a lot, I have no energy.

title: ~(으)려다가 [(eu)ryeodaga] (Was about to, tried to)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express an action that was about to happen but did not take place due to some intervening cause.
long_explanation: '~(으)려다가' is used when you want to express an action that was on the verge of happening or one that you intended to do, but for some reason did not happen, or another event intervened. Depending on the context, it can be translated as 'was about to', 'tried to', 'was going to', or 'intended to'.

examples.kr: 집에 가려다가 비가 너무 많이 와서 친구 집에 머물렀어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe garyeodaga biga neomu mani waseo chingu jibe meomulleosseoyo.
examples.en: I was about to go home, but it rained so much that I stayed at my friend's house.

examples.kr: 책을 사려다가 돈이 부족해서 못 샀어요.
examples.romaji: Chaegeul saryeodaga doni bujokhaeseo mot sasseoyo.
examples.en: I was about to buy a book, but I couldn't because I was short of money.

examples.kr: 전화를 하려다가 휴대폰 배터리가 떨어져서 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonhwareul haryeodaga hyudaepon baeteoriga tteoreojyeoseo mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: I was about to make a call, but I couldn't because my phone battery ran out.

examples.kr: 운동하려다가 갑자기 몸이 아파서 포기했어요.
examples.romaji: Undongharyeodaga gapjagi momi apaseo pogihesseoyo.
examples.en: I was about to exercise, but I suddenly felt sick, so I gave up.

title: ~(으)니 [(eu)ni] (Because, as one would expect)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that given the circumstances, the result is natural or to be expected.
long_explanation: '~(으)니 [(eu)ni]' is often used in Korean to mean 'because' or 'since,' emphasizing a cause-and-effect relationship or a natural/expected result. It can sound slightly more formal or written than '~(으)니까', and is also common in narratives to show that something is an obvious conclusion based on a certain action or condition.

examples.kr: 매일 연습하면서 스피치를 준비하였으니, 스피치 대회에서 우승하였어요.
examples.romaji: Maeil yeonseubhamyeonseo seupichireul junbihayeosseuni, seupichi daehoeeseo useunghayeosseoyo.
examples.en: I prepared my speech every day by practicing, so naturally I won the speech contest.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 열심히 공부하였으니, 시험에서 좋은 결과를 얻었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang yeolsimhi gongbuhayeosseuni, siheomeseo joheun gyeolgwareul eodeosseoyo.
examples.en: He always studied hard, so of course he got a good result on the test.

examples.kr: 너무 많이 먹었으니, 배가 아픈 건 당연해요.
examples.romaji: Neomu mani meogeosseuni, baega apeun geon dangyeonhaeyo.
examples.en: You ate too much, so it's only natural that your stomach hurts.

examples.kr: 양치를 안 하였으니, 이가 아픈 건 예상할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yangchireul an hayeosseuni, iga apeun geon yesanghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: You didn't brush your teeth, so it's expected that your teeth would hurt.

title: ~(으)면 ~(으)ㄹ수록 [(eu)myeon ~(eu)lsurok] (The more... the more...)
short_explanation: Used to express the idea that the more one situation or action occurs, the more another result follows.
long_explanation: '~(으)면 ~(으)ㄹ수록' is used to show a relationship of proportion, much like the English pattern 'the more..., the more...'. The first clause describes a certain action or condition increasing, and the second clause describes the corresponding change or result that likewise increases or intensifies.

examples.kr: 날이 점점 흐려져서 도로 위가 보이지 않으면 보이지 않을수록 운전하기가 무서워져요.
examples.romaji: Nariga jeomjeom heureojyeoseo doro wiga boiji anheumyeon boiji anheulsurok unjeonhagiga museowo-jyeoyo.
examples.en: The cloudier it gets and the less I can see the road, the scarier it is to drive.

examples.kr: 한국어를 공부하면 공부할수록 그 언어의 아름다움을 더 깊이 이해하게 됩니다.
examples.romaji: Hangugeoreul gongbuhamyeon gongbuhalsurok geu eoneoui areumdaumeul deo gipi ihaehage doemnida.
examples.en: The more you study Korean, the more deeply you can understand its beauty.

examples.kr: 친구들이랑 많이 얘기하면 얘기할수록 서로에 대해 더 많이 알 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeurirang mani yaegihamyeon yaegihalsurok seoroe daehae deo mani al su isseoyo.
examples.en: The more you talk with your friends, the more you can learn about each other.

examples.kr: 이 책을 읽으면 읽을수록 흥미롭게 느껴져요.
examples.romaji: I chaegeul ilgeumyeon ilgeulsurok heungmiropge neukkyeojyeoyo.
examples.en: The more I read this book, the more interesting it becomes.

title: ~(으)면서는 [(eu)myeonseoneun] (While, whereas)
short_explanation: Used to connect two conflicting or contrasting situations or actions, often to criticize or show surprise.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~(으)면서는' is used to connect two contrasting or unexpected situations in Korean. It can be translated as 'while' or 'whereas,' but it has a nuance of slight criticism or emphasis on the contradiction. It often conveys the speaker's surprise, disappointment, or disapproval about the two coexisting states.

examples.kr: 그는 학교에 다니면서는 전혀 공부를 하지 않아요, 그래서 성적이 나쁘다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hakgyoe danimyeonseoneun jeonhyeo gongbureul haji anhayo, geuraeseo seongjeogi nappeudago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: While attending school, he doesn’t study at all, so I think his grades are bad.

examples.kr: 어머니는 일을 하면서는 집안일도 다 처리하셨어요, 그런데 아무도 어머니를 도와주지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun ireul hamyeonseoneun jibanildo da cheorihasyeosseoyo, geureonde amudo eomeonireul dowajuji anasseoyo.
examples.en: While working, my mother also took care of all the housework, but nobody helped her.

examples.kr: 진수는 공부를 하면서는 항상 친구들과 놀기를 좋아해요, 그래서 시간관리가 정말 혼란스러워 보여요.
examples.romaji: Jinsuneun gongbureul hamyeonseoneun hangsang chingudeulgwa nolgireul joahaeyo, geuraeseo sigangwanriga jeongmal honranseureowo boyeoyo.
examples.en: While Jinsu studies, he also always likes to hang out with friends, so his time management looks really chaotic.

examples.kr: 비가 오면서는 날씨가 추워졌어요, 그런데 여름 중에 이렇게 추운 날씨는 정말 이상해요.
examples.romaji: Biga omyeonseoneun nalssiga chuweojyeosseoyo, geureonde yeoreum junge ireoke chuun nalssineun jeongmal isanghaeyo.
examples.en: While it was raining, the weather got cold, but such cold weather in the middle of summer is really strange.

title: ~(으)시거나 [(eu)sigeona] (Either... or... [honorific])
short_explanation: Used to present two or more possibilities or choices in a respectful manner (honorific).
long_explanation: '~(으)시거나' is the honorific form of '~거나' (meaning 'or'), used when speaking about or to elders, superiors, or in polite/formal situations. It gives multiple alternatives, allowing the subject (respected person) to choose.

examples.kr: 선생님이 칠판에 문제를 적으시거나, 학생들에게 직접 문제를 설명하시곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimi chilpane munjeleul jeogeusigona, hagsaengdeurege jikjeop munjeleul seolmyeonghasigon haeyo.
examples.en: The teacher either writes the question on the board or explains it directly to the students.

examples.kr: 소노피 할머니가 이번 주에 몸이 안 좋으시거나, 기침을 하시면 의사 선생님께 진료를 받으러 가셔야 해요.
examples.romaji: Sonopi halmeoniga ibeon jue momi an joeusigona, gichimeul hasimyeon uisa seonsaengnimkke jillyoreul badeureo gasyeoya haeyo.
examples.en: If Grandma Sono is not feeling well this week or has a cough, she should go see the doctor.

examples.kr: 운동을 하시거나, 책을 읽으시거나 하는 것이 좋은 스트레스 해소 방법입니다.
examples.romaji: Undongeul hasigona, chaegeul ilgeusigona haneun geosi joheun seuteureseu haeso bangbeobimnida.
examples.en: Either exercising or reading a book is a good way to relieve stress.

examples.kr: 어머니께서 집에 계시거나, 학교에 오시거나 하셔도 어느 쪽이든 편하십니다.
examples.romaji: Eomeonikkeseo jibe gyesigona, hakgyoe osigona hasyeodo eoneu jjogideun pyeonhasimnida.
examples.en: Whether mother stays at home or comes to school, either way is comfortable for her.

title: ~(으)시든지 [(eu)sideunji] (Whether... or... [honorific])
short_explanation: Used to list two or more possibilities in a respectful manner.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~(으)시든지' is the honorific counterpart of '~든지', which means 'whether... or...' and presents multiple possibilities or conditions politely. It allows freedom of choice for the respected person, without asserting which option is preferred.

examples.kr: 선생님이 미리 알려 주시든지, 아니면 수업시간에 배우시든지 해야 학생들이 이해할 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimi miri allyeo jusideunji, animyeon sueopsigane baeusideunji haeya haksaengdeuri ihaehal su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Whether the teacher explains it ahead of time or teaches it during class, it seems students can understand better that way.

examples.kr: 아빠가 지금 집에 오시든지, 아니면 조금 늦게 오시든지, 저는 항상 환영해요.
examples.romaji: Appaga jigeum jibe osideunji, animyeon jogeum neujge osideunji, jeoneun hangsang hwanyeonghaeyo.
examples.en: Whether my dad comes home now or comes a little late, I always welcome him.

examples.kr: 할머니가 저녁에 전화하시든지, 아니면 메시지를 보내시든지 하세요.
examples.romaji: Halmeoniga jeonyeoge jeonhwahasideunji, animyeon mesijireul bonaesideunji haseyo.
examples.en: Whether my grandmother calls in the evening or sends a message, she does so.

examples.kr: 의사 선생님이 약을 처방하시든지, 아니면 수술을 권고하시든지, 환자는 항상 존중받아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Uisa seonsaengnimi yageul cheobanghasideunji, animyeon susureul gwongohasideunji, hwanjaneun hangsang jonjungbadaya haeyo.
examples.en: Whether the doctor prescribes medication or recommends surgery, the patient should always be respected.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 데가 없다 [(eu)l dega eopda] (There's no way to...)
short_explanation: Used to express 'there's absolutely no way/place/opportunity to...' do something.
long_explanation: The phrase '~(으)ㄹ 데가 없다' literally means 'there is no place/way to do X' and emphasizes that, given the conditions, there is no possibility or option for the action. It can sound somewhat figurative, referring to both physical 'place' or a 'method/means' of doing something.

examples.kr: 그 문제를 해결할 데가 없어요, 너무 복잡해서 아무도 해결 방법을 찾지 못하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geu munjeleul haegyeolhal dega eopseoyo, neomu bokjabhaseo amudo haegyeol bangbeobeul chajji motago isseoyo.
examples.en: There's no way to solve that problem; it's too complex and no one can find a solution.

examples.kr: 우리가 그 영화를 볼 데가 없어요, 모든 표가 매진되었어요.
examples.romaji: Uriga geu yeonghwareul bol dega eopseoyo, modeun pyoga maejindwaesseoyo.
examples.en: There's no way for us to watch that movie; all the tickets are sold out.

examples.kr: 지금 이 시간에 교통체증을 피할 데가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum i sigane gyotongchejeungeul pihal dega eopseoyo.
examples.en: There's no way to avoid traffic congestion at this time.

examples.kr: 너무 늦게 왔으니까 그 차를 잡을 데가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu neujge wasunikka geu chareul jabeul dega eopseoyo.
examples.en: I arrived too late, so there's no way to catch that car.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 수밖에 없다 [(eu)l subakke eopda] (Have no choice but to)
short_explanation: Used to express that one has 'no choice but to' do something.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 수밖에 없다' emphasizes that a certain action or situation is unavoidable or inevitable. It is equivalent to the English phrase 'have no choice but to.'

examples.kr: 날씨가 너무 더워서 물을 마실 수밖에 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga neomu deowoseo mureul masil subakke eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: The weather was so hot that I had no choice but to drink water.

examples.kr: 시간이 너무 없어서 택시를 타고 갈 수밖에 없었습니다.
examples.romaji: Sigani neomu eopseoseo taegsireul tago gal subakke eopseosseumnida.
examples.en: I had too little time, so I had no choice but to take a taxi.

examples.kr: 저는 돈이 없어서 라면을 먹을 수밖에 없었습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun doni eopseoseo ramyeoneul meogeul subakke eopseosseumnida.
examples.en: I had no money, so I had no choice but to eat ramen.

examples.kr: 그가 너무 늦어서 저는 기다릴 수밖에 없었습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga neomu neujeoseo jeoneun gidaril subakke eopseosseumnida.
examples.en: He was so late that I had no choice but to wait.

title: ~(으)ㄹ지라도 [(eu)ljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express 'even if' or 'no matter how'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ지라도 [(eu)ljirado]' is a conditional ending in Korean used to convey that, even if the situation in the first clause is true, it does not affect or change the action or stance in the following clause. It often translates to 'no matter how' or 'even if'. It can also express an unlikely supposition or a scenario beyond one's control.

examples.kr: 그가 얼마나 서운해할지라도, 나는 그의 결정을 반대할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geuga eolmana seowonhaehaljirado, naneun geuui gyeoljeongeul bandaehal geoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if he feels really upset, I will oppose his decision.

examples.kr: 아무리 바쁠지라도, 우리는 시간을 내어 이 문제를 해결해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Amuri bappeuljirado, urineun siganeul naeeo i munjereul haegyeolhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: No matter how busy we are, we must find time to solve this problem.

examples.kr: 어떻게 해서든 우리 팀이 이 경기에 이길 수 있을지라도, 상대 팀은 여전히 강력한 상대입니다.
examples.romaji: Eotteoke haeseodeun uri timi i gyeonggie igil su isseuljirado, sangdae timeun yeojeonhi gangnyeokhan sangdaeyimnida.
examples.en: No matter how, even if our team can win this match, the opposing team is still very strong.

examples.kr: 이 춤을 아무리 잘 출지라도, 난 여전히 춤추는 게 부끄러워요.
examples.romaji: I chumeul amuri jal chuljirado, nan yeojeonhi chumchuneun ge bukkeureowoyo.
examples.en: Even if I dance this dance really well, I'm still shy about dancing.

title: ~(으)려나 [(eu)ryeona] (I wonder if...)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used when the speaker is wondering or pondering about a future possibility or outcome.
long_explanation: '~(으)려나 [(eu)ryeona]' is used in Korean to express doubt, curiosity, or speculation about a situation in the future. It is similar to the English expression 'I wonder if'. If the verb stem ends in a vowel, '려나' is used; if it ends in a consonant, '으려나' is used.

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 비가 올려나 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeoge biga olryeona moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I wonder if it will rain tonight.

examples.kr: 친구가 내 생일을 기억하려나 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga nae saengireul gieokharyeona moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I wonder if my friend will remember my birthday.

examples.kr: 이 시험을 통과할 수 있으려나 모르겠습니다.
examples.romaji: I siheomeul tonggwahal su isseuryeona moreugesseumnida.
examples.en: I wonder if I can pass this exam.

examples.kr: 내년에는 여행을 갈 수 있으려나 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naenyeon-eneun yeohaengeul gal su isseuryeona moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I wonder if I will be able to travel next year.

title: ~겠지만 [gesjiman] (I think, but...)
short_explanation: Used to express an assumption or conjecture followed by a contrasting idea or condition.
long_explanation: '~겠지만 [gesjiman]' is used in Korean to show a strong guess or assumption about something, immediately followed by a contrast or a different condition. It can be compared to the English phrase 'I think (that)... but...', and sometimes conveys a note of uncertainty or reservation.

examples.kr: 내일 날씨가 좋겠지만, 여행을 가기 위한 시간이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil nalssiga jotgetjiman, yeohaengeul gagi wihan sigani eopseoyo.
examples.en: I think the weather will be good tomorrow, but I don't have time to go on a trip.

examples.kr: 그녀가 이해해주겠지만, 그녀에게 내 실수를 설명하는 것은 어렵네요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga ihaehaejugesjiman, geunyeoege nae silsureul seolmyeonghaneun geoseun eoryeopneyo.
examples.en: I believe she’ll understand, but it's hard to explain my mistake to her.

examples.kr: 이번 시험에서 좋은 성적을 받겠지만, 아직도 많이 걱정돼요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeseo joeun seongjeogeul batgetjiman, ajikdo manhi geokjeongdwaeyo.
examples.en: I think I'll get good grades on this test, but I'm still very worried.

examples.kr: 친구들이 놀라겠지만, 나는 이번 파티에 참석하지 않을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeuri nollalgesjiman, naneun ibeon patie chamsokhaji aneul geoyeyo.
examples.en: I think my friends will be surprised, but I'm not going to attend this party.

title: ~게 되다 [ge dweda] (End up, come to)
short_explanation: Used to express that an action or situation resulted naturally or unintentionally.
long_explanation: '~게 되다' is used to indicate that an action or state 'came to be' as a result of certain circumstances, often without direct intention. It can refer to an unexpected outcome or something that happened gradually and naturally. It frequently translates as 'end up doing' or 'come to do' in English.

examples.kr: 비가 오는데 우산을 안 가져와서 젖게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Biga oneunde usaneul an gajyeowaseo jeotge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: It was raining, and I didn't bring an umbrella, so I ended up getting wet.

examples.kr: 공부를 많이 하지 않아서 시험에 떨어지게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul manhi haji anaseo siheome tteoreojige doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: I didn't study much, so I ended up failing the exam.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 많이 연습해서 한국어를 유창하게 말하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangukeoreul manhi yeonseubhaeseo hangukeoreul yuchanghage malhage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: I practiced Korean a lot, so I ended up speaking it fluently.

examples.kr: 주말에 친구들과 만나려 했는데, 그들이 바빠서 결국 혼자 영화를 보게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Jumare chingudeulgwa mannalyeo haenneunde, geudeuri bappaseo gyeolguk honja yeonghwareul boge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: I planned to meet my friends over the weekend, but they were busy, so I ended up watching a movie alone.

title: ~게 하다 [ge hada] (Make/cause someone to do)
short_explanation: Used to express 'making' or 'causing' someone to do something.
long_explanation: '~게 하다' indicates that someone or something makes or causes another person to perform an action. It corresponds to 'make/let/cause (someone) do something' in English. The subject is the person causing the action, and the object is the one who is made to do it.

examples.kr: 어머니는 동생 명주를 공부하게 하셨어요, 그래서 명주는 시험을 잘 볼 수 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun dongsaeng Myeongjureul gongbuhage hasyeosseoyo, geuraeseo Myeongjuneun siheomeul jal bol su isseotseumnida.
examples.en: Mother made my younger sibling Myeongju study, so Myeongju was able to do well on the exam.

examples.kr: 사장님은 직원들을 일찍 회사에 도착하게 했습니다, 그래서 모든 사람이 일찍 일을 시작하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Sajangnimeun jigweondeureul iljjik hoesa-e dochakhage haesseumnida, geuraeseo modeun sarami iljjik ireul sijakhage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: The boss made the employees arrive at the office early, so everyone started work early.

examples.kr: 선생님은 학생들이 한국어 문장을 만들게 했어요, 그래서 학생들은 더 잘 이해하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun haksaengdeuri hangugeo munjangeul mandeulge haesseoyo, geuraeseo haksaengdeureun deo jal ihaehage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: The teacher made the students create Korean sentences, and they came to understand Korean better.

examples.kr: 그 영화는 나를 웃게 했어요, 코미디 부분이 정말 재미있었거든요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaneun nareul utge haesseoyo, komidi bubuni jeongmal jaemiisseotgeodeunyo.
examples.en: That movie made me laugh; its comedy parts were really entertaining.

title: ~고 말다 [go malda] (End up)
short_explanation: Used to express that an action is completed or ends with an unexpected or unintended result.
long_explanation: '~고 말다' emphasizes that an action/event reached its conclusion (often regretfully or unexpectedly). It can carry the nuance of something happening despite efforts or intentions to avoid it, leading to a sense of finality or mild lament.

examples.kr: 저는 연습을 너무 많이 해서 손가락이 아파 결국 연습을 멈추고 말았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yeonseubeul neomu mani haeseo songaragi apa gyeolguk yeonseubeul meomchugo malasseoyo.
examples.en: I practiced too much, so my fingers hurt and I ended up stopping practice.

examples.kr: 친구가 계속 추천해서 결국 그 영화를 보고 말았어요, 그런데 별로 재미없었어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga gyesok chucheonhaeseo gyeolguk geu yeonghwareul bogo malasseoyo, geureonde byeollo jaemieopseosseoyo.
examples.en: My friend kept recommending it, so I finally ended up watching that movie, but it wasn’t very good.

examples.kr: 너무 배가 고파서 그녀가 만든 요리를 다 먹고 말았습니다, 사실 재료 선택이 조금 별로였어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu baega gopaseo geunyeoga mandeun yorireul da meokgo malasseumnida, sasil jaeryo seontaegi jogeum byeolloyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was so hungry that I ended up eating all the food she made; honestly, the ingredient choices weren’t great.

examples.kr: 하루 종일 일하고 너무 피곤해서 잠들고 말았어요, 그래서 계획했던 일을 다 못 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Haru jongil ilhago neomu pigonhaeseo jamdeulgo malasseoyo, geuraeseo gyehoekhaetdeon ireul da mot haesseumnida.
examples.en: After working all day I was so tired that I ended up falling asleep, so I couldn’t finish my planned tasks.

title: ~고 말하다 [go malhada] (Say that...)
short_explanation: Used to convey that someone said something in a manner suggesting finality or firm intention.
long_explanation: The construction '~고 말하다' in Korean means 'to say (something).' It can carry a nuance of definitiveness or insistence in the statement. It is often used when someone states a fact, an order, or a firm decision they have made.

examples.kr: 그녀는 배가 불러도 작은 케이크 한 조각을 더 먹겠다고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun baega bulleodo jageun keikeu han jogageul deo meokgetdago malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: She said that she would eat another slice of cake even though she was already full.

examples.kr: 우리 어머니는 저녁에 일찍 잘 것이라고 말했어요. 너무 피곤해서 그렇대요.
examples.romaji: Uri eomeonineun jeonyeoge iljjik jal geosirago malhaesseoyo. Neomu pigonhaeseo geureotaeyo.
examples.en: My mother said she would go to bed early tonight. She said it’s because she’s very tired.

examples.kr: 회사 대표는 상황이 어렵다고 말했습니다, 그래서 직원들은 더 집중해야겠다고 느꼈어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesa daepyeoneun sanghwangi eoryeopdago malhaesseumnida, geuraeseo jigweondeureun deo jipjunghaeyagetdago neukkyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The company’s CEO said that things are difficult, so the employees felt they should focus more.

examples.kr: 그는 결코 포기하지 않겠다고 말해서, 모두가 그의 결심을 믿게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gyeolko pogihaji angetdago malhaeseo, moduga geuui gyeolsimeul mitge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: He said he would never give up, so everyone came to trust his determination.

title: ~고 보면 [go bomyeon] (Upon closer look, when you consider)
short_explanation: Used to express the meaning 'when seen/considered in a certain way' or 'once you look at it, you realize...'.
long_explanation: '~고 보면 [go bomyeon]' conveys the idea that after doing or seeing something, a new perspective or outcome emerges. It indicates that things may look different 'when you actually do/see them'.

examples.kr: 처음에는 문제가 어려워 보였지만, 자세히 보고 보면 그렇게 어렵지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeumeneun munjega eoryeowo boyeotjiman, jasehi bogo bomyeon geureoke eoryeopji anhayo.
examples.en: At first the problem looked difficult, but when you examine it closely, it's not that hard.

examples.kr: 그의 아이디어가 처음에는 이상하게 들렸지만, 곰곰이 생각해 보고 보면 굉장히 독창적이에요.
examples.romaji: Geuui aideoga cheoeumeneun isanghage deullyeotjiman, gomgomi saenggakae bogo bomyeon goaengjanghi dokchangjeogiyeyo.
examples.en: His idea sounded strange at first, but when you think it over, it's actually very innovative.

examples.kr: 사진을 보고 보면 그가 꽤 행복해 보이네요.
examples.romaji: Sajineul bogo bomyeon geuga kkwae haengbokhae boineyo.
examples.en: When I look at the photo, he actually seems quite happy.

examples.kr: 이 책을 읽고 보면 작가의 의도를 더 잘 이해할 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: I chaegeul ilkgo bomyeon jakgaui uidoeul deo jal ihaehal su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Once you read this book, I think you'll understand the author’s intention much better.

title: ~고서 [goseo] (After doing)
short_explanation: Used to express that an action is performed after the execution of another action.
long_explanation: '~고서 [goseo]' is a Korean grammar form used to indicate that another action or event occurs after the first action has been completed. It roughly translates to 'after doing something.' This construction usually implies that the same subject completes one action and then proceeds somewhat directly to the next.

examples.kr: 지난 주에 도서관에 갔어요. 책을 빌리고서 돌아왔어요.
examples.romaji: Jinan ju-e doseogwan-e gasseoyo. Chaegeul bil-ri-go-seo dorawasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to the library last week and came back after borrowing a book.

examples.kr: 집에 도착하자마자 밥을 먹고서 씻었어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe dochakha-jamaja babeul meok-go-seo ssiseosseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I arrived home, I ate and then washed up.

examples.kr: 나는 숙제를 다 하고서 TV를 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun sugjereul da ha-go-seo tibireul bwasseoyo.
examples.en: I watched TV after finishing all my homework.

examples.kr: 우리는 수영장에서 수영을 하고서 밥을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun suyeongjang-eseo suyeongeul ha-go-seo bab-eul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: We ate after swimming at the pool.

title: ~고자 [goja] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to express the purpose or aim of an action: 'in order to', 'for the purpose of'.
long_explanation: '~고자 [goja]' is used to express someone’s intention or goal—like 'in order to' in English. It clarifies the purpose of an action. Note that this form is somewhat formal or literary; in more casual speech, you might see different expressions such as '~려고'.

examples.kr: 저는 토픽 시험을 통과하기 위해 한국어를 공부하고자 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun TOPIK siheomeul tong-gwa-hagi wihae hangukeoreul gongbuhagoja hamnida.
examples.en: In order to pass the TOPIK exam, I intend to study Korean.

examples.kr: 그녀는 자기 스스로를 향상시키고자 매일 운동을 합니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jagi seuseuroreul hyangsang-sikigoja maeil undongeul hamnida.
examples.en: She exercises daily in order to improve herself.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 우리 가족을 위해 매일 일하고자 합니다.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun uri gajogeul wihae maeil ilhagoja hamnida.
examples.en: My father intends to work every day in order to provide for our family.

examples.kr: 우리는 환경을 보호하고자 재활용품을 구입하기로 결정했습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun hwangyeongeul bohohagoja jaehwallyongpumeul guibhagiro gyeoljeonghaesseumnida.
examples.en: In order to protect the environment, we decided to purchase recycled products.

title: ~기는 하다 [gineun hada] (Do something but...)
short_explanation: Used to express 'I do (action) but...', showing a contrast with an additional clause.
long_explanation: '~기는 하다 [gineun hada]' acknowledges that something is true while introducing a contrasting or qualifying statement. The nuance is similar to 'I do X, but...' or 'Yes, it’s true that X, but...' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 먹기는 했지만 그렇게 많이 먹지는 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun meok-gineun haessjiman geureoke mani meokjineun anhasseoyo.
examples.en: I did eat, but I didn't eat that much.

examples.kr: 제가 그 영화를 보기는 했는데 재미있게는 보지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jega geu yeonghwareul bo-gineun haenneunde jaemiitge-neun boji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: I did watch that movie, but I didn't really find it fun.

examples.kr: 그는 운동을 하기는 한다. 그러나 건강한 식생활은 유지하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun undongeul ha-gineun handa. Geureona geonganghan siksaenghwareun yuji haji anhayo.
examples.en: He does exercise, but he doesn't maintain a healthy diet.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어를 배우기는 하지만 아직은 잘 못해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangukeoreul baeugineun hajiman ajigeun jal motaeyo.
examples.en: I do study Korean, but I still can't speak it well.

title: ~기로 하다 [giro hada] (Decide to)
short_explanation: Used to express the decision or resolution to do something.
long_explanation: '~기로 하다 [giro hada]' is used to indicate that someone has decided or resolved to carry out a particular action. It can refer to personal decisions or collectively agreed plans, often used when describing future intentions.

examples.kr: 나는 매일 아침 운동하기로 결정했어요, 그래서 날씨가 춥더라도 매일 운동하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeil achim undonghagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo, geuraeseo nalssiga chupdeorado maeil undonghago isseoyo.
examples.en: I decided to exercise every morning, so I do it daily even if it's cold.

examples.kr: 우리 모두 내년에 함께 여행 가기로 했어요, 그래서 지금부터 돈을 모으기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Uri modu naenyeone hamkke yeohaeng gagiro haesseoyo, geuraeseo jigeumbuteo doneul moeugiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: We all decided to travel together next year, so we've decided to start saving money now.

examples.kr: 그는 올해 안에 흡연을 끊기로 했어요, 그래서 담배를 더 이상 사지 않기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun olhae ane heubyeoneul kkeungiro haesseoyo, geuraeseo dambaereul deo isang saji anhgiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: He decided to quit smoking this year, so he decided not to buy cigarettes anymore.

examples.kr: 회사는 직원들의 안전을 위해 매주 금요일에 마스크를 착용하기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaneun jigweondeur-ui anjeoneul wihae maeju geumyoire maseukeureul chakyonghagiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: The company decided to wear masks every Friday for the employees’ safety.

title: ~기로 되다 [giro dweda] (It is decided/settled)
short_explanation: Used to express that something has been officially decided or settled.
long_explanation: '~기로 되다 [giro dweda]' is used when a decision has been made—often collectively or officially—and is now settled. It is akin to ‘It has been decided that...’ in English.

examples.kr: 우리는 다음 주에 여행 가기로 되었어요. 날짜는 이미 정해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun daeum ju-e yeohaeng gagiro doeeosseoyo. Naljja-neun imi jeonghaejyeosseoyo.
examples.en: It's been decided that we'll travel next week. The date has already been set.

examples.kr: 그녀는 자세한 계획을 세우기로 되었어요. 다음 달에 결혼식을 준비 중이에요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jasehan gyehoekeul seugiro doeeosseoyo. Daeum dale gyeolhonsigeul junbi jungieyo.
examples.en: It was settled that she would make a detailed plan. She’s preparing for a wedding next month.

examples.kr: 우리는 매주 목요일마다 회의를 하기로 되었어요, 모든 팀원이 참석할 수 있는 시간이에요.
examples.romaji: Urineun maeju mogyoil-mada hoeuireul hagiro doeeosseoyo, modeun timweon-i chamseokhal su itneun siganieyo.
examples.en: It has been decided that we’ll hold meetings every Thursday, as that’s a time everyone can attend.

examples.kr: 누구를 팀 리더로 선발할지는 이미 결정되었고, 그가 그 역할을 맡기로 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Nugureul tim lideoro seonbalhaljineun imi gyeoljeongdoeeotgo, geuga geu yeokhareul matgiro doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: Who would be chosen as the team leader was already decided, and he was settled to take on that role.

title: ~기 시작하다 [gi sijak-hada] (Begin to)
short_explanation: Used to express the beginning of an action or state.
long_explanation: '~기 시작하다 [gi sijak-hada]' means 'to start doing something.' It's comparable to 'begin to' or 'start to' in English. It emphasizes that an action or condition has just begun.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우기 시작하려고 이 학교에 왔어요. 전에는 전혀 몰랐어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangukeoreul baeugi sijak-haryeogo i hakgyoe wasseoyo. Jeoneneun jeonhyeo mollasseoyo.
examples.en: I came to this school to start learning Korean. I knew nothing before.

examples.kr: 운동을 본격적으로 시작하려고 헬스클럽에 등록했어요. 건강에 좋다고 하더라고요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul bongyeokjeogeuro sijak-haryeogo helseu-keulleobe deungnokhaesseoyo. Geongange johdago hadeoragoyo.
examples.en: I registered at the gym to start exercising seriously. They say it’s good for your health.

examples.kr: 요즘 아침에 일어나기 시작하면 커피를 꼭 한 잔 마셔요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum achim-e il-eonagi sijak-hamyeon keopireul kkok han jan masyeoyo.
examples.en: These days, whenever I start my morning, I definitely have a cup of coffee.

examples.kr: 그날 이후로는 매일 영화를 보기 시작했어요. 사람들의 다양한 이야기를 접하고 싶거든요.
examples.romaji: Geu-nal ihuroneun maeil yeonghwareul bogi sijak-haesseoyo. Saramdeurui dayanghan iyagireul jeophago sipgeodeunyo.
examples.en: Since that day, I started watching movies every day because I want to encounter various people's stories.

title: ~기 전에 [gi jeone] (Before)
short_explanation: '~기 전에' is used to express 'before doing something'.
long_explanation: '~기 전에 [gi jeone]' means 'before (doing something).' It marks that one action or state happens prior to another. Commonly used with the infinitive form of the verb plus '기 전에'.

examples.kr: 여행을 가기 전에 짐을 싸야 돼요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengeul gagi jeone jimeul ssaya dwaeyo.
examples.en: You need to pack your luggage before going on a trip.

examples.kr: 미팅 시작하기 전에 발표 준비를 마쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Miting sijak-hagi jeone balpyo junbireul machyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I finished preparing my presentation before the meeting started.

examples.kr: 저는 항상 운동하기 전에 스트레칭을 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangsang undong-hagi jeone seuteurechingeul hamnida.
examples.en: I always stretch before I exercise.

examples.kr: 시험 보기 전에 충분히 공부했어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom bogi jeone chungbunhi gongbuhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I studied enough before taking the exam.

title: ~기 힘들다 [gi himdeulda] (It's hard to...)
short_explanation: Expresses difficulty in performing an action or task.
long_explanation: '~기 힘들다 [gi himdeulda]' is used to describe that it's difficult or hard to do something. '힘들다' means 'hard' or 'tough,' while the preceding '~기' nominalizes the verb, turning it into 'doing X is hard.'

examples.kr: 매일 아침 일찍 일어나기 힘들어요, 하지만 어쩔 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Maeil achim iljjik ireonagi himdeureoyo, hajiman eojjeol su eopseoyo.
examples.en: It's hard to wake up early every morning, but I have no choice.

examples.kr: 한국어를 배우는 게 처음에는 어려웠지만, 계속 연습해도 익숙해지기 힘들다는 걸 깨달았어요.
examples.romaji: Hangukeoreul baeuneun ge cheoeumeneun eoryeowotjiman, gyesok yeonseuphaedo iksukhaejigi himdeuldaneun geol kkaedaratseoyo.
examples.en: At first, learning Korean was tough, but I realized it's still hard to get used to it even with continued practice.

examples.kr: 매일 운동하기 힘들지만, 건강을 위해 꾸준히 하려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Maeil undong-hagi himdeuljiman, geongangeul wihae kkujunhi haryeogo haeyo.
examples.en: It's hard to exercise every day, but I'm trying to do it consistently for my health.

examples.kr: 사람들 앞에서 말하기가 정말 힘들어요, 아직도 계속 연습 중이에요.
examples.romaji: Saramdeul apeseo malhagiga jeongmal himdeureoyo, ajikdo gyesok yeonseup jungieyo.
examples.en: It's really hard to speak in front of people; I'm still practicing.

title: ~기를 [gireul] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the purpose or motive behind an action, similar to 'in order to'.
long_explanation: '~기를 [gireul]' is attached to a verb (in its nominalized form) to mean 'in order to do X' or 'for the purpose of doing X.' It's frequently followed by expressions like '위해(서)' (wihae[seo]), highlighting intent or purpose.

examples.kr: 이 해외 여행은 영어를 배우기를 위해 가는 거예요.
examples.romaji: I haeoe yeohaengeun yeongeoreul baeugireul wihae ganeun geoyeyo.
examples.en: I'm going on this overseas trip in order to learn English.

examples.kr: 아침 일찍 일어났어요, 강의를 듣기를 위해서요.
examples.romaji: Achim iljjik ireonasseoyo, ganguireul deudgireul wihaeseoyo.
examples.en: I woke up early in order to attend the lecture.

examples.kr: 그는 집을 사기를 위해 돈을 모았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jibeul sagireul wihae doneul moasseoyo.
examples.en: He saved money in order to buy a house.

examples.kr: 그녀는 책을 쓰기를 위해 많은 경험을 쌓았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun chaegeul sseugireul wihae manheun gyeongheomeul ssahasseoyo.
examples.en: She accumulated a lot of experience in order to write a book.

title: ~기만 하다 [giman hada] (Just)
short_explanation: '~기만 하다' is used to express that someone or something does only the mentioned action and nothing else.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~기만 하다' is used in Korean to show exclusivity of action — that the verb in question is the only thing done. The nominalized form (~기) plus '만 하다' implies 'only do X.' Often, it can carry a slightly negative nuance or express dissatisfaction because it implies that the action is insufficient or not meeting expectations.

examples.kr: 나는 밤새 공부하기만 했어요, 다른 것은 하나도 하지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun bamsae gongbu-hagiman haesseoyo, dareun geoseun hanado haji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: I just studied all night and didn't do anything else.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 텔레비전을 보기만 해서 그게 걱정이에요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun tellebijeoneul bogiman haeseo geuge geokjeong-ieyo.
examples.en: My father only watches television, which worries me.

examples.kr: 그는 매일 같은 식당에 가서 먹기만 해요. 건강에 좋지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun maeil gateun sikdang-e gaseo meok-giman haeyo. Geongange joji anhayo.
examples.en: He just goes to the same restaurant every day to eat. It's not healthy.

examples.kr: 우리 친구는 게임하기만 하면서 시간을 허비해요.
examples.romaji: Uri chinguneun geim-hagiman hamyeonseo siganeul heobihaeyo.
examples.en: Our friend only plays games and wastes time.

title: ~기에는 [gieneun] (For, in order to)
short_explanation: Used to express a purpose or intention ('for', 'in order to').
long_explanation: '~기에는 [gieneun]' is a structure used in Korean to indicate that one is doing something for a particular purpose or end goal, similar to 'in order to' or 'for the sake of' in English. It highlights the reason for an action and what is required to achieve it.

examples.kr: 토픽 시험을 통과하기에는 더 많이 공부해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Topik siheomeul tong-gwa-hagi-eneun deo mani gongbuhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: I need to study more in order to pass the TOPIK test.

examples.kr: 학교에 늦지 않기에는 아침 일찍 일어나야 돼요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe neujji anh-gieneun achim iljjik ireonaya dwaeyo.
examples.en: You have to wake up early to avoid being late for school.

examples.kr: 자동차를 사기에는 더 많은 돈을 모아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jadongchareul sa-gieneun deo maneun doneul moaya haeyo.
examples.en: You need to save more money to buy a car.

examples.kr: 달리기 대회에서 이기기에는 매일 연습해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Dalligi daehoe-eseo igi-gieneun maeil yeonseuphaeya hamnida.
examples.en: You have to practice every day to win the running competition.

title: ~나 보다 [na boda] (It seems, looks like)
short_explanation: Used to express an assumption or guess, like 'it seems' or 'looks like'.
long_explanation: '~나 보다 [na boda]' is a common grammar pattern in Korean for making inferences or guesses based on observation or context. It can be translated as 'it seems that...' or 'looks like...' in English. It does not express absolute certainty, only a plausible guess or assumption.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좀 춥나 봐요, 외투를 입어야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga jom chupna bwayo, oetureul ibeoya getseoyo.
examples.en: It seems a bit cold, I should wear a coat.

examples.kr: 그가 나를 좋아하나 봐요, 항상 나를 찾아요.
examples.romaji: Geuga nareul joahanabwayo, hangsang nareul chajayo.
examples.en: It looks like he likes me, he always comes to find me.

examples.kr: 후배가 일을 잘하나 봐요, 상사가 그를 칭찬하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hubaega ireul jalhanabwayo, sangsaga geureul chingchanhago isseoyo.
examples.en: It seems the junior is doing his job well; the boss is praising him.

examples.kr: 친구가 오늘 기분이 안 좋나 봐요, 얼굴이 우울해 보여요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga oneul gibuni an jo-nabwayo, eolguri u-ulhae boyeoyo.
examples.en: It seems my friend is in a bad mood today; he looks depressed.

title: ~나요? [nayo?] (Isn't it?, right?)
short_explanation: Used to confirm or get the listener's agreement or opinion.
long_explanation: '~나요? [nayo?]' is a colloquial way in Korean to seek the listener's confirmation or agreement, akin to saying 'Isn't it?' or 'Right?' in English. It invites the other person's feedback or concurrence, helping foster a cooperative tone in conversation.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 정말 좋은데, 외출하면 좋을 것 같아요, 그렇지 않나요?
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga jeongmal joheunde, oechulhamyeon joeul geot gatayo, geureochi annayo?
examples.en: The weather is really nice today, it’d be great to go out, don't you think?

examples.kr: 이 레스토랑의 음식은 맛있는데, 다음에도 여기에 또 오면 좋을 것 같아요, 그렇지 않나요?
examples.romaji: I resteorangui eumsikeun masinneunde, daeumedo yeogie tto omyeon joeul geot gatayo, geureochi annayo?
examples.en: The food at this restaurant is delicious; it’d be nice to come here again next time, wouldn't it?

examples.kr: 그 상황을 이해하지 못한 건 저만이 아니었을 건데, 그렇지 않나요?
examples.romaji: Geu sanghwang-eul ihaehaji mothan geon jeomani anieosseul geonde, geureochi annayo?
examples.en: I doubt I was the only one who couldn't understand that situation, right?

examples.kr: 그 영화는 재미있어서 다시 보고 싶을 것 같아요, 그렇지 않나요?
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaneun jaemiisseoseo dasi bogo sipeul geot gatayo, geureochi annayo?
examples.en: That movie was really fun; I think I'd like to watch it again, wouldn't you?

title: ~남짓 [namjit] (About, around)
short_explanation: Indicates an approximate number or amount (similar to 'about' or 'around').
long_explanation: '~남짓 [namjit]' is added after numbers to indicate an approximate quantity, similar to 'about' or 'around' in English. It suggests the total might be a bit more or a bit less than that number, providing a near approximation.

examples.kr: 저는 이 책을 100페이지 남짓 읽었어요, 아직 많이 남아서 더 읽어야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i chaegeul baekpeiji namjit ilgeosseoyo, ajik mani namaseo deo ilgeoya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I've read about 100 pages of this book; I still have a lot left, so I think I should read more.

examples.kr: 여기서 서울까지는 100km 남짓 거리가 있어요, 차로 가면 1시간 정도 걸려요.
examples.romaji: Yeogiseo Seoul-kkajineun baek-kilomeeteo namjit georiga isseoyo, charo gamyeon hansigan jeongdo geollyeoyo.
examples.en: It's about 100 km from here to Seoul; it takes around an hour by car.

examples.kr: 오늘은 사람이 5000명 남짓 모여서 큰 축제를 즐겼어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul-eun sarami o-cheon-myeong namjit moyeoseo keun chukjereul jeul-gyeosseoyo.
examples.en: About 5,000 people gathered today and enjoyed a big festival.

examples.kr: 내가 지금까지 읽은 책은 대략 200권 남짓이에요.
examples.romaji: Naega jigeumkkaji ilgeun chaegeun daeryak i-baek-gwon namjisieyo.
examples.en: So far, I've read about 200 books.

title: ~는 대로 [neun daero] (As is, the way it is)
short_explanation: Used to express 'the same way', 'just as', or 'exactly like'.
long_explanation: '~는 대로 [neun daero]' can follow a verb stem or a noun to indicate 'the way it is done' or 'just as someone does something.' It emphasizes doing or perceiving something exactly as it is, or following a particular method without changing it.
formation:
1) Verb stem + 는 대로
2) Noun + (으)로 + 대로
(Note: actual usage varies depending on the part of speech.)

examples.kr: 엄마가 집을 청소하는 대로 나도 똑같이 청소해야 돼.
examples.romaji: Eommaga jibeul cheongsohaneun daero nado ttokgati cheongsohaeya dwae.
examples.en: I have to clean the house the same way my mom cleans it.

examples.kr: 그는 원래 하던 대로 계속 동일한 일을 해 왔습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun wonrae hadeon daero gyesok dongilhan ireul hae watseumnida.
examples.en: He has continued doing the same work in the way he originally did.

examples.kr: 친구가 가르쳐준 대로, 그래서 라면을 만들었어.
examples.romaji: Chingu-ga gareuchyeojun daero, geuraeseo ramyeoneul mandeureosseo.
examples.en: I made the ramen exactly the way my friend taught me.

examples.kr: 그 예술가의 그림은 본래 모습 그대로 감상해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Geu yesulgaui geurimeun bonlae moseup geudaero gamsanghaeya haeyo.
examples.en: You should appreciate that artist’s painting in its original state.

title: ~는 바와 같이 [neun bawa gachi] (Just like, as if)
short_explanation: Used to compare two situations, meaning 'just like' or 'as if'.
long_explanation: '~는 바와 같이 [neun bawa gachi]' is used to highlight a similarity between two actions or states. '바' (roughly 'the situation' or 'the way') and '같이' ('like') combine to mean 'just like that situation.' It carries a nuance similar to 'as if...' or 'the way that...' in English.
formation: Verb stem + 는 바와 같이 / Noun + (인) 바와 같이

examples.kr: 그는 마치 태어난 것처럼 눈을 감은 바와 같이 잠을 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun machi taeeonan geotcheoreom nuneul gameun bawa gachi jameul jasseoyo.
examples.en: He slept as if he had closed his eyes the moment he was born.

examples.kr: 학생들은 선생님의 설명을 이해하지 못해, 마치 외국어를 들은 바와 같았어요.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeureun seonsaengnim-ui seolmyeongeul ihaehaji mothae, machi oegugeoreul deureun bawa gatasseoyo.
examples.en: The students couldn’t understand the teacher’s explanation, as if they were listening to a foreign language.

examples.kr: 그녀는 고생한 것처럼 피곤한 얼굴을 한 바와 같이 집에 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gosaenghan geotcheoreom pigonhan eolgureul han bawa gachi jibe wasseoyo.
examples.en: She came home looking exhausted, as if she’d had a hard time.

examples.kr: 시험에 떨어진 것처럼 그는 슬픈 얼굴을 한 바와 같이 방에 들어갔어요.
examples.romaji: Siheome tteoreojin geotcheoreom geuneun seulpeun eolgureul han bawa gachi bange deureogasseoyo.
examples.en: He entered the room with a sad face, as if he had failed the exam.

title: ~는 편이다 [neun pyeonida] (Tend to)
short_explanation: Used to express a habit, tendency, or general characteristic of someone.
long_explanation: The structure '~는 편이다' is used in Korean to express regular habits or tendencies. It is typically translated as 'tend to (do)', 'usually (do)', or 'often (do)'. It helps describe the usual or characteristic behavior of a person or situation.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침 일찍 일어나는 편이에요, 아침에 여러 가지 할 일이 많아서 일찍 일어나야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achim iljjik ireonaneun pyeoniyeyo, achime yeoreo gaji hal iri manaseo iljjik ireonaya haeyo.
examples.en: I tend to wake up early every morning, as I have many things to do in the morning.

examples.kr: 그는 감정적인 사람이어서 분노를 쉽게 보이는 편이에요, 때로는 그의 표현이 과해 보일 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gamjeongjeogin saramieoseo bunnoreul swipge boineun pyeoniyeyo, ttaeroneun geuui pyohyeoni gwahae boil su isseoyo.
examples.en: Because he is an emotional person, he tends to show his anger easily; sometimes his expressions can look excessive.

examples.kr: 사춘기 시절에는 고민이 아무리 커도 부모님한테 말하기 쉽지 않은 편이에요, 그들이 이해 못할 것 같아서 말이죠.
examples.romaji: Sachungi sijeol-eneun gomin-i amuri keodo bumonimhante malhagi swipji aneun pyeoniyeyo, geudeuri ihae mothal geot gataseo malijyo.
examples.en: During adolescence, no matter how big our worries are, we tend not to share them with our parents, thinking they won't understand.

examples.kr: 집에서는 주로 한식을 먹는 편이에요, 한국 요리를 가장 잘하니까요.
examples.romaji: Jib-eseoneun juro hansigeul meokneun pyeoniyeyo, hanguk yorireul gajang jalhanikkayo.
examples.en: At home, we tend to eat Korean food, because that's what I cook best.

title: ~는다는 것 [neundaneun geot] (The fact that)
short_explanation: Used to express 'the fact that' or 'the meaning that' when referring to or summarizing someone's statement or idea.
long_explanation: The '~는다는 것' construction is used to convey or emphasize 'the fact that' something is stated or believed. It can summarize someone’s words, thoughts, or statements. It often appears in discussions to restate a point or highlight that a particular idea or fact is important.

examples.kr: 그가 학교를 다닌다는 것은 정말 열심히 공부하고 있다는 걸 보여주는 증거예요.
examples.romaji: Geuga hakgyoreul danindaneun geoseun jeongmal yeolsimhi gongbuhago ittdaneun geol boyeo-juneun jeunggeo-yeyo.
examples.en: The fact that he attends school shows that he is really studying hard.

examples.kr: 우리가 서로를 이해한다는 것은 정말 중요한 관계를 만들어 가는데 필요한 일이에요.
examples.romaji: Uriga seororeul ihaehandaneun geoseun jeongmal jungyohan gwangyereul mandeureo ganeunde pilyohan iri-eyo.
examples.en: The fact that we understand each other is necessary for building a really important relationship.

examples.kr: 나는 내 친구가 큰 성공을 거두었다는 것을 알고 참 기뻤어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun nae chinguga keun seonggongeul geodueot-daneun geoseul algo cham gippeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was very happy to learn the fact that my friend achieved great success.

examples.kr: 그가 운동을 좋아한다는 것은 건강을 위해 노력한다는 것을 의미해요.
examples.romaji: Geuga undongeul johahandaneun geoseun geongangeul wihae noryeokhandaneun geoseul uimihaeyo.
examples.en: The fact that he likes to exercise means that he's making an effort for his health.

title: ~는데 [neunde] (But, and, so)
short_explanation: Used to connect two clauses in various contexts—often 'but', 'and', or 'so'.
long_explanation: '~는데' is a versatile connector in Korean. Its meaning depends on context—sometimes it indicates contrast (but), sometimes a sequential or related action (and/so). It can also be used at the end of a clause to invite further elaboration or explanation.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추운데 외투를 안 입었어요. 병이 나겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chunneunde oetureul an ibeosseoyo. Byeongi nagesseoyo.
examples.en: It's cold out, but you didn't wear a coat. You might get sick.

examples.kr: 친구를 만나기로 했는데, 비가 와서 계획이 바뀌었어요.
examples.romaji: Chingureul mannagiro haetneunde, biga waseo gyehoegi bakkwieosseoyo.
examples.en: I was supposed to meet a friend, but it rained, so the plan changed.

examples.kr: 오늘 공부를 많이 했는데 여전히 이해가 안 가요.
examples.romaji: Oneul gongbureul manhi haetneunde yeojeonhi ihaega an gayo.
examples.en: I studied a lot today, but I still don't understand.

examples.kr: 그가 웃었는데, 알고 보니 나한테 화가 나 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga useotneunde, algo boni nahante hwaga na isseosseoyo.
examples.en: He smiled, but it turned out he was actually angry with me.

title: ~는지 알다/모르다 [neunji alda/moreuda] (Know/don't know whether)
short_explanation: Used to express knowing or not knowing whether something is or will be the case.
long_explanation: The '~는지 알다/모르다' structure is used to indicate whether the speaker (or someone else) knows or doesn't know a particular fact or circumstance. It can also appear in questions to ask if someone knows about a certain situation.

examples.kr: 그가 학교에 갔는지 알아요?
examples.romaji: Geuga hakgyoe gatneunji arayo?
examples.en: Do you know if he went to school?

examples.kr: 저는 그녀가 아직 사랑하는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun geunyeoga ajik saranghaneunji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I don't know if she still loves (me or someone).

examples.kr: 우리가 이길 수 있는지 알아요?
examples.romaji: Uriga igil su inneunji arayo?
examples.en: Do you know if we can win?

examples.kr: 너가 그의 생일을 기억하는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Neoga geuui saengireul gieokhaneunji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I don't know if you remember his birthday.

title: ~는지라 [neunjira] (Because, since)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the reason or cause ('because', 'since').
long_explanation: '~는지라 [neunjira]' emphasizes that the condition in the first clause is the reason or cause for the following situation. It can carry a nuance that the cause is somewhat pressing or unavoidable, functioning like 'because' or 'since'.

examples.kr: 그녀가 너무 열심히 공부하는지라 숙제도 항상 완벽하게 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga neomu yeolsimhi gongbuhaneunjira sukjedo hangsang wanbyeokhage haeyo.
examples.en: Because she studies so hard, she always does her homework perfectly.

examples.kr: 날씨가 너무 추운지라 학교에 가고 싶지 않아.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga neomu chuunjira hakgyoe gago sipji ana.
examples.en: Since it's so cold, I don't want to go to school.

examples.kr: 아기가 아프는지라 온 밤을 잠을 이루지 못했습니다.
examples.romaji: Agiga apeuneunjira on bameul jameul iruji mothaetseumnida.
examples.en: Because the baby was sick, I couldn't sleep all night.

examples.kr: 이번 주에 일이 많아서 너무 바쁜지라 휴식할 시간이 전혀 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jue iri manaseo neomu bappeunjira hyusikhal sigani jeonhyeo eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: I was so busy this week due to having a lot of work, so I had no time to rest.

title: ~다가 [daga] (While doing, was doing but)
short_explanation: Connects two actions, indicating the first action was ongoing but got interrupted or changed by the second action.
long_explanation: '~다가' shows that one action or event was in progress when another action or situation intervened. It often implies that the second action wasn’t necessarily planned, but it happened and stopped the first action in its tracks.

examples.kr: 책을 읽다가 잠이 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Chaegeul ilgdaga jami deureosseoyo.
examples.en: I fell asleep while reading a book.

examples.kr: 집에 가다가 차가 고장 나서 버스를 타고 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe gadaga chaga gojang naseo beoseureul tago wasseoyo.
examples.en: On my way home, my car broke down, so I took the bus.

examples.kr: 밥을 먹다가 친구가 급히 전화해서 다 못 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Babeul meokdaga chinguga geuphi jeonhwahaeseo da mot meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: While I was eating, my friend suddenly called, so I couldn’t finish my meal.

examples.kr: 공부하다가 갑자기 나가야 했어요, 부장님이 오셔서요.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhadaga gapjagi nagaya haesseoyo, bujangnimi osyeoseoyo.
examples.en: I was studying, but I had to leave suddenly because my boss arrived.

title: ~다가는 [daganeun] (If continue doing)
short_explanation: Expresses a potential negative outcome if a certain action continues.
long_explanation: The pattern '~다가는' warns about a negative result or consequence if the preceding action persists. It’s used to caution someone: 'If you keep doing X, then Y (bad result) will happen.'

examples.kr: 너는 계속 이렇게 늦게까지 일하다가는 몸이 망가져 버릴 거야.
examples.romaji: Neoneun gyesok ireoke neutgekkaji ilhadaganeun momi manggajyeo beoril geoya.
examples.en: If you keep working this late, your health will suffer.

examples.kr: 점심시간에 밥 대신 커피만 마시다가는 건강에 문제가 생길 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeomsim sigane bap daesin keopiman masidaganeun geongange munjega saenggil geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you keep drinking only coffee instead of eating lunch, you'll have health problems.

examples.kr: 우리가 이렇게 자주 충돌하다가는 이 관계는 오래가지 못할 거야.
examples.romaji: Uriga ireoke jaju chungdolhadaganeun i gwangyeneun oraegaji mothal geoya.
examples.en: If we keep having conflicts so often, this relationship won’t last long.

examples.kr: 매일 밤 늦게 잠들다가는 아침에 일어나기 힘들어질 거야.
examples.romaji: Maeil bam neutge jamdeuldaganeun achime ireonagi himdeureojil geoya.
examples.en: If you keep going to bed late every night, it will be hard to get up in the morning.

title: ~다가도 [dagado] (Even though was doing)
short_explanation: Indicates that an unexpected or sudden change occurred while in the middle of doing something.
long_explanation: '~다가도' is used when something disrupts or abruptly changes an action that was in progress. It conveys a nuance of surprise or sudden shift, differing from what was initially expected to happen.

examples.kr: 나는 집에 가다가도 갑자기 비가 많이 와서 우산을 샀어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jibe gadagado gapjagi biga mani waseo usaneul sasseoyo.
examples.en: Even though I was on my way home, it suddenly started raining a lot, so I bought an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그는 공부하다가도 친구가 영화를 보자고 하면 바로 그만두고 영화관에 가요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gongbuhadagado chinguga yeonghwareul bojago hamyeon baro geumandugo yeonghwagwane gayo.
examples.en: Even if he’s studying, if his friend suggests watching a movie, he immediately stops and goes to the cinema.

examples.kr: 주인공이 결승전을 이기다가도 마지막에 실수를 해서 패배했어요.
examples.romaji: Juingongi gyeolseungjeoneul igidagado majimage silsureul haeseo paebaehaesseoyo.
examples.en: Even though the main character was winning the final, he made a mistake at the end and lost.

examples.kr: 우리는 피크닉을 가다가도 갑자기 날씨가 안 좋아져서 집으로 돌아왔어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun pikeunikeul gadagado gapjagi nalssiga an joajyeoseo jibeuro dolawasseoyo.
examples.en: We were on our way to a picnic, but the weather suddenly got bad, so we went back home.

title: ~다니 [dani] (Exclamation, surprise)
short_explanation: Used to express exclamation, surprise, disbelief, or shock.
long_explanation: '~다니 [dani]' conveys strong emotional reaction—amazement, incredulity, or shock—when hearing or realizing something. It's similar to saying 'I can't believe that...' or 'Really?!' in English. It can appear in direct or reported speech.
formation: Verb + 아/어/여 + 다니 / Adjective stem + 다니

examples.kr: 네가 그녀와 결혼하려고 한다니, 정말 믿을 수 없어!
examples.romaji: Nega geunyeowa gyeolhonharyeogo handani, jeongmal mideul su eopseo!
examples.en: You're going to marry her? I really can't believe it!

examples.kr: 내가 이렇게 중요한 프로젝트를 맡게 될 줄이라니, 정말 놀라워!
examples.romaji: Naega ireohge jungyohan peurojekteureul matge doel jurirani, jeongmal nollawo!
examples.en: I'm really surprised that I ended up being in charge of such an important project!

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있다니, 왜 아무도 말해 주지 않았지?
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi itdani, wae amudo malhae juji anhatji?
examples.en: There's a test tomorrow? Why didn’t anyone tell me?

examples.kr: 그가 이런 일을 할 줄 알았다니, 나는 정말 깜짝 놀랐어!
examples.romaji: Geuga ireon ireul hal jul alatdani, naneun jeongmal kkamjjak nollasseo!
examples.en: I'm really shocked that he would do such a thing!

title: ~다면 [damyeon] (If it is the case that)
short_explanation: Expresses a hypothetical condition (similar to 'if' in English).
long_explanation: '~다면 [damyeon]' is used to form conditional statements, much like 'if' in English. It introduces a hypothetical scenario or condition, and the result or conclusion follows in the same sentence or after.

examples.kr: 시간이 있다면, 저는 여기서 내일까지 기다릴 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sigani itdamyeon, jeoneun yeogiseo naeilkkaji gidaril su isseoyo.
examples.en: If I have time, I can wait here until tomorrow.

examples.kr: 네가 여기에 온다면, 저녁 식사를 함께 할 수 있겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nega yeogie ondamyeon, jeonyeok siksareul hamkke hal su issgesseoyo.
examples.en: If you come here, we can have dinner together.

examples.kr: 비가 오다면, 우산을 가져오세요.
examples.romaji: Biga odamyeon, usaneul gajyeo-oseyo.
examples.en: If it's raining, bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그게 실제라면, 정말 놀라운 일이에요.
examples.romaji: Geuge siljelamyeon, jeongmal nollaun irieyo.
examples.en: If that’s real, it's truly amazing.

title: ~더라도 [deorado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'even if' or 'even though', presenting a hypothetical or contrary-to-fact condition.
long_explanation: '~더라도 [deorado]' is a Korean grammar pattern meaning 'even if' or 'even though.' It introduces a hypothetical or imagined scenario that does not prevent a certain action or outcome in the following clause. The overall sense is that the second action/decision remains firm despite the 'even if' condition.

examples.kr: 비가 오더라도 나는 학교에 갈 거예요, 학습을 계속해야 하니까요.
examples.romaji: Biga odeorado naneun hakgyoe gal geoyeyo, hakseubeul gyesokhaeya hanikkayo.
examples.en: Even if it rains, I will go to school, because I have to continue studying.

examples.kr: 시험이 어렵더라도 최선을 다하겠습니다, 실패는 선택이 아니에요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi eoryeopdeorado choiseoneul dahagessseumnida, silpaeneun seontaegi anieyo.
examples.en: Even if the test is difficult, I will do my best, because failure is not an option.

examples.kr: 너무 추워지더라도 스키를 탈 거예요, 그것이 제가 즐기는 방법이니까요.
examples.romaji: Neomu chuuojideorado seukireul tal geoyeyo, geugeosi jega jeulgineun bangbeom-inikkayo.
examples.en: Even if it gets really cold, I'll still go skiing, because that's how I enjoy myself.

examples.kr: 내일이 휴일이더라도 나는 일찍 일어날 거예요, 그래야 늦지 않을 거니까요.
examples.romaji: Naeiri hyuil-ideorado naneun iljjik ireonal geoyeyo, geuraeya neujji anheul geonikkayo.
examples.en: Even if tomorrow is a holiday, I’m going to wake up early so I won’t be late for anything.

title: ~더라구요 [deoraguyo] (It seemed, I noticed)
short_explanation: Expresses the speaker's personal observation or realization about a past event.
long_explanation: '~더라구요' is a casual, conversational ending in Korean for sharing something you noticed or realized. It indicates the speaker is conveying newly discovered information or a personal impression from experience. It usually attaches to the verb stem in the past or descriptive form.

examples.kr: 저는 어제 큰 할인이 있는 걸 보고 정말 놀랐더라구요, 그래서 바로 쇼핑하러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eoje keun halini issneun geol bogo jeongmal nollatdeoraguyo, geuraeseo baro syoping-hareo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I was really surprised to see a big discount yesterday, so I went shopping right away.

examples.kr: 날씨가 흐려서 산책 가기에 별로라고 느꼈더라구요, 그래서 집에 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga heuryeoseo sanchaek gagie byeollorago neukkyeotdeoraguyo, geuraeseo jibe isseotsseumnida.
examples.en: Because the weather was cloudy, I felt it wasn’t a good day for a walk, so I stayed home.

examples.kr: 친구가 점점 몸이 커지는 걸 보니까 임신이구나 싶더라구요, 그래서 축하해 주었습니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguga jeomjeom momi keojineun geol bonikka imsin-iguna sipdeoraguyo, geuraeseo chukahae jueotsseumnida.
examples.en: Noticing my friend’s body gradually getting bigger, I realized she was pregnant, so I congratulated her.

examples.kr: 그 영화를 보고 나서 감독이 정말 재능 있구나 싶더라구요, 그래서 더 관심이 생겼어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwareul bogo naseo gamdogi jeongmal jaeneung itguna sipdeoraguyo, geuraeseo deo gwansimi saenggyeosseoyo.
examples.en: After watching that movie, I realized the director is really talented, and I became more interested.

title: ~던 [deon] (That used to)
short_explanation: Refers to a past habit or situation that no longer continues.
long_explanation: '~던 [deon]' is used to describe a past action or state that used to happen or exist but no longer does. It often carries a nostalgic or retrospective nuance. It modifies a following noun, indicating something like, ‘the cafe I used to go to,’ or ‘the toy he used to play with.’

examples.kr: 저는 고등학교 때 자주 가던 카페에 오랜만에 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun godeunghakgyo ttae jaju gadeon kape-e oraenmane wasseoyo.
examples.en: I came back to the cafe I used to visit often in high school, for the first time in a while.

examples.kr: 언니는 옛날에 먹던 초콜릿을 다시 찾으려고 노력 중이에요.
examples.romaji: Eonni-neun yetnare meokdeon chokolliteul dasi chajaryeogo noryeok jungieyo.
examples.en: My older sister is trying to find the chocolate she used to eat in the past.

examples.kr: 너는 내가 매일 입던 터틀넥을 기억하니?
examples.romaji: Neoneun naega maeil ipdeon teoteulnek-eul gieokhani?
examples.en: Do you remember the turtleneck I used to wear every day?

examples.kr: 아빠는 예전에 조카와 놀아주던 장난감을 구하러 서점에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Appaneun yejeone jokawa norajudeon jangnangameul guhareo seojeome gasseoyo.
examples.en: Dad went to the bookstore to look for the toy he used to play with when my niece was little.

title: ~도록 [dorok] (So that, in order to)
short_explanation: Indicates purpose or reason for an action; 'so that', 'in order to'.
long_explanation: '~도록 [dorok]' expresses purpose, goal, or extent, similar to 'so that' or 'in order to' in English. It shows the reason or aim behind an action. It can also imply how long or to what degree an action continues.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 잘하게 되도록 매일 한 시간씩 공부하려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeo-reul jalhage doedorok maeil han siganssik gongbu-haryeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I try to study an hour every day so that I can become good at Korean.

examples.kr: 건강을 유지하도록, 적절히 운동하고 영양가 있는 식사를 해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Geongangeul yujihadorok, jeokjeolhi undonghago yeongyangga inneun siksareul haeya hamnida.
examples.en: In order to stay healthy, you should exercise appropriately and eat nutritious meals.

examples.kr: 이론을 이해하도록 선생님이 복잡한 개념을 간단하게 설명해 주셨어요.
examples.romaji: Iron-eul ihaehadorok seonsaengnimi bokjaphan gaenyeomeul gandanhage seolmyeonghae jusyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The teacher explained the complex concepts simply so that we could understand the theory.

examples.kr: 아이들이 안전하게 놀 수 있도록, 놀이터에는 안전장치가 잘 설치되어 있어요.
examples.romaji: Aideuri anjeonhage nol su itdorok, noriteo-eneun anjeon-jangchiga jal seolchidoeeo isseoyo.
examples.en: So that children can play safely, the playground is equipped with proper safety devices.

title: ~도록 하다 [dorok hada] (Make sure, see to it that)
short_explanation: Used to give instructions or commands to ensure a certain outcome.
long_explanation: '~도록 하다' can mean 'make sure to,' 'ensure that,' or 'see to it that.' The speaker is directing someone (or themselves) to do something in order to achieve or maintain a particular result. It often carries a sense of imperative or strong advice.

examples.kr: 당신이 내일 꼭 출석하도록 하세요. 중요한 정보를 공유해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini naeil kkok chulseok-hadorok haseyo. Jungyohan jeongboreul gongyuhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: Make sure you attend tomorrow. We need to share important information.

examples.kr: 식사 후에는 손을 깨끗이 씻도록 하세요.
examples.romaji: Siksa hu-eneun soneul kkaekkeushi ssitdorok haseyo.
examples.en: Make sure you wash your hands thoroughly after meals.

examples.kr: 내년까지 모든 프로젝트를 마무리하도록 해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naenyeonkkaji modeun peurojekteureul mamurihadorok haeya hamnida.
examples.en: You must see to it that all projects are finished by next year.

examples.kr: 학생들이 시험에 잘 대비하도록 준비물을 미리 안내해주세요.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeuri siheome jal daebihadorok junbimureul miri annaehaejuseyo.
examples.en: Please inform the students in advance about what they need, so they can prepare well for the exam.

title: ~라든지 [radeunji] (Or, either)
short_explanation: Lists options or possibilities; means 'or' or 'either'.
long_explanation: '~라든지 [radeunji]' is used to present multiple possible options or examples, similar to 'or' in English. You can list items or actions, emphasizing that these are merely examples among many possibilities.

examples.kr: 그림을 그린다든지, 사진을 찍는다든지, 운동을 한다든지, 취미 활동은 다양해요.
examples.romaji: Geurimeul geurindadeunji, sajineul jjikneundadeunji, undongeul handadeunji, chwimi hwaldongeun dayanghaeyo.
examples.en: You can draw pictures, take photos, or exercise—there are many different hobbies.

examples.kr: 빨리 와야 하는 이유가 배가 고프다든지, 해야 할 일이 있다든지, 여러 가지일 수 있겠죠.
examples.romaji: Ppalli waya haneun iyuga baega gopeudadeunji, haeya hal iri itdadeunji, yeoreo gajil su itgetjyo.
examples.en: Maybe you need to come quickly because you’re hungry, or you have a task to do—there can be various reasons.

examples.kr: 아이스크림 사러 갈 건데, 바닐라라든지 초콜릿라든지 다른 맛도 많이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Aiseukeurim sareo gal geonde, banillaradeunji chokollit-radeunji dareun matdo manhi isseoyo.
examples.en: I’m going to buy ice cream; there’s vanilla, chocolate, or many other flavors.

examples.kr: 책을 좋아하는 사람들은 로맨스 소설이라든지, 자기계발서라든지, 다양한 장르를 즐길 수 있죠.
examples.romaji: Chaekeul johahaneun saramdeureun romaenseu sosoliradeunji, jagigyebalseoradeunji, dayanghan janreureul jeulgil su itjyo.
examples.en: People who enjoy reading can read romance novels, self-improvement books, or other various genres.

title: ~라도 [rado] (Even if, at least)
short_explanation: Indicates a fallback option ('at least') or a concession ('even if').
long_explanation: The Korean particle '~라도' often has two core usages: (1) 'even if' (though somewhat less strong than '~더라도'), or (2) selecting the least favorable or minimal option when there is no better choice, translating to 'at least.' It implies partial satisfaction or a fallback stance.
formation:
1) Noun + (이)라도
2) Sometimes attached to verbs or adjectives (but often overlaps with '~더라도').

examples.kr: 숙제를 하지 않더라도, 수업은 꼭 들어야 해요.
examples.romaji: Sukjereul haji antdeorado, sueobeun kkok deureoya haeyo.
examples.en: Even if you didn't do your homework, you must attend class.

examples.kr: 그 집이 너무 비싸더라도 돈이 없다면 작은 방이라도 임대해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Geu jibi neomu bissadeorado doni eopsdamyeon jageun bang-irado imdaehaeya haeyo.
examples.en: Even if that house is too expensive, if you have no money, you should at least rent a small room.

examples.kr: 취업이 어렵고 힘들더라도 최소한 하루에 한 번은 지원서를 보내야 해요.
examples.romaji: Chwieobi eoryeopgo himdeuldeorado choesohan harue han beon-eun jiweonseoreul bonaeya haeyo.
examples.en: Even if job-hunting is hard, you should at least send out one application a day.

examples.kr: 맛집에서 다 주문하지 못한다면, 작은 디저트라도 사 보는 게 어떨까요?
examples.romaji: Matjibeseo da jumunhaji mothandamyeon, jageun dijeoteurado sa boneun ge eotteolkayo?
examples.en: If you can’t order everything at the restaurant, how about at least getting a small dessert?

title: ~라서 [raseo] (Because [it is Noun], so...)
short_explanation: Used with nouns to express reason or cause, meaning 'because it is...' or 'so...'.
long_explanation: '~라서 [raseo]' (or '~이라서') attaches to **nouns**, showing that 'because (it is) X, ... follows.' It’s similar to '(으)라서' usage. For verbs and adjectives, Korean often uses '-아/어/해서.'

examples.kr: 오늘은 휴일이라서 출근 안 해도 돼요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun hyuil-iraseo chulgeun an haedo dwaeyo.
examples.en: Because it's a holiday today, I don’t have to go to work.

examples.kr: 그 식당은 유명한 곳이라서 항상 손님이 많아요.
examples.romaji: Geu sikdang-eun yumyeonghan gos-iraseo hangsang sonnimi manhayo.
examples.en: Because that restaurant is a famous place, it always has a lot of customers.

examples.kr: 요즘은 방학이라서 학교에 학생이 거의 없어요.
examples.romaji: Yojeumeun banghak-iraseo hakgyoe haksaengi geoui eopseoyo.
examples.en: These days it's vacation (break), so there are hardly any students at school.

examples.kr: 주말이라서 도로가 많이 막히네요.
examples.romaji: Jumal-iraseo doroga manhi makhineyo.
examples.en: Because it's the weekend, the roads are really congested.

title: ~라야 하다 [rayahada] (Must, have to)
short_explanation: A formal/literary way to express obligation or necessity, akin to 'must.'
long_explanation: The phrase '~라야 하다' is a somewhat formal expression meaning 'must do X' or 'it’s necessary to do X.' It can appear with nouns (e.g., '학생이라야 한다') or with certain verb forms. In modern Korean, it's less common than '~아/어야 하다.'
formation: Noun + (이)라야 하다 / Certain verb forms + 라야 하다

examples.kr: 이 일은 전문가라야 할 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: I ireun jeonmungagara-ya hal su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: It seems only a specialist can do this job (i.e. you must be a specialist).

examples.kr: 정직한 사람이라야 이 책임을 맡을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeongjikhan saram-iraya i chaegimeul mateul su isseoyo.
examples.en: You must be an honest person to take on this responsibility.

examples.kr: 정말 간절한 열망이라야 그런 노력을 계속할 수 있죠.
examples.romaji: Jeongmal ganjeolhan yeolmang-iraya geureon noryeokeul gyesokhal su itjyo.
examples.en: Only a truly earnest desire can drive someone to keep up that effort.

examples.kr: 건강이라야 무엇이든 할 수 있다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Geongang-iraya mueot-ideun hal su itddago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: I believe you have to be healthy if you want to do anything.

title: ~려고 [ryeogo] (Intending to, planning to)
short_explanation: Used to express intention or plan to do something.
long_explanation: '~려고' attaches to the verb stem to show the speaker’s plan or intention, similar to 'I'm going to...' or 'I'm planning to...' in English. It’s often used with future actions the speaker has decided on.

examples.kr: 내일 친구들과 영화를 보러 가려고 하는데, 아직 어떤 영화를 볼지 못 정했어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil chingudeulgwa yeonghwareul boreo garyeogo haneunde, ajik eotteon yeonghwareul bolji mot jeonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I'm planning to watch a movie with my friends tomorrow, but I haven’t decided which one yet.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에 책을 읽으려고 했지만 너무 피곤해서 그냥 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul bam-e chaekeul ilgeuryeogo haetjiman neomu pigonhaeseo geunyang jasseoyo.
examples.en: I intended to read a book tonight, but I was too tired and just went to sleep.

examples.kr: 부모님 댁에 가려고 했는데 갑자기 일이 생겨서 못 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Bumonim daege garyeogo haetneunde gapjagi ili saenggyeoseo mot gasseoyo.
examples.en: I was planning to visit my parents, but something came up and I couldn’t go.

examples.kr: 엄마는 아빠에게 새 지갑을 주려고 했는데, 아빠가 이미 같은 걸 사서 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun appaege sae jigabeul juryeogo haetneunde, appaga imi gateun geol saseo nollasseoyo.
examples.en: Mom intended to give Dad a new wallet, but she was surprised because he’d already bought the same one.

title: ~려고 하다 [ryeogo hada] (Try to, plan to)
short_explanation: Used to express intention or an attempt to do something; similar to 'try to' or 'plan to' in English.
long_explanation: '~려고 하다 [ryeogo hada]' is a commonly used verb construction that indicates the subject's intention or attempt to do something in the near future. It can be translated as 'I’m going to...', 'I plan to...', or 'I’m trying to...' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 내일 친구를 만나려고 하지만, 계획이 바뀔 수도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun naeil chingureul mannaryeogo hajiman, gyehoegi bakkwil sudo isseoyo.
examples.en: I plan to meet my friend tomorrow, but the plan might change.

examples.kr: 그는 기타를 배우려고 했지만, 시간이 많지 않아서 결국 포기했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gitareul baeuryeogo haetjiman, sigani manchi anhaseo gyeolguk pogihaesseoyo.
examples.en: He tried to learn the guitar, but he didn’t have much time, so he gave up.

examples.kr: 우리는 이번 주말에 등산을 가려고 하지만, 날씨가 좋지 않아서 가능성이 적어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun ibeon jumare deungsane garyeogo hajiman, nalssiga johji anhaseo ganeungseongi jeogeoyo.
examples.en: We’re planning to go hiking this weekend, but since the weather isn’t good, it’s unlikely.

examples.kr: 제가 이제부터 새로운 기술을 배우려고 합니다. 이는 제 전문성을 높이기 위해서예요.
examples.romaji: Jega ijebuteo saeroun gisuleul baeuryeogo hamnida. Ineun je jeonmunseongeul nopigi wihaeseoyeyo.
examples.en: I’m going to learn new skills from now on. This is to improve my professional expertise.

title: ~려는데 [ryeoneunde] (Trying to, want to, but)
short_explanation: Used to express an intention or plan, followed by a difficulty or complication.
long_explanation: '~려는데 [ryeoneunde]' indicates that the speaker has an intention or plan (similar to '~려고 하는데'), but something is making it uncertain or difficult. It’s often followed by explanations of why the plan might fail or change.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 조금 일찍 집에 가려는데, 갑자기 긴급 업무가 들어와서 힘들 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul jogeum iljjik jibe garyeoneunde, gapjagi gingeup eopmuga deureowaseo himdeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: I was trying to leave work early today, but an urgent task came up, so it looks difficult.

examples.kr: 처음에는 그 프로젝트를 완료하려는데, 여러 가지 문제가 생겨서 완성하지 못했습니다.
examples.romaji: Cheoeumeneun geu peurojekteureul wallyoharyeoneunde, yeoreogaji munjega saenggyeoseo wanseonghaji mothaesseumnida.
examples.en: At first, I intended to finish the project, but various problems arose and I couldn’t complete it.

examples.kr: 내일 친구와 영화를 보려는데, 모든 표가 매진된 상태라서 갈 수 있을지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil chinguwa yeonghwareul boryeoneunde, modeun pyoga maejindoen sangtaeraseo gal su isseulji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I’m planning to watch a movie with my friend tomorrow, but I’m not sure if we can go because it’s sold out.

examples.kr: 여행을 가려는데, 날씨가 좋지 않아서 또 미룰지 고민 중이에요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengeul garyeoneunde, nalssiga johji anaseo tto mirulji gomin jungieyo.
examples.en: I want to go on a trip, but the weather’s bad, so I’m debating whether to postpone again.

title: ~리가 없다 [riga eopda] (There’s no way that)
short_explanation: Expresses impossibility or disbelief.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 리가 없다' indicates that something is impossible or that there’s no chance it could happen. It conveys strong disbelief about the situation. It can be translated as 'There’s no way that...' or 'It can’t be that...'.

examples.kr: 그가 저에게 거짓말을 할 리가 없어요. 그는 정말 정직한 사람이에요.
examples.romaji: Geuga jeoege geojismareul hal riga eopsoyo. Geuneun jeongmal jeongjikhan saramieyo.
examples.en: There’s no way he would lie to me. He’s very honest.

examples.kr: 너무 많이 먹어서 더 먹을 수 있을 리가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu mani meogeoseo deo meogeul su isseul riga eopsoyo.
examples.en: I’ve eaten so much that there’s no way I could eat more.

examples.kr: 가방이 너무 무거워서 더 들 수 있을 리가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Gabangi neomu mugeowoseo deo deul su isseul riga eopsoyo.
examples.en: My bag is too heavy, so there’s no way I can carry any more.

examples.kr: 제가 빨간색을 싫어해서, 그 색 옷을 입을 리가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jega ppalgansaeg-eul silheohaeseo, geu saeg oseul ibeul riga eopsoyo.
examples.en: I hate the color red, so there’s no way I’d wear clothes in that color.

title: ~리요 [riyo] (Likely, probably)
short_explanation: A more formal or older-style ending expressing a prediction or assumption.
long_explanation: '~리요' is a somewhat archaic or very formal style verb ending used for predictions or expectations about the future. It implies a relatively firm belief in the likelihood of the event. Modern usage might be rare in casual speech, but it can appear in narratives or historical contexts.

examples.kr: 내일은 비가 올 리요. 우산을 챙기시지요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun biga ol riyo. Usaneul chaenggisijiyo.
examples.en: It is likely to rain tomorrow. Please take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그분은 맛있는 음식을 좋아할 리요, 요리사이니까요.
examples.romaji: Geu-buneun masinneun eumsigeul johahal riyo, yorisainikkayo.
examples.en: He probably likes good food, because he’s a chef.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 대성공할 리요, 유명 배우들이 다 나오니까요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun daeseong-gonghal riyo, yumyeong baudeuriga da naonikkan-yo.
examples.en: This movie is likely to be a huge success because it has all famous actors.

examples.kr: 오늘은 버스가 많이 지연될 리요, 출근 시간 교통이 복잡하거든요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun beoseuga manhi jiyeondoel riyo, chulgeun sigan gyotongi bokjaphageodeunyo.
examples.en: Buses will probably be delayed a lot today, because traffic is complicated during rush hour.

title: ~마다 [mada] (Every)
short_explanation: Indicates something happens regularly or repeats at a certain interval.
long_explanation: '~마다' is a particle attached to time expressions (or other nouns) to mean 'every'—for example, 'every day,' 'every week,' or 'every time.' It shows that some event, activity, or situation occurs each time or regularly at that interval.

examples.kr: 나는 매일 아침마다 운동을 해요. 건강을 위해 꼭 필요한 습관이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeil achim-mada undongeul haeyo. Geongangeul wihae kkok pil-yo-han seupgwan-ieyo.
examples.en: I exercise every morning. It’s an essential habit for my health.

examples.kr: 이곳은 점심시간마다 사람이 많아져서 자리를 잡기 힘들어요.
examples.romaji: Igoseun jeomsimsigan-mada sarami manajyeoseo jarireul jabgi himdeureoyo.
examples.en: Every lunchtime, it gets crowded here, so it's tough to find a seat.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 주말마다 쉬지 않고 대청소를 해요.
examples.romaji: Uri eommaneun jumal-mada swiji anhgo daecheong-soreul haeyo.
examples.en: Every weekend, my mom does a thorough cleaning without resting.

examples.kr: 가방 안에는 물병마다 작은 간식이 하나씩 들어 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gabang aneneun mulbyeong-mada jageun gansigi hanassik deureo isseoyo.
examples.en: Inside the bag, there’s a small snack in each water bottle.

title: ~만 [man] (Only, just)
short_explanation: Indicates exclusivity or limitation, equivalent to 'only' or 'just' in English.
long_explanation: '~만 [man]' is a particle attached to nouns (or pronouns) to show that something is restricted, or that it applies exclusively to that noun. It conveys ‘only X’ or ‘just X,’ excluding all else.

examples.kr: 저는 커피만 마셨어요. 다른 음료는 전혀 마시지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopiman masyeosseoyo. Dareun eumryoneun jeonhyeo masiji anasseoyo.
examples.en: I only drank coffee. I didn’t have any other drinks at all.

examples.kr: 나만 그 사실을 알고 있어요. 다른 사람들은 모르더라고요.
examples.romaji: Naman geu sasileul algo isseoyo. Dareun saramdeureun moreudeoragoyo.
examples.en: Only I know that fact. It seems like other people don’t know.
