examples.kr: 이번 주말에는 휴식만 취할 생각이에요. 다른 건 안 하려고요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal-eneun hyusikman chwihal saeng-gag-ieyo. Dareun geon an haryeogoyo.
examples.en: This weekend, I plan to do nothing but rest. I’m not going to do anything else.

examples.kr: 그는 친구들만 만나러 갔고, 가족은 만나지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chingudeul-man mannareo gatgo, gajogeun mannaji anasseoyo.
examples.en: He only went to see his friends; he didn’t meet his family.

title: ~만 하다 [man hada] (Sufficient, just right)
short_explanation: Expresses that a certain amount or condition is enough or suitable.
long_explanation: This structure can be interpreted as ‘(it) is just enough to...’ or ‘(it) suffices to...’. Although in modern usage the pattern '~(으)ㄹ 만 하다' often means ‘worth doing something,’ certain contexts use ‘~만 하다’ to mean that something is just right or sufficient.

examples.kr: 이 정도 양이면 딱 만 하다고 생각해요. 더 이상 필요 없어요.
examples.romaji: I jeongdo yangimyeon ttak man hadago saeng-gakhaeyo. Deo isang pil-yo eopseoyo.
examples.en: I think this amount is just enough. We don't need any more.

examples.kr: 음식이 너무 뜨거울 때는 물을 넣어서 딱 먹기만 하게 만들 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Eumsiki neomu tteugeoul ttaeneun muleul neoeoseo ttak meok-giman hage mandeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: When the food is too hot, you can add some water so it’s just right to eat.

examples.kr: 시험 공부는 충분히 했으니 오늘은 휴식만 하면 될 만 해요.
examples.romaji: Siheom gongbuneun chungbunhi haesseuni oneureun hyusikman hamyeon doel man haeyo.
examples.en: I studied enough for the test, so just resting today should be sufficient.

examples.kr: 이 음악은 방해가 안 될 정도로 조용해서 일하면서 듣기만 하네요.
examples.romaji: I eumageun banghaega an doel jeongdoro joyonghaeseo ilhamyeonseo deuk-giman haneyo.
examples.en: This music is quiet enough not to be distracting, so I can just listen while working.

title: ~만큼 [mankeum] (As much as, as many as)
short_explanation: Indicates an equivalent degree or amount, meaning 'as much as' or 'to the extent that.'
long_explanation: '~만큼 [mankeum]' is used to denote an equivalent degree, quantity, or extent, similar to English ‘as much as’ or ‘as many as.’ It can attach to nouns, verbs, or adjectives, indicating the extent or degree matches the specified reference.

examples.kr: 그는 자신의 실력만큼 보수를 받고 싶어해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jasin-ui sill-yeok mankeum bosureul batgo sip-eohaeyo.
examples.en: He wants to be paid as much as his skill level merits.

examples.kr: 당신이 노력한 만큼 결과가 따라올 거예요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini noryeokhan mankeum gyeolgwa-ga ttaraol geoyeyo.
examples.en: You will get results in proportion to how much effort you put in.

examples.kr: 그녀는 남들만큼 노래를 잘 부를 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun namdeul mankeum noraereul jal bureul su isseoyo.
examples.en: She can sing as well as anyone else.

examples.kr: 이 음식은 보이는 만큼 맛있어요.
examples.romaji: I eumsikeun boineun mankeum masisseoyo.
examples.en: This food is as tasty as it looks.

title: ~며/면서 [myeo/myeonseo] (While)
short_explanation: Used to indicate two simultaneous or closely related actions/states, similar to 'while' in English.
long_explanation: The endings '~며' or '~면서' show that two actions happen at the same time or that one action occurs in the background of another. It can also highlight a contrast or additional aspect, but the main nuance is simultaneity—doing two things at once or having two states occur together.

examples.kr: 집에 갈 때 음악을 들으면서 메시지를 확인해요.
examples.romaji: Jibe gal ttae eumageul deureumyeonseo mesijireul hwakinhaeyo.
examples.en: I check my messages while listening to music on my way home.

examples.kr: 학교에 입학하기 전에 열심히 공부하면서도 다른 활동들에도 참여했어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe iphak-hagi jeone yeolsimhi gongbu-hamyeonseodo dareun hwaldongdeuredo chamyeohaesseoyo.
examples.en: Before starting school, I studied hard while also participating in other activities.

examples.kr: 영화를 보면서 팝콘을 먹는 걸 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul bomyeonseo papkoneul meokneun geol joahaeyo.
examples.en: I like eating popcorn while watching movies.

examples.kr: 운동하면서 뉴스를 보는 편이에요. 동시에 건강 정보도 찾아봐요.
examples.romaji: Undonghamyeonseo nyuseureul boneun pyeoniyeyo. Dongsie geongang jeongbodo chajabwayo.
examples.en: I usually watch the news while exercising. At the same time, I look up health information.

title: ~면 [myeon] (If)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a conditional statement, equivalent to 'if' in English.
long_explanation: '~면 [myeon]' is a conditional form in the Korean language. It conveys the meaning of 'if', creating a condition that if a certain situation occurs, another event will follow. This grammar is often used to express hypothetical situations or intentions that depend on a condition. Note that the verb typically appears in its plain or basic form before '~면'.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 오면, 우리는 공원에 가지 않을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga omyeon, urineun gongwone gaji anheul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If it rains tomorrow, we won't go to the park.

examples.kr: 보고 싶으면 그 사람에게 전화하세요.
examples.romaji: Bogo sipeumyeon geu saramege jeonhwa haseyo.
examples.en: If you miss him, call him.

examples.kr: 많이 공부하면 시험에 붙을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Manhi gongbuhamyeon siheome but-eul su isseoyo.
examples.en: If you study a lot, you can pass the test.

examples.kr: 마지막 버스를 놓치면 택시를 타야 돼요.
examples.romaji: Majimag beoseureul nohchimyeon taegsireul taya dwaeyo.
examples.en: If we miss the last bus, we have to take a taxi.

title: ~면 어때 [myeon eottae] (How about if)
short_explanation: Used to suggest an action or situation; 'How about if'.
long_explanation: '~면 어때 [myeon eottae]' is used in Korean to propose an alternative plan or seek agreement on a course of action. It can mean 'How about if...' or 'What if...'. The speaker is asking for someone’s opinion or reaction to a hypothetical idea.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋으니까, 우리 공원에서 놀면 어때?
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joheunikka, uri gongwoneseo nolmyeon eottae?
examples.en: The weather is nice, so how about we hang out in the park?

examples.kr: 걱정이 많아 보여. 잠시 체육관에 가서 운동하면 어때?
examples.romaji: Geokjeongi manha boyeo. Jamsi cheyukgwane gaseo undonghamyeon eottae?
examples.en: You look worried. How about going to the gym and exercising for a bit?

examples.kr: 시간이 없다고요? 그럼 음식을 배달하면 어때?
examples.romaji: Sigani eopsdagoyo? Geureom eumsigeul baedalhamyeon eottae?
examples.en: You said you don't have time? Then how about ordering food delivery?

examples.kr: 이 문제를 어떻게 해결하면 어때?
examples.romaji: I munjeleul eotteoke haegyeolhamyeon eottae?
examples.en: How about we figure out how to solve this problem?

title: ~면서도 [myeonseodo] (Even though, while)
short_explanation: Expresses a contrast or contradiction between two clauses, meaning 'even though' or 'while'.
long_explanation: '~면서도 [myeonseodo]' is used when two facts or actions coexist, yet they seem contradictory or contrasting. It can also convey 'despite' or 'although' in English, highlighting the unexpected coexistence of these two states or actions.

examples.kr: 그녀는 놀랍게도 일하면서도 학교 공부를 계속하고 있어요. 그런데 항상 성적이 뛰어난 편이에요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nollapge do ilhamyeonseodo hakgyo gongbureul gyesokhago isseoyo. Geureonde hangsang seongjeogi ttwieonan pyeonieyo.
examples.en: Surprisingly, she keeps up with her schoolwork even while she’s working. Yet her grades are always outstanding.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 어렵게 만들어졌지만, 재미있으면서도 교훈적인 내용을 담고 있어요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun eoryeopge mandeureojyeotjiman, jaemiisseumyeonseodo gyohunjjeok-in naeyongeul damgo isseoyo.
examples.en: This movie was difficult to make, but it's enjoyable and also contains a moral lesson.

examples.kr: 그는 건강을 유지하면서도 매일 야근을 해요. 그런데도 항상 활기가 넘쳐요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geongangeul yujihamyeonseodo maeil yageuneul haeyo. Geureondedo hangsang hwalgiga neomchyeoyo.
examples.en: Even though he works overtime every day, he maintains his health and is always energetic.

examples.kr: 겨울이면서도 날씨가 따뜻해서, 아웃도어 활동하기에 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Gyeourimyeonseodo nalssiga ttatteushaeseo, autdoeo hwaldonghagie joayo.
examples.en: Even though it’s winter, the weather is warm, so it’s good for outdoor activities.

title: ~밖에 [bakke] (Only, nothing but)
short_explanation: Used to emphasize 'only' or 'nothing but' when accompanied by a negative verb.
long_explanation: '~밖에 [bakke]' is a Korean particle that appears together with negative verbs to stress that there is nothing else except the stated noun. The sentence structure literally means 'aside from X, there is nothing/no one else,' conveying 'only X' or 'nothing but X.'

examples.kr: 나는 커피밖에 마시지 않아. 다른 음료는 마실 필요가 없어서.
examples.romaji: Naneun keopibakke masiji ana. Dareun eumryoneun masil pilyoga eopseoseo.
examples.en: I drink nothing but coffee. I don't need other beverages.

examples.kr: 이 시험을 준비하기 위해서는 나밖에 없는 것 같아. 다른 사람들은 준비하지 않았거든.
examples.romaji: I siheomeul junbihagi wihaeseoneun na bakke eomneun geot gata. Dareun saramdeureun junbihaji anhageodeun.
examples.en: It seems like I'm the only one preparing for this exam; other people didn't prepare.

examples.kr: 그녀는 자신의 생일밖에 기억하지 못해. 다른 중요한 일자들은 잊어버렸대.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jasinui saengil bakke gieokhaji mothae. Dareun jungyohan iljadeureun ijeobeoryeotdae.
examples.en: She remembers nothing but her own birthday. She’s forgotten all other important dates.

examples.kr: 나는 피자밖에 안 먹었어. 다른 음식은 맛이 없더라고.
examples.romaji: Naneun pijabakke an meogeosseo. Dareun eumsik-eun masi eopdeorago.
examples.en: I ate nothing but pizza. The other food wasn’t tasty.

title: ~부터 [buteo] (From)
short_explanation: Indicates the starting point in time or space; 'from', 'since'.
long_explanation: '~부터 [buteo]' is a postposition marking the starting point of an action or condition in time or space. In English, it corresponds to 'from' or 'since.' It’s used with time expressions (e.g., 'from tomorrow') or location expressions (e.g., 'from Seoul').

examples.kr: 저는 아침 7시부터 일하러 가요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun achim ilgop-si buteo ilhareo gayo.
examples.en: I go to work from 7 AM.

examples.kr: 이번 주말부터 여행을 계획하려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal buteo yeohaengeul gyehoekharyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I’m planning a trip starting this weekend.

examples.kr: 서울부터 부산까지 기차로 몇 시간 걸리나요?
examples.romaji: Seoul buteo Busan kkaji gicharo myeot sigan geollinayo?
examples.en: How many hours does it take by train from Seoul to Busan?

examples.kr: 2012년부터 코리아를 사랑하게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: I-cheon sip-i nyeon buteo Korialeul saranghage dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: I’ve loved Korea since 2012.

title: ~부터 ~까지 [buteo ~ kkaji] (From ~ to)
short_explanation: Used to specify a range or period, 'from ~ to'.
long_explanation: '~부터 ~까지 [buteo ~ kkaji]' indicates a start and end point in time, location, or range. It parallels 'from ~ to' in English. For instance, 'from 1 to 10' or 'from Seoul to Busan.'

examples.kr: 나는 아침 8시부터 저녁 6시까지 일해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun achim yeodeol-si buteo jeonyeok yeoseot-si kkaji ilhaeyo.
examples.en: I work from 8 in the morning until 6 in the evening.

examples.kr: 친구 집부터 학교까지 걸어갔어요.
examples.romaji: Chingu jip buteo hakgyo kkaji georeogasseoyo.
examples.en: I walked from my friend's house to school.

examples.kr: 1부터 10까지 세어 보세요.
examples.romaji: Il buteo sip kkaji se-eo boseyo.
examples.en: Count from 1 to 10.

examples.kr: 이번 주말부터 다음 주말까지 여행을 가려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal buteo daeum jumal kkaji yeohaengeul garyeogo haeyo.
examples.en: I plan to travel from this weekend to next weekend.

title: ~사이 [sai] (Between)
short_explanation: Indicates 'between' or 'among' two or more subjects or points.
long_explanation: '~사이 [sai]' is used to mean 'between' or 'among' when referring to two or more subjects. It can describe physical distance (e.g., between cities) or relationships (e.g., between people).
formation: Noun1 + 와/과 + Noun2 + 사이 / Noun + 사이

examples.kr: 서울과 부산 사이 거리는 약 325km예요.
examples.romaji: Seoul-gwa Busan sai georineun yak sam-baek isipsam km-yeyo.
examples.en: The distance between Seoul and Busan is about 325 km.

examples.kr: 친구와 사이가 안 좋아서 요즘 연락을 안 해요.
examples.romaji: Chingu-wa sai-ga an joaseo yojeum yeollageul an haeyo.
examples.en: I haven’t been getting along well with my friend lately, so I haven’t contacted him.

examples.kr: 아침과 점심 사이에 간식을 먹는 게 중요해요.
examples.romaji: Achim-gwa jeomsim sai-e gansigeul meokneun ge junggyaohaeyo.
examples.en: Eating a snack between breakfast and lunch is important.

examples.kr: 주말 동안 부모님과의 사이가 많이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Jumal dongan bumonimgwa-ui saiga manhi joajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Over the weekend, my relationship with my parents improved a lot.

title: ~세요 [seyo] (Please do, let’s do)
short_explanation: A polite sentence-ending used to make suggestions or requests.
long_explanation: '세요 [seyo]' is an honorific verb ending in Korean used to politely ask or suggest someone do something. It can mean 'please do X' or 'let’s do X' depending on context. It often appears in daily polite speech.

examples.kr: 제발 조용히 하세요, 여기서 공부하는 사람들이 많아요.
examples.romaji: Jebal joyonghi haseyo, yeogiseo gongbuhaneun saramdeuri manhayo.
examples.en: Please be quiet; there are many people studying here.

examples.kr: 같이 점심 먹으러 가세요. 제가 맛있는 식당을 알아요.
examples.romaji: Gachi jeomsim meogeureo gaseyo. Jega masitneun sikdangeul arayo.
examples.en: Let’s go eat lunch together. I know a place that serves delicious food.

examples.kr: 지금 공부하세요. 시험이 얼마 안 남았어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum gongbuhaseyo. Siheomi eolma an namasseoyo.
examples.en: Please study now. There’s not much time left until the exam.

examples.kr: 저를 따라 오세요. 길을 잃지 않도록 안내해 드릴게요.
examples.romaji: Jeoreul ttara oseyo. Gireul ilchi antorok annaehae deurilgeyo.
examples.en: Please follow me. I’ll guide you so you don’t get lost.

title: ~아/어 보다 [a/eo boda] (Try)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the action of trying something.
long_explanation: '~아/어 보다 [a/eo boda]' is a Korean grammar pattern that is used when someone is trying to do something or trying something out for the first time. It can also be used when asking or suggesting someone to try something. In English, it is similar to 'try'. It is generally used after the verb stem.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어 공부를 해 보려고 합니다, 재미있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeo gongbureul hae boryeogo habnida, jaemiisseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: I'll try to study Korean, it seems fun.

examples.kr: 나는 이제 고기를 먹어 보려고 합니다, 그것이 어떤 맛인지 궁금해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ije gogireul meogeoboryeogo habnida, geugeosi eoddeon matinji gunggeumhaeyo.
examples.en: I will try eating meat now, I'm curious what it tastes like.

examples.kr: 저는 이 새로운 일을 해 보려고 결정했습니다, 도전하는 것이 좋다고 생각합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i saeroun ireul hae boryeogo gyeoljeonghaessseubnida, dojeonhaneun geosi jotdago saenggakhabnida.
examples.en: I decided to try this new job, I think it's good to challenge myself.

examples.kr: 오늘 첫 가이드 투어를 시도해 보았어요, 그리고 재미있는 경험이었어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul cheot gaideu tueoreul sidohae boaesseoyo, geurigo jaemiinneun gyeongheomieosseoyo.
examples.en: I tried my first guided tour today, and it was a fun experience.

title: ~아/어 버리다 [a/eo beorida] (Regrettably, completely)
short_explanation: Used to express regret or completion.
long_explanation: '~아/어 버리다 [a/eo beorida]' is a verbal construction in Korean that is used to show a sense of regret or completion of an action. It is used when the speaker feels regret about an action that has already been done or when an action has been completed leaving nothing more to do. It adds a sense of finality or regret to the verb it is attached to.

examples.kr: 저는 숙제를 너무 빨리 해버렸어요, 이제 더 이상 할게 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun sukjereul neomu ppalli ha beoryeosseoyo, ije deo isang halge eobseoyo.
examples.en: I finished my homework too early, now I have nothing more to do.

examples.kr: 어제 축구 경기에서 우리 팀이 져 버려서 회사 동료들에게 야유를 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje chukgu gyeonggieseo uri timi jyeo beoryeoseo hoesa dongnyo-deulege yayureul badasseoyo.
examples.en: Because our team lost the soccer match yesterday, I got jeered by my coworkers.

examples.kr: 친구가 나에게 농담으로 거짓말을 해버렸어요, 그래서 저는 기분이 좋지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga naege nongdameuro geojitmaleul haebeoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo jeoneun gibuni joji anhayo.
examples.en: My friend lied to me as a joke, so I feel bad.

examples.kr: 나는 아침에 일찍 출발해 버렸는데, 교통체증 때문에 길에서 많은 시간을 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun achime iljjik chulbalhae beoryeossneunde, gyotongchejeung ttaemune gireseo manheun siganeul bonaesseoyo.
examples.en: I set off early in the morning, but due to traffic congestion, I spent a lot of time on the road.

title: ~아/어 다니다 [a/eo danida] (Keep doing, repeatedly do)
short_explanation: Used to describe the continuation or repetition of an action, often in various places or on multiple occasions.
long_explanation: '~아/어 다니다' is a Korean verbal ending that expresses that someone repeatedly or habitually does an action, often moving around while doing it. It is typically used with action verbs to convey repeated or continuous activity. The choice between ~아 or ~어 depends on the final vowel of the verb stem.

examples.kr: 나는 방과 후에 친구들과 여기저기 돌아다니며 놀고 다녀요.
examples.romaji: Naneun banggwa hue chingudeulgwa yeogijeogi doradanimyeo nolgo daniroyo.
examples.en: I go around here and there with my friends after school and hang out.

examples.kr: 그녀는 휴일마다 맛집을 찾아다녀요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hyuilmada matjibeul chajadanyeoyo.
examples.en: She goes around looking for good restaurants every holiday.

examples.kr: 우리 강아지는 집 안을 뛰어다니며 장난을 쳐요.
examples.romaji: Uri gangajineun jib aneul ttwieodanimyeo jangnaneul chyeoyo.
examples.en: Our puppy runs around the house playing around.

examples.kr: 요즘에 새로운 카페들을 찾아다니면서 커피를 마시고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yojeume saeroun kape-deureul chajadanimyeonseo keopireul mashigo isseoyo.
examples.en: These days, I'm going around finding new cafes and drinking coffee.

title: ~아/어 두다 [a/eo duda] (Leave something in a state)
short_explanation: This grammar is used to express an intentional action to leave something or someone in a certain state or condition.
long_explanation: The '~아/어 두다 [a/eo duda]' form is used in Korean grammar to indicate the deliberate act of leaving something or someone in a certain state or condition. In English, this is often translated as 'to leave something in a state'. It is constructed by attaching 아/어 to the stem of an action verb followed by 두다. The form of 아/어 will depend on the final vowel of the verb stem.

examples.kr: 나는 창문을 열어 두었어, 그래서 공기가 좋아질 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Naneun changmuneul yeoreo dueosseo, geuraeseo gongiga joajil geot gata.
examples.en: I left the window open, so I think the air will get better.

examples.kr: 그는 책을 탁자 위에 놓아 두었어, 나중에 다시 읽을 준비가 되었어.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chaekeul takja wie noha dueosseo, najunge dasi ilgeul junbiga doeosseo.
examples.en: He left the book on the table, ready to read again later.

examples.kr: 나는 전화를 끊어 두었어, 대화가 너무 어려웠어.
examples.romaji: Naneun jeonhwaleul kkeunheo dueosseo, daehwaga neomu eoryeowosseo.
examples.en: I left the phone call disconnected, the conversation was too difficult.

examples.kr: 타오르는 난로 옆에 차를 따뜻하게 두었어.
examples.romaji: Taoreuneun nanlo yeope chareul ttatteuthage dueosseo.
examples.en: I left the tea warm by the burning heater.

title: ~아/어 놓다 [a/eo nohda] (Do in advance, set something up)
short_explanation: Used to convey the concept of doing something in preparation for something or setting something up.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~아/어 놓다 [a/eo nohda]' is often used in Korean to express the idea of doing something in advance or preparing for something. It implies that an action has been performed and the result of the action remains. It's also used to express the intention of setting something up or putting things in a certain state.

examples.kr: 내일 아침을 위해서 오늘 저녁에 밥을 미리 지어 놓았어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil achimeul wihayeo oneul jeonyeoge babeul miri jieo nohasseoyo.
examples.en: I cooked rice in advance tonight for tomorrow morning.

examples.kr: 미팅 시작하기 전에 프레젠테이션을 먼저 준비해 놓아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Miting sijakhagi jeone peurejenteisyeoneul meonjeo junbihae nohayahaeyo.
examples.en: We have to prepare the presentation first before starting the meeting.

examples.kr: 우리는 여행 가기 전에 짐을 미리 싸 놓았어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun yeohaeng gagi jeone jimeul miri ssa nohasseoyo.
examples.en: We packed our luggage in advance before going on a trip.

examples.kr: 동생이 오기 전에 방을 청소해 놓았어요.
examples.romaji: Dongsaengi ogi jeone bangeul cheongsohae nohasseoyo.
examples.en: I cleaned up the room before my younger sibling came.

title: ~아/어야 되다/하다 [a/eoya dweda/hada] (Have to, must)
short_explanation: This pattern is used to describe an obligation or necessity, equivalent to 'have to' or 'must' in English.
long_explanation: '~아/어야 되다/하다 [a/eoya dweda/hada]' is used in Korean to express a sense of obligation or requirement, often in cases where the speaker must perform a certain action. It is akin to 'must' or 'have to' in English, giving the subject of the sentence a required action to carry out. This can be used in a variety of contexts, ranging from obligations in daily life, job requirements, giving or receiving advice, rules, and more.
formation: Verb stem + 아/어야 하다 or Verb stem + 아/어야 되다.

examples.kr: 저는 8시에 학교에 가야 해요, 지각하면 큰 문제가 될 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun 8si-e hakgyo-e gayahaeyo, jigakhmyeon keun munje-ga doel geoyeyo.
examples.en: I have to go to school at 8, it will be a big problem if I am late.

examples.kr: 문제를 해결하려면, 처음부터 다시 시작해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Munjeleul haegyeolharyeomyeon, cheoeumbuteo dasi sijakhaeya habnida.
examples.en: To solve the problem, we have to start over from the beginning.

examples.kr: 제가 늦지 않으려면 버스를 타야 해요.
examples.romaji: Je-ga neutji an-euryeomyeon, beoseuleul tayahaeyo.
examples.en: I have to take the bus in order not to be late.

examples.kr: 기분이 좋아지려면 운동을 해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Gibuni joajiryeomyeon undongeul haya habnida.
examples.en: I have to exercise in order to feel better.

title: ~아/어지다 [a/eojida] (Become, get)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a change of state or condition; 'become', 'get'.
long_explanation: '~아/어지다 [a/eojida]' is a verb ending used in Korean to indicate a change in state or condition. The change implied by ~아/어지다 can be physical, mental, or situational, signaling that something or someone has transitioned from one state or condition to another. The context determines whether a sentence with ~아/어지다 refers to a change within oneself or something external.

examples.kr: 그녀는 이름을 들을 때마다 기분이 좋아졌어요, 그 이름은 그녀에게 행복한 추억을 상기시켜줬어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun ireumeul deureul ttaemada gibuni joahjyeosseoyo, geu ireumeun geunyeoege haengbokhan chueogeul sanggishyeojwosseoyo.
examples.en: She became happy every time she heard the name, as it reminded her of happy memories.

examples.kr: 저는 마음이 안정되면서 점점 훨씬 더 행복해지기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeumi anjeongdoemyeonseo jeomjeom hwolssin deo haengbokhaejigi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: As my mind settled, I started to get a lot happier.

examples.kr: 모든 사람들이 자신이 원하는 것을 얻으면서 부자가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Modeun saramdeuli jasini wonhaneun geoseul eodeumyeonseo bujaga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: Everyone became rich as they got what they wanted.

examples.kr: 그녀는 시간이 지나면서 매우 성숙해졌어요, 그녀의 경험은 그녀를 더욱 강하게 만들었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun sigani jinamyeonseo maeu seongsukhaejyeosseoyo, geunyeoui gyeongheomeun geunyeoreul deouk ganghage mandeureosseoyo.
examples.en: She became very mature over time; her experiences made her stronger.

title: ~아서/어서 [aseo/eoseo] (So, because, and)
short_explanation: Used to express reason, cause or condition; 'So', 'because' or 'and'.
long_explanation: '~아서/어서 [aseo/eoseo]' is a connective ending in Korean that indicates reason, cause or condition. It can be compared to 'so', 'because', or 'and' in English. ~아서 is used after vowels in verbs ending or else ~어서 is used.

examples.kr: 나는 배가 아파서 학교에 가지 못했습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun baega apaseo hakgyoe gaji moshaessseubnida.
examples.en: I couldn't go to school because my stomach hurt.

examples.kr: 결혼식이 있어서 그를 만나러 서울로 갔습니다.
examples.romaji: Gyeolhonsigi isseoseo geureul mannareo seoullo gassseubnida.
examples.en: I went to Seoul to meet him because there was a wedding.

examples.kr: 하늘이 맑아서 별들이 아주 잘 보였습니다.
examples.romaji: Haneuli malgaseo byeoldeuli aju jal boyeossseubnida.
examples.en: The sky was clear so the stars were seen very well.

examples.kr: 그녀가 웃어서 나도 기분이 좋아졌습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga useoseo nado gibuni johajyeossseubnida.
examples.en: She smiled, and so I felt better.

title: ~았/었다가 [at/eotdagga] (Did something and then another situation occurred)
short_explanation: Used to express that after a completed action or event in the past, a different situation/event followed.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~았/었다가 [at/eotdagga]' is used to show that one action was completed in the past and then a new or contrasting action or situation occurred. It connects the two events, often implying a change or unexpected outcome.

examples.kr: 저는 따뜻한 커피를 마셨다가 갑자기 배가 아파서 병원에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ttatteuthan keopireul masyeotdagga gapjagi baega apaseo byeongwone gasseoyo.
examples.en: I drank warm coffee, and then suddenly my stomach hurt, so I went to the hospital.

examples.kr: 그는 축구를 했다가 넘어져서 다쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chukgureul haetdagga neomeojyeoseo dachyeosseoyo.
examples.en: He played soccer and then fell down and got injured.

examples.kr: 영화를 봤다가 잠이 들어 버렸어요. 그래서 결말을 모릅니다.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul bwatdagga jami deureo beoryeosseoyo. Geuraeseo gyeolmareul moreumnida.
examples.en: I was watching a movie and then I fell asleep. So, I don't know how it ends.

examples.kr: 내가 공부를 했다가 친구가 도서관에 놀러 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Naega gongbureul haetdagga chinguga doseogwane nolleo wasseoyo.
examples.en: I was studying, and then my friend came to the library to hang out.

title: ~았/었던 [at/eotdeon] (That used to be)
short_explanation: Used to express past states or conditions; 'that used to be'.
long_explanation: '~았/었던 [at/eotdeon]' is a grammar point used in Korean to express past states or conditions, equivalent to 'that used to be' in English. It can be used to describe a person, place, thing, or situation in the past. The past tense verb is combined with '던' to express a state or condition that was continuous in the past.

examples.kr: 언제나 가득 차 있었던 이 곳은 지금은 완전히 비어 있어요.
examples.romaji: Eonjena gadeuk cha isseotdeon i goseun jigeumeun wanjeonhi biyeo isseoyo.
examples.en: This place that used to always be full is now completely empty.

examples.kr: 우리가 자주 놀았던 그 공원은 이제 없어요.
examples.romaji: Uriga jaju nolatdeon geu gongwaneun ije eopseoyo.
examples.en: The park where we used to play often is not there anymore.

examples.kr: 너가 찾던 그 책은 지금은 다 팔렸어요.
examples.romaji: Neoga chatdeon geu chaegeun jigeumeun da pallyeosseoyo.
examples.en: The book that you were looking for has been all sold out now.

examples.kr: 옛날에 살았던 집은 지금은 다른 사람이 살고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yetnare salatdeon jibeun jigeumeun dareun sarami salgo isseoyo.
examples.en: The house where I used to live is now occupied by someone else.

title: ~았/었으면 좋겠다 [at/eosseumyeon johgetda] (I hope, wish)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express a desire or a wish for a particular situation to happen.
long_explanation: '~았/었으면 좋겠다 [at/eosseumyeon johgetda]' is a Korean grammar point used to express the speaker's hope or wish for a situation that has not yet occurred, similar to 'I hope' or 'I wish' in English. It is also used to express regret for a past event that did not go as desired. In formation, it uses the past tense of a verb followed by '으면 좋겠다' to indicate the speaker's hope or wish.

examples.kr: 내일 날씨가 좋았으면 좋겠다. 바다에 가서 놀고 싶은데 매번 비가 와서 가지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil nalssiga johasseumyeon johgetda. Badae gaseo nolgo sipeunde maebeon biga waseo gaji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: I hope the weather is good tomorrow. I want to go to the beach, but every time it rains, I couldn’t go.

examples.kr: 맛있는 음식을 잘 만들었으면 좋겠다. 친구들에게 좋은 음식을 만들어주고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Mas-issneun eumsigeul jal mandeureosseumyeon johgetda. Chingudeurege joeun eumsigeul mandeureojugo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I wish I could cook delicious food well. I want to cook good food for my friends.

examples.kr: 토픽 시험에서 좋은 점수를 받았으면 좋겠다. 공부를 많이 했으니까.
examples.romaji: Topik siheomeseo joeun jeomsureul badasseumyeon johgetda. Gongbureul mani haessnikka.
examples.en: I hope I got a good score on the TOPIK exam. I studied a lot.

examples.kr: 지난 주말에 더 많이 쉬었으면 좋겠다. 지금은 너무 피곤해요.
examples.romaji: Jinan jumare deo manhi swieosseumyeon johgetda. Jigeumeun neomu pigonhaeyo.
examples.en: I wish I had rested more last weekend. I'm so tired now.

title: ~았/었지만 [at/eotjiman] (But, however, even though)
short_explanation: Used to express a contrast or conflict with something; 'but', 'however', 'even though'.
long_explanation: '~았/었지만 [at/eotjiman]' is a conjunction used in Korean to show a contrast between the action or state provided in the first clause and the latter clause. This is similar to expressions such as 'but', 'however', or 'even though' in English. Usually, the condition or situation described in the first clause contrasts with or does not lead to the expected outcome mentioned in the latter clause.

examples.kr: 저는 공부를 많이 했지만 시험에서 떨어졌어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbureul mani haetjiman siheomeseo tteoreojyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I studied a lot, but I failed the test.

examples.kr: 친구가 나에게 초대장을 주었지만 파티에 가지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga naege chodaechangeul jueotjiman patie gaji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: My friend gave me an invitation, but I couldn't go to the party.

examples.kr: 날씨가 매우 좋았지만 나는 집에서 잠만 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga maeu johatjiman naneun jibeseo jamman jasseoyo.
examples.en: The weather was very nice, but I just slept at home.

examples.kr: 아무리 알려 주었지만, 그는 그것을 이해하지 못했습니다.
examples.romaji: Amuri allyeo jueotjiman, geuneun geugeoseul ihaehaji moshaetsseumnida.
examples.en: No matter how much I explained, he couldn't understand it.

title: ~았/었지요 [at/eotjiyo] (Explanatory, as you know)
short_explanation: Used to explain or remind something that the speaker and listener both know; 'weren't they', 'didn't you', 'haven't we' etc.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~았/었지요 [at/eotjiyo]' is used in sentences to explain or remind something that the speaker and the listener both know or have experienced before. It is similar to 'weren't they', 'didn't you', 'haven't we' in English and is often used to induce an agreement response from the listener. It is commonly used when the speaker assumes that the listener is aware of what is being said.

examples.kr: 우리는 그 영화를 본 적이 있었지요, 그것은 정말 재미있었지요.
examples.romaji: Urineun geu yeonghwareul bon jeogi isseotjiyo, geugeoseun jeongmal jaemiisseotjiyo.
examples.en: We have seen that movie before, it was really fun, wasn't it?

examples.kr: 당신은 저를 도와줬지요, 그래서 저는 정말 감사했어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsineun jeoreul dowajwatjiyo, geuraeseo jeoneun jeongmal gamsahaesseoyo.
examples.en: You helped me, didn't you? That's why I was really grateful.

examples.kr: 우리는 그 일에 대해 많이 얘기했었지요, 이제는 그것을 결정할 필요가 있어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun geu ire daehae mani yaegihaesseotjiyo, ijeneun geugeoseul gyeoljeonghal piryoga isseoyo.
examples.en: We talked a lot about that matter, didn't we? Now we need to make a decision about it.

examples.kr: 미래에 관한 우리의 계획은 주제였지요, 그것은 아직도 중요한 문제입니다.
examples.romaji: Miraee gwanhan uriui gyehoegeun jujeyeotjiyo, geugeoseun ajikdo jungyohan munjeimnida.
examples.en: Our plan for the future was the topic, wasn't it? It is still an important issue.

title: ~어야지 [eoyaji] (Intention, resolution)
short_explanation: Used to express a speaker's intention or resolution, equivalent to 'I should' or 'I must' in English.
long_explanation: '~어야지 [eoyaji]' is a Korean structure used to indicate the speaker’s resolve or intention. It implies a determination or necessity to perform an action in the future, akin to 'I should' or 'I must' in English. It is commonly used in sentences where the speaker is planning or making a firm decision to do something.

examples.kr: 저는 내일이 시험이니까 오늘은 공부해야지, 그래야 내일 시험을 잘 볼 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun naeiri siheom-inikka oneureun gongbuhaeyaji, geuraeya naeil siheomeul jal bol su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Since I have a test tomorrow, I must study today so that I can do well on the test tomorrow.

examples.kr: 다이어트를 해야지, 내 몸은 건강을 위해 좋은 음식을 먹어야 해요.
examples.romaji: Daieteureul haeyaji, nae momeun geongangeul wihae joheun eumsigeul meogeoya haeyo.
examples.en: I should go on a diet; my body needs to eat good food for health.

examples.kr: 집안일을 해야지, 나는 내 방을 청소하려고 계획하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jibanireul haeyaji, naneun nae bangeul cheongsoharyeogo gyehoekhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I should do the housework. I'm planning to clean my room.

examples.kr: 저는 다음 주에 시험이 있으니까 소설보다는 공부하는 시간을 확보해야지.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun da-eum jue siheomi iss-eunikka soseol bodaneun gongbuhaneun siganeul hwagbohaeyaji.
examples.en: Since I have an exam next week, I should make time to study rather than reading novels.

title: ~었더라면 [eotdeoramyeon] (If it had been the case that)
short_explanation: Used to express 'If it had been the case that'.
long_explanation: '~었더라면 [eotdeoramyeon]' is a grammar structure used to describe an assumption or supposition about a past event or situation. It expresses a counterfactual condition—something that did not actually happen but is imagined for the purpose of speculation or explanation. It can be translated as 'if it had been the case that' or 'if...had...'.

examples.kr: 만약 날씨가 좋았더라면, 우리는 바다에 갔을 테니까 출판사에서 일할 필요가 없었을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Manyak nalssiga johatdeoramyeon, urineun badae gasseul tenikka chulpansae-seo ilhal piryoga eobseosseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If the weather had been good, we would have gone to the sea, so we wouldn't have needed to work at the publishing company.

examples.kr: 그들이 안 왔더라면, 우리를 도와줄 사람은 없었을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geudeuri an watdeoramyeon, urireul dowajul sarameun eobseosseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If they hadn't come, there would have been nobody to help us.

examples.kr: 그것을 알았더라면, 나는 다른 일을 했을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geugeoseul alatdeoramyeon, naneun dareun ireul haesseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If I had known that, I would have done something else.

examples.kr: 그가 웨이터 일을 해봤더라면, 그는 요리하는 것에 대한 더 깊은 이해를 가졌을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geuga weiteo ireul haebwatdeoramyeon, geuneun yorihaneun geose daehamyeonseo deo gipeun ihaereul gajyeosseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If he had tried working as a waiter, he would have had a deeper understanding of cooking.

title: ~에 [e] (At, on, in, to)
short_explanation: Used to specify location, time, and destination (or direction with 가다/오다).
long_explanation: '~에 [e]' is a particle used in Korean to denote a specific location, time, or destination. It can translate to 'on', 'at', 'in', or 'to' in English, and is placed after a noun to indicate when something happens, where something is, or where someone goes. For example, '학교에 가다' means 'to go to school'.

examples.kr: 제가 학교에 공부하러 갔어요. 학교에 있을 때는 친구들과 항상 즐거운 시간을 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Jega hakgyoe gongbuhareo gasseoyo. Hakgyoe isseul ttaeneun chingudeulgwa hangsang jeulgeoun siganeul bonaesseoyo.
examples.en: I went to school to study. When I was at school, I always had a good time with my friends.

examples.kr: 크리스마스에 가족들과 함께 집에 있었어요, 그리고 친구들은 외국에 여행을 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Keuriseumaseu-e gajokdeulgwa hamkke jib-e isseosseoyo, geurigo chingudeureun oegug-e yeohaengeul gasseoyo.
examples.en: I was at home with my family on Christmas, and my friends went on a trip to a foreign country.

examples.kr: 회사에 가서 일을 하면, 저녁에 친구들과 식당에 가서 저녁을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesae gaseo ireul hamyeon, jeonyeoge chingudeulgwa sikdange gaseo jeonyeogeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I went to work at the company, and then in the evening I went to a restaurant with my friends to have dinner.

examples.kr: 곧 여름에 서울에 갈 계획이에요, 그런데 여름에 서울은 너무 더워서 좀 걱정이에요.
examples.romaji: Got yeoreum-e seoure gal gyehoeg-ieyo, geureonde yeoreum-e seoureun neomu deowoseo jom geokjeong-ieyo.
examples.en: I plan to go to Seoul in the summer, but I'm a little worried because it's so hot in Seoul during the summer.

title: ~에 따라 [e ddara] (According to, depends on)
short_explanation: Used to express 'according to' or 'depends on'.
long_explanation: '~에 따라 [e ddara]' is a grammar point in Korean used to express that something is dependent on or varies according to another factor. It shows that the result or situation can change based on a particular condition or factor.

examples.kr: 날씨에 따라 우리의 여행 계획이 변경될 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssie ddara uriui yeohaeng gyehoegi byeongyeongdoel su isseoyo.
examples.en: Our travel plans can change depending on the weather.

examples.kr: 살아있는 동물의 종류에 따라 그들의 생활 패턴이 많이 달라질 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Saraissneun dongmului jongnyue ddara geudeurui saenghwal paeteuni manhi dallajil su isseoyo.
examples.en: The lifestyle patterns of living animals can differ greatly depending on their species.

examples.kr: 사람들의 의견에 따라 당신의 결정이 달라질 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Saramdeurui uigyene ddara dangsinui gyeoljeongi dallajil su isseoyo.
examples.en: Your decision can vary depending on people's opinions.

examples.kr: 성적에 따라 대학 선택이 달라질 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Seongjeoge ddara daehak seontaegi dallajil su isseoyo.
examples.en: Your choice of university may vary depending on your grades.

title: ~에 따르다 [e ddareuda] (To be attributed to, according to)
short_explanation: Used to express cause, reason, criteria or standards; 'according to', 'in accordance with', 'dependent on'.
long_explanation: '~에 따르다 [e ddareuda]' is a compound verb commonly used in Korean to indicate that something happens or changes due to or as per some reason, rules, condition, or standard. It's like saying 'according to', 'in accordance with', or 'dependent on' in English. It's used to describe a circumstance that varies or is defined based on certain criteria or standards.

examples.kr: 날씨에 따라서 옷을 입는 스타일이 바뀌기 마련이에요, 매우 추운 날에는 멋보다 따뜻함이 우선이죠.
examples.romaji: Nalssie ttaraseo oseul ibneun seutairi bakwigi maranieyo, maeu chuun nal-eneun meotboda ttatteumhami useonijyo.
examples.en: It's natural that the style of clothing changes according to the weather. On very cold days, warmth takes precedence over style.

examples.kr: 음식의 맛은 재료에 따라 전혀 다를 수 있어요, 신선한 재료를 사용하면 맛있는 음식을 만들 수 있지요.
examples.romaji: Eumsigui maseun jaeryoe ttaraseo jeonhyeo dareul su isseoyo, sinseonhan jaeryoreul sayonghamyeon masinneun eumsigeul mandeul su issjiyo.
examples.en: The taste of food can be completely different depending on the ingredients. You can make delicious food by using fresh ingredients.

examples.kr: 교통상황에 따라서 도착 시간이 달라질 수 있어요, 교통이 막히면 늦게 도착하게 될 수 있죠.
examples.romaji: Gyotongsanghwange ttaraseo dochak sigani dallajil su isseoyo, gyotongi makimyeon neudge dochakhage doel su itjyo.
examples.en: The arrival time can change depending on the traffic conditions. If the traffic is congested, you could arrive late.

examples.kr: 실력에 따라 결과가 달라지는 거예요, 열심히 공부하면 좋은 결과를 얻을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sillyeoge ttara gyeolgwaga dallajineun geoyeyo, yeolsimhi gongbuhamyeon joheun gyeolgwareul eodeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: The result varies depending on your ability. Studying hard can yield good results.

title: ~에 비해 [e bihae] (Compared to)
short_explanation: Used to compare or contrast something in respect to another.
long_explanation: '~에 비해 [e bihae]' is a postposition in Korean used to indicate comparison or contrast between two subjects or objects, similar to 'compared to' in English. Its use emphasizes the different characteristics or states of things based on a certain standard or reference.

examples.kr: 서울에 비해 부산은 날씨가 좋아서 여름에 가기 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Seoure bihae Busaneun nalssiga joaseo yeoreume gagi joayo.
examples.en: Compared to Seoul, the weather in Busan is better, so it's good to go there in the summer.

examples.kr: 저는 채소에 비해 과일을 더 많이 먹어요, 과일이 더 달아서 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chaesoe bihae gwaireul deo manhi meogeoyo, gwairi deo dalaseo joayo.
examples.en: I eat more fruit compared to vegetables because fruit is sweeter, and I like that.

examples.kr: 지난 학기 성적에 비해 이번 학기 성적은 훨씬 향상되었어요.
examples.romaji: Jinan hakgi seongjeoge bihae ibeon hakgi seongjeogeun hwolssin hyangsangdwaesseoyo.
examples.en: Compared to last semester's grades, this semester's grades have improved a lot.

examples.kr: 커피에 비해 차는 카페인이 덜하니 밤에 마실 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Keopie bihae chaneun kapeini deolhani bame masil su isseoyo.
examples.en: Compared to coffee, tea has less caffeine, so you can drink it at night.

title: ~에게 [ege] (To someone, for someone)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the target or recipient of an action.
long_explanation: '~에게 [ege]' is a particle in Korean grammar that is used to indicate the target or recipient of an action. It is attached to the end of a noun/pronoun and translates to 'to' or 'for' in English. It's frequently used when giving, sending, or saying something to someone.

examples.kr: 저는 어제 친구에게 이 메시지를 보냈어요, 그런데 아직 답장이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eoje chinguege i mesijireul bonaesseoyo, geureonde ajik dapjangi eobseoyo.
examples.en: I sent this message to my friend yesterday, but there's no reply yet.

examples.kr: 선생님은 학생들에게 과제를 많이 주셨어요, 다 완료하기 위해선 시간이 많이 필요할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun haksaengdeurege gwajeleul mani jusyeosseoyo, da wallyo hagi wihaeseon sigani manhi pil-yohal geot gatayo.
examples.en: The teacher gave a lot of assignments to the students. I think it will take a lot of time to finish them all.

examples.kr: 어머니께서는 아기에게 이야기를 들려주고 계셔요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonigeseoneun agiege iyagireul deullyeojugo gyesyeoyo.
examples.en: The mother is telling a story to her baby.

examples.kr: 저는 동생에게 선물을 줬어요, 그는 새로운 책을 받으며 아주 행복해 보였어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun dongsaengege seonmureul jwasseoyo, geuneun saeroun chaegeul badeumyeo aju haengbokhae boyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I gave a gift to my younger sibling. He looked very happy receiving a new book.

title: ~에서 [eseo] (At, in)
short_explanation: '에서 [eseo]' is used to indicate location or origin where an action takes place.
long_explanation: '에서 [eseo]' is a particle often used in Korean to specify the place of origin or the space in which an action unfolds. It can sometimes be translated as 'at', 'in', or 'from' in English. The noun before '에서' is the reference point, and the verb that follows indicates an action taking place in or from that location.

examples.kr: 저는 서울에서 태어났어요. 서울은 제가 처음 숨을 쉬어 본 곳이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun Seoureseo taeeonasseoyo. Seoureun jega cheoeum sumeul swieo bon gos-ieyo.
examples.en: I was born in Seoul. Seoul is the first place I ever breathed.

examples.kr: 학교에서 공부하는 것이 저에게 가장 중요해요. 그래서 항상 열심히 하는 편이에요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoeseo gongbuhaneun geosi jeo-ege gajang jungyohaeyo. Geuraeseo hangsang yeolsimhi haneun pyeon-ieyo.
examples.en: Studying at school is the most important thing for me. That's why I'm always diligent.

examples.kr: 공항에서 비행기를 타고 도쿄로 갔어요. 도쿄는 저에게는 생소한 곳이지만 참 재미있었어요.
examples.romaji: Gonghangeseo bihaenggireul tago Dokyoro gasseoyo. Dokyoneun jeoege-neun saengsohan gos-ijiman cham jaemiisseosseoyo.
examples.en: I took a plane from the airport to Tokyo. Tokyo was unfamiliar to me, but it was really fun.

examples.kr: 커피숍에서 음악을 들으며 공부를 해요. 그러면 즐겁게 공부할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Keopisyopeseo eumageul deuleumyeo gongbureul haeyo. Geureomyeon jeulgeopge gongbuhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I study while listening to music in a coffee shop. That way, I can study happily.

title: ~에서부터 ~까지 [eseobuteo ~ kkaji] (From ~ to)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a duration or range from a specific start point to an end point.
long_explanation: '에서부터 [eseobuteo]' and '까지 [kkaji]' are postpositions used in Korean to indicate a duration or range from a specified start point to an end point. They can be used with both time and place. In English, this can be translated as 'from ~ to'.

examples.kr: 매일 아침 7시에서부터 8시까지 아침 운동을 하고 학교에 가요.
examples.romaji: Maeil achim 7si-eseobuteo 8si-kkaji achim undongeul hago hakgyoe gayo.
examples.en: Every morning, I do morning exercise from 7AM to 8AM and then go to school.

examples.kr: 우리는 서울에서부터 부산까지 차로 여행을 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun Seouleseobuteo Busankkaji charo yeohaengeul haesseoyo.
examples.en: We traveled by car from Seoul to Busan.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에는 토요일 저녁 5시에서부터 일요일 오후 3시까지 휴식을 취해요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal-eneun toyoil jeonyeok 5si-eseobuteo iryoil ohu 3si-kkaji hyusigeul chwihaeyo.
examples.en: This weekend, I will rest from Saturday at 5 p.m. to Sunday at 3 p.m.

examples.kr: 사진 전시회는 11월 1일에서부터 11월 30일까지 열릴 거예요.
examples.romaji: Sajin jeonsihoeneun 11wol 1il-eseobuteo 11wol 30il-kkaji yeollil geoyeyo.
examples.en: The photo exhibition will be open from November 1 to November 30.

title: ~와/과 [wa/gwa] (And, with)
short_explanation: Used to express 'and' or 'with' in a list or connection between two or more nouns.
long_explanation: '~와/과 [wa/gwa]' is a connective particle in Korean that links two or more nouns together. It is equivalent to the English conjunction 'and' or preposition 'with'. It is used when you need to link nouns in a list or show a connection between them. The choice between '와' (after a vowel) or '과' (after a consonant) depends on the final sound of the preceding noun.
formation: Noun(ending with a vowel) + 와 / Noun(ending with a consonant) + 과

examples.kr: 오늘 아침에는 밥과 김치와 갈비를 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul achimeneun bapgwa gimchiwa galbireul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: This morning I ate rice, kimchi, and ribs.

examples.kr: 나는 내 친구와 영화관에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun nae chinguwa yeonghwagwane gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to the cinema with my friend.

examples.kr: 운동화와 청바지와 티셔츠를 사러 가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Undonghwawa cheongbajiwa tisyeocheureul sareo gago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to go buy sneakers, jeans, and a T-shirt.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 나는 가족과 함께 행복한 시간을 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal-e naneun gajokgwa hamkke haengbokhan siganeul bonaesseoyo.
examples.en: I spent a happy time with my family this weekend.

title: ~와/과 같다 [wa/gwa gatda] (Be the same as, like)
short_explanation: Used to express similarities or equivalences; 'like', 'the same as'.
long_explanation: '~와/과 같다 [wa/gwa gatda]' is used in Korean to express similarity, comparison, or equivalence—acting like 'as', 'like' or 'the same as' in English. The context determines whether '와' or '과' is used, depending on whether the preceding noun ends in a vowel or a consonant.

examples.kr: 그녀의 눈은 별과 같아요, 빛나고 아름다워요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoui nuneun byeolgwa gatayo, bitnago areumdawayo.
examples.en: Her eyes are like stars; they shine and are beautiful.

examples.kr: 성장하면서 목표는 항상 북극성과 같았어요, 언제나 방향을 제시해 줬죠.
examples.romaji: Seongjanghamyeonseo mokpyoneun hangsang bukgeukseong-gwa gatasseoyo, eonjena banghyangeul jesihae jwotjyo.
examples.en: As I grew up, my goal was always like the North Star; it always gave me direction.

examples.kr: 우리 학교의 기숙사는 호텔과 같아요, 매우 편안하고 모든 시설이 잘 갖춰져 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri hakgyoui gisugsaneun hotel-gwa gatayo, maeu pyeonanago modeun siseoli jal gatchwojyeo isseoyo.
examples.en: Our school's dormitory is like a hotel—it's very comfortable and has all the necessary facilities.

examples.kr: 이 문제는 그 전의 문제와 같아요, 유사한 해결 방법을 가지고 있어요.
examples.romaji: I munjeneun geu jeonui munjewa gatayo, yusahan haegyeol bangbeomeul gajigo isseoyo.
examples.en: This problem is the same as the previous one; it has a similar solution.

title: ~와/과 달리 [wa/gwa dalli] (Unlike, different from)
short_explanation: This pattern is used to indicate contrast or difference between two things or situations.
long_explanation: '~와/과 달리' is a postposition in Korean generally used to contrast or compare two different things, situations, or ideas. It translates into English as 'unlike' or 'different from' and indicates a clear contrast between the two subjects.

examples.kr: 매일 출근하는 것과 달리, 오늘은 집에서 일했어요.
examples.romaji: Maeil chulgeunhaneun geot-gwa dalli, oneureun jibeseo ilhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Unlike going to work every day, I worked from home today.

examples.kr: 여름과 달리 겨울에는 날씨가 춥기 때문에 많은 옷을 입어야 해요.
examples.romaji: Yeoreum-gwa dalli gyeoure-neun nalssiga chubgi ttaemune maneun oseul ibeoya haeyo.
examples.en: Unlike summer, in winter you have to wear a lot of clothes because it's cold.

examples.kr: 철우씨와 달리, 진우씨는 공부를 잘해요.
examples.romaji: Cheolussi-wa dalli, Jinwussi-neun gongbureul jalhaeyo.
examples.en: Unlike Cheolwoo, Jinwoo is good at studying.

examples.kr: 서울과 달리 부산에서는 겨울이 덜 춥습니다.
examples.romaji: Seoul-gwa dalli Busanesoneun gyeouri deol chupsseumnida.
examples.en: Unlike Seoul, winters are less cold in Busan.

title: ~을/를 통해 [eul/reul tonghae] (Through, by means of)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the medium or method through which an action or result was achieved.
long_explanation: '~을/를 통해 [eul/reul tonghae]' is a postpositional phrase in Korean used to signify the means, channel, or method through which an action or outcome was reached. It corresponds to 'through' in English and often appears with expressions about communicating information, conveying feelings, or achieving results.

examples.kr: 이 책을 통해 그의 생각과 철학을 더 잘 이해할 수 있었다.
examples.romaji: I chaekeul tonghae geuui saenggakgwa cheolhageul deo jal ihaehal su isseotda.
examples.en: Through this book, I was able to understand his thoughts and philosophy better.

examples.kr: 남자는 음악을 통해 자신의 감정을 표현했다.
examples.romaji: Namjaneun eumageul tonghae jasinui gamjeongeul pyohyeonhaetda.
examples.en: He expressed his emotions through music.

examples.kr: 문화교류를 통해 우리는 다른 국가들과의 관계를 강화할 수 있다.
examples.romaji: Munhwagyoryureul tonghae urineun dareun gukadeulgwaui gwangyereul ganghwahal su itda.
examples.en: Through cultural exchange, we can strengthen our relationships with other countries.

examples.kr: 여행을 통해 나는 여러 가지 문화와 풍경을 경험했다.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengeul tonghae naneun yeoreo gaji munhwawa punggyeongeul gyeongheomhaetda.
examples.en: Through traveling, I experienced various cultures and landscapes.

title: ~이/가 되다 [i/ga dweda] (Become)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to describe a change or transition into a new state or condition.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~이/가 되다 [i/ga dweda]' is used in Korean to indicate a change or transition into a different state or condition. It can be used to describe things like becoming an adult, becoming a teacher, or even something more abstract like becoming happy or becoming cold. The subject or condition that is changing is placed before '이/가 되다'.

examples.kr: 아이들이 어른이 되는데는 시간이 많이 필요해요.
examples.romaji: Aideuri eoreuni doeneunde-neun sigani mani piryohaeyo.
examples.en: It takes a lot of time for children to become adults.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아주 유명한 가수가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun aju yumyeonghan gasuga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: She has become a very famous singer.

examples.kr: 오늘은 갑자기 추워져서 장갑이 필요하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun gabjagi chuwojyeoseo janggabi piryohage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: Today, it suddenly became cold, so I needed gloves.

examples.kr: 나는 공부를 열심히 해서 의사가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun gongbureul yeolsimhi haeseo uisaga doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: I studied hard and became a doctor.

title: ~이/가 아니다 [i/ga anida] (Is not, are not)
short_explanation: Used to negate a noun; 'is not', 'are not'.
long_explanation: The literal translation of '~이/가 아니다 [i/ga anida]' is 'is not' or 'are not'. It is used to negate a noun in a statement. You put '이 아니다' after a noun that ends with a consonant and '가 아니다' after a noun that ends with a vowel. This is roughly equivalent to English 'not', functioning to show contradiction or denial.

examples.kr: 저는 학생이 아닙니다, 저는 선생님이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun haksaengi anibnida, jeoneun seonsaengimnida.
examples.en: I am not a student, I am a teacher.

examples.kr: 고양이가 우리 분실물이 아닙니다, 우리 분실물은 강아지예요.
examples.romaji: Goyangiga uri bunsilmuri anibnida, uri bunsilmureun gangajiyeyo.
examples.en: The cat is not our lost item; our lost item is a puppy.

examples.kr: 요리 잘하는 사람은 내가 아닙니다, 저는 요리하는 능력이 전혀 없어요.
examples.romaji: Yori jalhaneun sarameun naega anibnida, jeoneun yorihaneun neungnyeogi jeonhyeo eopseoyo.
examples.en: I am not the person who cooks well; I have absolutely no cooking ability.

examples.kr: 그 사람은 우리 학교 학생이 아닙니다, 그는 다른 학교의 학생이에요.
examples.romaji: Geu sarameun uri hakgyo haksaengi anibnida, geuneun dareun hakgyoui haksaengieyo.
examples.en: That person is not a student of our school; he is a student of another school.

title: ~이라도 [irado] (Even if, at least)
short_explanation: Used to signify 'even if' or 'at least' in scenarios where something is better than nothing.
long_explanation: '~이라도 [irado]' is a postposition used in Korean to minimize the value of the subject but imply that the mentioned thing is still better than having nothing at all. It implies a somewhat unsatisfactory situation, yet shows a compromise, similar to 'even if' or 'at least' in English.

examples.kr: 비록 그것이 기대했던 것이 아니라도, 아무것도 없는 것보다는 낫죠.
examples.romaji: Birok geugeosi gidaehaetdeon geosi anirado, amugeosdo eopneun geotbodaneun natjyo.
examples.en: Even if it's not what I expected, it's better than having nothing.

examples.kr: 이 사진이라도 찍어 두면 나중에 좋은 추억이 될 거예요.
examples.romaji: I sajinirado jjigeo dumyeon najunge joeun chueogi doel geoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if it's just this photo, it will become a good memory later.

examples.kr: 노래를 잘 못해도 노래방에서 한 곡이라도 불러 보세요.
examples.romaji: Noraereul jal mothaedo noraebangeseo han gogirado bulleo boseyo.
examples.en: Even if you can't sing well, try singing at least one song at karaoke.

examples.kr: 시험에서 높은 점수를 못 받았더라도, 이해 안 가는 부분이라도 공부했다면 큰 수확이에요.
examples.romaji: Siheomeseo nopeun jeomsureul mot badasdeorado, ihae an ganeun bubunirado gongbuhatdamyeon keun suhwagieyo.
examples.en: Even if you didn’t get a high score on the test, studying at least the parts you didn’t understand is a big accomplishment.

title: ~이래 [irae] (Since then)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a period of time starting from a specific point in the past to the present time.
long_explanation: '~이래 [irae]' is used in Korean to express 'since then' or 'ever since', indicating that something has continued or remained the same from a past point in time up to the present.

examples.kr: 그 사건이 발생한 지 5년 이래로 나는 그곳을 한 번도 방문한 적이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geu sageoni balsenghan ji ony e nyon iraero naneun geu goseul han beondo bangmunhan jeogi eopseoyo.
examples.en: I haven't visited that place even once in the five years since that incident happened.

examples.kr: 백 년 이래 최초로 우리 학교 축구팀이 우승을 차지했어요.
examples.romaji: Baek nyeon irae choecho-ro uri hakgyo chukgutimi useungeul chajieosseoyo.
examples.en: For the first time in a hundred years, our school's soccer team won.

examples.kr: 나는 이렇게 열정적인 구직자를 만난 게 정말 오랜만이래.
examples.romaji: Naneun ireohge yeoljeongjeok-in gujikjareul mannan ge jeongmal oraenmanirae.
examples.en: It's really been a long time since I met such a passionate job seeker.

examples.kr: 학교에서 가장 높은 점수를 받았던 그날 이래로, 부모님이 나를 아주 자랑스러워하셨어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoeseo gajang nopeun jeomsureul badatdeon geunal iraero, bumonimi nareul aju jarangseureowohasyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Ever since the day I got the highest score at school, my parents have been very proud of me.

title: ~이랑 [irang] (And, with)
short_explanation: Used to express the relationship of 'and' or 'with' between two or more things or people.
long_explanation: '~이랑 [irang]' is a postposition in Korean that can mean 'and' or 'with' when connecting two or more nouns. It is often used for casual or friendly contexts, indicating doing something together with someone or having something along with something else.

examples.kr: 저는 친구랑 영화를 보러 갔어요. 정말 재미있었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chingurang yeonghwareul boreo gasseoyo. Jeongmal jaemiisseosseoyo.
examples.en: I went to watch a movie with my friend. It was really fun.

examples.kr: 길고 어려운 숙제를 친구랑 같이 해서 도전정신이 생겼어요.
examples.romaji: Gilgo eoryeoun sukjereul chingurang gachi haeseo dojeonjeongsini saenggyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I did my long and difficult homework with my friend, and it built my sense of challenge.

examples.kr: 가족이랑 잊지 못할 여행을 다녀왔어요. 정말 즐거웠어요.
examples.romaji: Gajogirang itji mot-hal yeohaengeul danyeowasseoyo. Jeongmal jeulgeowosseoyo.
examples.en: I went on an unforgettable trip with my family. It was really enjoyable.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침에 운동이랑 샤워를 하고 학교에 가요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achime undongirang syaworeul hago hakgyoe gayo.
examples.en: Every morning, I exercise and take a shower, then go to school.

title: ~이렇게 [ireohge] (Like this, in this way)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the manner or degree of an action; 'like this', 'in this way'.
long_explanation: '~이렇게 [ireohge]' is an adverb in Korean that describes how or to what degree an action is performed. It can translate as 'like this' or 'in this way.' It can also convey surprise or emphasis depending on context.

examples.kr: 이렇게 더운 날에는 아이스크림을 먹는 것이 최고예요.
examples.romaji: Ireohge deoun nal-eneun aiseukeurimeul meogneun geosi choegoyeyo.
examples.en: On a hot day like this, eating ice cream is the best.

examples.kr: 제가 이렇게 늦게 도착할 줄 몰랐어요.
examples.romaji: Jega ireohge neujge dochakhal jul mollasseoyo.
examples.en: I didn't know I would arrive this late.

examples.kr: 나는 이렇게 큰 문제를 해결할 수 있을 줄 몰랐어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ireohge keun munjereul haegyeolhal su isseul jul mollasseoyo.
examples.en: I didn't think I could solve such a big problem like this.

examples.kr: 저는 이렇게 몸이 커진 줄 몰랐어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ireohge momi keojin jul mollasseoyo.
examples.en: I didn't realize my body had grown like this.

title: ~이므로 [imyeo] (Therefore, because)
short_explanation: Used to express cause or reason; 'therefore', 'because'.
long_explanation: '이므로 [imyeo]' is a conjunction in Korean used to indicate cause or reason, similar to 'therefore' or 'because' in English. It is especially common in formal or written contexts to connect a reason with its result. The noun or adjective preceding it is the cause, and what follows is the outcome or conclusion.

examples.kr: 일주일 동안 매일 비가 왔으므로, 우산을 챙기는 것이 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Iljuil dongan maeil bi ga wasseumuro, usaneul chaenggineun geosi joeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Since it has been raining every day for a week, it would be good to carry an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그녀는 한식을 아주 잘 만들 수 있으므로, 동네 사람들에게서 요리로 사랑받고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hansigeul aju jal mandeul su isseumuro, dongne saramdeuregeseo yoriro sarangbadgo isseoyo.
examples.en: Because she can cook Korean food very well, she is loved for her cooking by the people in the neighborhood.

examples.kr: 날이 매우 추우므로, 스카프를 쓰는 것이 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nari maeu chuumuro, seukapeureul sseuneun geosi jokesseoyo.
examples.en: Since the weather is very cold, it would be a good idea to wear a scarf.

examples.kr: 내일은 공휴일이므로, 우체국이 문을 닫을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Naeireun gonghyuilimuro, uchegugi muneul dad-eul geosimnida.
examples.en: Since tomorrow is a public holiday, the post office will be closed.

title: ~이어서 [ieoseo] (And then, following that)
short_explanation: Used to show continuation or result of an action/event; 'and then', 'following that'.
long_explanation: '~이어서 [ieoseo]' is a connector in Korean that indicates a sequence of events or actions, meaning 'and then' or 'continuing from that.' It can derive from '이다 + -어서' in certain contexts, or it can be used to show that one action follows directly after another.

examples.kr: 나는 방을 청소했고 이어서 저녁을 준비했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun bangeul cheongsohaetgo ieoseo jeonyeogeul junbihaesseoyo.
examples.en: I cleaned the room, and then I prepared dinner.

examples.kr: 우리는 먼저 저녁을 먹었고 이어서 산책을 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun meonjeo jeonyeogeul meogeotgo ieoseo sanchaekeul haesseoyo.
examples.en: We ate dinner first and then went for a walk.

examples.kr: 그녀가 열심히 공부했고 이어서 시험에 합격했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga yeolsimhi gongbuhaetgo ieoseo siheome hapgyeokhaetseumnida.
examples.en: She studied hard, and then she passed the exam.

examples.kr: 나는 아침 일찍 일어났고 이어서 천천히 준비를 마쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun achim iljjik ileonatgo ieoseo cheoncheonhi junbireul machyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I woke up early in the morning, and then I finished getting ready at a leisurely pace.

title: ~이었다 [ieotda] (Was, were)
short_explanation: Used to describe a state or condition in the past; 'was', 'were'.
long_explanation: The '~이었다 [ieotda]' form is the past tense of '이다' (to be). It describes a previous condition, quality, role, or identity of a noun—translated as 'was' or 'were' in English. It is not used for describing past actions (which require the normal past tense of action verbs).

examples.kr: 그는 어릴 때 정말 착하고 예의 바른 아이였다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun eoril ttae jeongmal chakhago yeui bareun aieotda.
examples.en: When he was young, he was a very kind and polite child.

examples.kr: 진안에서 보았던 그 늙은 나무가 정원의 가장 아름다운 풍경이었다.
examples.romaji: Jinan-eseo boatdeon geu neulgeun namuga jeongwone gajang areumdaun punggyeongieotda.
examples.en: That old tree I saw in Jinan was the most beautiful scenery in the garden.

examples.kr: 그녀는 우리 학교에서 영어 선생님이었다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun uri hakgyoeseo yeongeo seonsaengnimieotda.
examples.en: She was an English teacher at our school.

examples.kr: 그렇게 해서 그 해의 여름은 잊지 못할 최고의 시간이었다.
examples.romaji: Geureohge haeseo geu haeui yeoreumeun itji mothal choegoui siganieotda.
examples.en: Thus, that summer of that year was an unforgettable, wonderful time.

title: ~이지만 [ijiman] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: The particle '~이지만 [ijiman]' is used to show a contrast or contradiction between two statements. It is analogous to 'but' or 'however' in English. It typically appears after a copula or descriptive verb stem. The first part of the sentence states one situation or fact, followed by a second part that indicates a contrasting or opposing circumstance.

examples.kr: 너무 아프지만 병원에 가서 약을 사 왔어요. 집에서 쉴 예정이에요.
examples.romaji: Neomu apeujiman byeongwone gaseo yageul sa wasseoyo. Jibeseo swil yejeong-ieyo.
examples.en: I was in a lot of pain, but I went to the hospital and bought medicine. I plan to rest at home.

examples.kr: 오늘 바람이 많이 불지만 날씨가 좋아서 화장실 창문을 열어놓았어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul barami mani buljiman nalssiga joaseo hwajangsil changmuneul yeoreonohasseoyo.
examples.en: The wind is blowing a lot today, but the weather is nice, so I left the bathroom window open.

examples.kr: 숙제를 다 하지는 못했지만 일단 제출했어요. 내일 마저 할 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Sukjereul da hajineun moshaessjiman ildan jechulhaesseoyo. Naeil majeo hal geos-imnida.
examples.en: I didn't finish all the homework, but I submitted it anyway. I will finish the rest tomorrow.

examples.kr: 저는 지금 정말 배고파요. 저녁을 먹었지만 아직도 배고프네요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jigeum jeongmal baegopayo. Jeonyeogeul meogeossjiman ajikdo baegopneyo.
examples.en: I'm really hungry right now. I ate dinner, but I'm still hungry.

title: ~인데 [inde] (But, and, so)
short_explanation: Used to connect sentences with meanings like 'but', 'and', or 'so'.
long_explanation: The pattern '~인데 [inde]' (for nouns) or '~는데 [neunde]' (for verbs/adjectives) is one of the most commonly used connectors in Korean. Although there is no exact single English equivalent, it can be translated as 'but', 'and', or 'so' depending on context. Often, the first clause states a situation or background, and the second clause shows the result, contrast, or additional info.

examples.kr: 저는 알바를 해야 하는데 시간이 없어요, 그래서 시간을 효율적으로 쓰는 방법을 찾아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun albaleul haeya haneunde sigani eopseoyo, geuraeseo siganeul hyoyuljeogeuro sseuneun bangbeobeul chajaya haeyo.
examples.en: I have to work part-time, but I don't have time, so I need to find a more efficient way to use my time.

examples.kr: 나는 코딩을 좋아하는데, 이해하기 어려워서 자주 헷갈려요.
examples.romaji: Naneun koding-eul joahaneunde, ihaehagi eoryeowoseo jaju het-gal-lyeoyo.
examples.en: I like coding, but it's hard to understand, so I get confused often.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋은데 외출 계획이 없어서 집에서 영화를 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joheunde oechul gyehoegi eopseoseo jibeseo yeonghwareul bwasseoyo.
examples.en: The weather is nice, but I had no plans to go out, so I watched a movie at home.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있는데 아직 공부를 안 해서 밤새 공부해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi inneunde ajik gongbureul an haeseo bamsae gongbuhaeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: I have an exam tomorrow, but I haven't studied yet, so I'll have to study all night.

title: ~인데다 [indeda] (Moreover, besides)
short_explanation: Used to add more information or another reason; 'moreover', 'besides'.
long_explanation: '~인데다 [indeda]' is used in Korean to give an additional supporting reason or trait. It can mean 'furthermore', 'in addition', or 'besides'. It typically attaches to descriptive verbs or copulas to emphasize an extra point on top of what was previously stated.
formation: Descriptive Verb + (으)ㄴ/는 데다 or Noun + 인데다

examples.kr: 그녀는 아름다울 뿐만 아니라 똑똑한데다 마음씨도 정말 착해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun areumdaul ppunman anira ttokttokhandeda maeumssido jeongmal chakaeyo.
examples.en: She's not only beautiful but also smart, and on top of that, she has a really kind heart.

examples.kr: 이 핸드폰은 기능이 다양한데다 가격도 저렴해서 많은 사람들이 찾게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: I haendeuponeun gineungi dayanghandeda gagyeokdo jeoryeomhaseo manheun saramdeuri chatge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: This phone has a variety of features, and besides that, it's inexpensive, so many people have been seeking it.

examples.kr: 이 식당은 맛이 좋은데다 위치도 좋아서 사람들이 많이 찾아옵니다.
examples.romaji: I sikdangeun masi joheundeda wichi-do joaseo saramdeuri manhi chajaomnida.
examples.en: This restaurant not only has great taste but also a good location, so a lot of people visit.

examples.kr: 그는 훌륭한 가수이지만 음악을 작곡하는 능력이 있는데다 리더십도 뛰어나요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hullyunghan gasuijiman eumageul jakgokhaneun neungnyeogi indeda rideosipdo ttwieonayo.
examples.en: He is an excellent singer, and he can compose music in addition to having great leadership.

title: ~인지 [inji] (Whether)
short_explanation: Used to express doubt, uncertainty, or an indirect question; 'whether', 'if'.
long_explanation: '~인지 [inji]' is a conjunction used in Korean to introduce a subordinate clause expressing doubt, uncertainty, or an indirect question. It corresponds to 'whether' or 'if' in English. It is used after verbs or adjectives and can also indicate not knowing or being unsure about something.

examples.kr: 그가 올 것인지 아닌지 잘 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga ol geos-inji an-inji jal moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure whether he will come or not.

examples.kr: 그 차를 사야 할 것인지 고민이에요.
examples.romaji: Geu chareul saya hal geos-inji gominieyo.
examples.en: I'm wondering whether I should buy that car.

examples.kr: 어떤 옷을 입을지 결정하기가 어렵습니다.
examples.romaji: Eotteon oseul ibeulji gyeoljeonghagiga eoryeopseumnida.
examples.en: It's hard to decide what clothes to wear.

examples.kr: 그가 진심인지 아닌지 판단하기 어렵습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga jinsiminji an-inji pandanhagi eoryeopseumnida.
examples.en: It's hard to judge whether he is sincere or not.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 때 [eul ttae] (When, while)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a specific time or situation for an action; 'when', 'while'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 때 [eul ttae]' is a common Korean grammar structure meaning 'when' or 'while'. It attaches to the verb stem or adjective stem to show that an action/event takes place under those circumstances or at that time.

examples.kr: 누나가 집에 올 때 항상 반겨주는 것이 여동생의 일이에요.
examples.romaji: Nunaga jib-e ol ttae hangsang bangyeojuneun geosi yeodongsaeng-ui irieyo.
examples.en: Welcoming her older sister whenever she comes home is the younger sister’s job.

examples.kr: 출근할 때 항상 커피를 마시는 습관이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Chulgeunhal ttae hangsang keopireul masineun seubgwani isseoyo.
examples.en: I have a habit of always drinking coffee when I go to work.

examples.kr: 공부를 할 때 음악을 듣는 것이 집중하는 데 도움이 돼요.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul hal ttae eumageul deunneun geosi jibjunghaneunde doumi dwaeyo.
examples.en: Listening to music when studying helps me concentrate.

examples.kr: 비가 올 때 행복한 노래를 듣는 것은 좋은 아이디어입니다.
examples.romaji: Biga ol ttae haengbokhan noraereul deunneun geoseun jo-eun aidieoimnida.
examples.en: Listening to a happy song when it rains is a good idea.

title: ~자 [ja] (Let's)
short_explanation: '~자 [ja]' is a casual Korean grammar form used to propose an action together, similar to 'let's' in English.
long_explanation: '~자 [ja]' is an informal suggestion form in Korean, attached to the stem of action verbs. It encourages both speaker and listener to do something together. Because it's casual, it's usually used among friends or peers of similar age/status.

examples.kr: 밖에 나가서 놀이터에서 놀자. 오늘 날씨가 너무 좋으니까 집에만 있기 아깝잖아.
examples.romaji: Bakke nagaseo noliteoeseo nolja. Oneul nalssiga neomu jo-eunikka jibeman itgi akkapjanha.
examples.en: Let's go out and play at the playground. The weather's so nice; it'd be a waste to stay inside.

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 같이 식사하자. 제가 내일 준비하는 것 좀 도와줄게요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeoge gachi siksahaja. Jega naeil junbihaneun geot jom dowajulgeyo.
examples.en: Let's have dinner together tonight. I can help you prepare for tomorrow.

examples.kr: 게임하러 가자. 집에만 있으면 스트레스가 쌓이니까 잠깐이라도 바람 쐬자.
examples.romaji: Geimhareo gaja. Jibeman isseumyeon seuteureseuga ssainikka jamkan-irado baram ssoeja.
examples.en: Let's go play a game. Staying home just builds stress, so let's go get some fresh air, even briefly.

examples.kr: 서점에 가서 책을 골라보자. 인터넷으로 찾는 것보다 직접 보는 게 재밌잖아.
examples.romaji: Seojeome gaseo chaekeul gollaboja. Inteones-euro chatneun geotboda jikjeop boneun ge jaemijtjana.
examples.en: Let's go to the bookstore and pick out some books. It's more fun than searching online.

title: ~자마자 [jamaja] (As soon as)
short_explanation: '~자마자 [jamaja]' expresses that one action occurs immediately after another action finishes.
long_explanation: The structure '~자마자 [jamaja]' means 'as soon as' in Korean. It indicates that the second action happens right after the first action is completed, showing no real time gap in between. Attach it directly to the verb stem of the first action.

examples.kr: 학교에서 집에 도착하자마자 숙제를 했어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoeseo jibe dochakha-jamaja sukjereul haesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I got home from school, I did my homework.

examples.kr: 맛있는 저녁을 먹으면서 텔레비전을 보자마자 기분이 훨씬 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Masinneun jeonyeogeul meogeumyeonseo tellebijeoneul bojamaja gibuni hwolssin joajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I started watching TV while having a delicious dinner, I felt much better.

examples.kr: 비행기가 착륙하자마자 가족에게 전화를 했어요.
examples.romaji: Bihaenggiga chakryukha-jamaja gajog-ege jeonhwareul haesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as the plane landed, I called my family.

examples.kr: 출근하자마자 커피를 마셨어요.
examples.romaji: Chulgeunha-jamaja keopireul masyeosseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I arrived at work, I drank coffee.

title: ~장 [jang] (Counting unit for flat items)
short_explanation: '~장 [jang]' is a Korean counter used to count flat objects like paper, tickets, photos, etc.
long_explanation: '~장 [jang]' is a measure word (counter) in Korean for flat objects. It parallels words like 'sheet' or 'piece' in English when referring to items such as paper, tickets, documents, photographs, and so on.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 여행을 위해 표 3장을 사야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon yeohaengeul wihae pyo sam-jangeul saya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I think I need to buy 3 tickets for this trip.

examples.kr: 나는 학생들에게 공책 10장을 나눠주었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun haksaengdeurege gongchaek yeol-jangeul nanwojueosseoyo.
examples.en: I handed out ten notebooks to the students.

examples.kr: 우리는 사진 100장으로 앨범을 만들기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun sajin baek-jangeuro aelbeomeul mandeulgiro haesseoyo.
examples.en: We decided to make an album with 100 photos.

examples.kr: 마지막으로 카드 한 장을 뽑아 주세요.
examples.romaji: Majimageuro kadeu han jangeul bbob-a juseyo.
examples.en: Please draw one last card.

title: ~저 [jeo] (That kind of)
short_explanation: Used to describe 'that kind of' or 'such' qualities or characteristics.
long_explanation: '~저 [jeo]' refers to an element of 'such' or 'that kind of' in Korean, often seen in words like '저렇다' (to be like that), '그렇다' (to be so), '이렇다' (to be like this). It can emphasize a certain abstract quality or scenario for comparison, emphasis, or expressing a particular state/behavior.

examples.kr: 그런 저런 이유로 그는 행복해 보이지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geureon jeoreon iyuro geuneun haengbokhae boiji anasseoyo.
examples.en: For this and that reason, he didn't seem happy.

examples.kr: 저런 차를 보면 부러워요. 나도 저런 차를 갖고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoreon chareul bomyeon bureowoyo. Nado jeoreon chareul gatgo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: When I see a car like that, I feel envious. I want one like that, too.

examples.kr: 그녀가 저런 말을 할 줄은 몰랐어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga jeoreon mareul hal jureun mollasseoyo.
examples.en: I didn't know she would say something like that.

examples.kr: 제가 저런 일을 할 수 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Jega jeoreon ireul hal su isseulkkayo?
examples.en: Can I do something like that?

title: ~전 [jeon] (Before)
short_explanation: Used to express an action that happened before something else.
long_explanation: '전 [jeon]' is a postposition in Korean used to indicate an action or event that occurs prior to another action/event. It is similar to 'before' in English and is often used with time expressions or other chronological references.

examples.kr: 나는 학교에 가기 전에 아침 식사를 항상 먹습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun hakgyoe gagi jeone achim siksareul hangsang meokseumnida.
examples.en: I always eat breakfast before going to school.

examples.kr: 회의 시작하기 전에 자료를 모두 준비해 두었어요.
examples.romaji: Hoeui sijak-hagi jeone jaryoreul modu junbihae du-eosseoyo.
examples.en: I prepared all the materials before the meeting started.

examples.kr: 공부하고 싶은데, 시험이 끝나기 전에는 시간이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhago sipeunde, siheomi kkeutnagi jeoneneun sigani eobseoyo.
examples.en: I want to study, but I have no time before the exam ends.

examples.kr: 집에 가기 전에 슈퍼마켓에서 장을 봐야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jibe gagi jeone syupeomakeseo jangeul bwaya haeyo.
examples.en: I have to go shopping at the supermarket before going home.

title: ~적 [jeok] (Time, instance)
short_explanation: Used to denote a specific instance or time when something happened.
long_explanation: '~적 [jeok]' refers to a certain time or instance associated with the verb it follows, somewhat akin to 'when I was...' or 'the time that...' in English. You often see it combined with '에' (e.g., '어릴 적에') to mean 'when one was young', etc.

examples.kr: 저는 어릴 적에 고양이 애완동물을 갖고 싶었지만 부모님이 허락하지 않으셨어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eoril jege goyangi aewandongmureul gatgo sipeotjiman bumonimi heorakhaji aneusyeosseoyo.
examples.en: When I was a child, I wanted to have a pet cat, but my parents wouldn't allow it.

examples.kr: 처음 한국어를 배울 적에는 말하기가 매우 어려웠습니다.
examples.romaji: Cheoeum hangugeoreul baeul jegeneun malhagiga maeu eoryeowotseumnida.
examples.en: When I first started learning Korean, speaking was very difficult.

examples.kr: 그녀가 웃을 적에 나는 항상 행복해지는 기분이 들어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga useul jege naneun hangsang haengbokhaejineun gibuni deureoyo.
examples.en: Whenever she smiles, I always feel happy.

examples.kr: 고등학교 때 졸업식에 참석했을 적에, 우리 모두 마지막인 줄 알아서 흐느끼며 울었습니다.
examples.romaji: Godeunghakgyo ttae joreopsige chamseokhaesseul jege, uri modu majimagin jul araseo heuneukkimyeo ureosseumnida.
examples.en: At our high school graduation, we all sobbed because we realized it was the end.

title: ~죠 [jyo] (~Isn't it?)
short_explanation: Used as a tag question to request confirmation or agreement from the listener.
long_explanation: '~죠 [jyo]' is typically used to seek agreement or confirmation from the listener, much like a tag question in English (e.g. 'isn't it?', 'right?'). It can also appear as '~지요', which is slightly more formal/polite.

examples.kr: 오늘은 날씨가 좋죠?
examples.romaji: Oneureun nalssiga johjyo?
examples.en: The weather is nice today, isn't it?

examples.kr: 영화가 재미있었죠?
examples.romaji: Yeonghwaga jaemiisseotjyo?
examples.en: The movie was fun, wasn't it?

examples.kr: 그녀는 아름답죠?
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun areumdapjyo?
examples.en: She is beautiful, isn't she?

examples.kr: 우리 곧 만날 거죠?
examples.romaji: Uri got mannalggeojyo?
examples.en: We will meet soon, right?

title: ~지 않다 [ji anta] (Negative form)
short_explanation: Used to negate verbs/adjectives; equivalent to 'not' in English.
long_explanation: '~지 않다 [ji anta]' creates the negative form of verbs or adjectives, similar to 'not' in English. It indicates that an action does not happen or a state does not exist.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침밥을 먹지 않아요. 대신에 과일을 먹어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achimbabeul meokji anhayo. Daesine gwail-eul meogeoyo.
examples.en: I don't eat breakfast every morning. Instead, I eat fruit.

examples.kr: 우리 할머니는 한국에 살지 않아요, 미국에 살아요.
examples.romaji: Uri halmeonineun hanguge salji anhayo, miguge sarayo.
examples.en: Our grandmother doesn't live in Korea, she lives in America.

examples.kr: 나는 이런 상황을 좋아하지 않아요. 나에게 스트레스를 줘요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ireon sanghwangeul johahaji anhayo. Na-ege seuteureseureul jwoyo.
examples.en: I do not like these kinds of situations; they give me stress.

examples.kr: 당신은 그 사람을 알지 않아요? 그는 우리 학교에서 유명한 선생님이에요.
examples.romaji: Dangsineun geu sarameul alji anhayo? Geuneun uri hakgyoeseo yumyeonghan seonsaengnimieyo.
examples.en: Don't you know that person? He is a famous teacher at our school.

title: ~지 않아도 되다 [ji anado dweda] (Don't have to)
short_explanation: Used to express that an action is not necessary or mandatory; 'don't have to'.
long_explanation: '~지 않아도 되다 [ji anado dweda]' indicates that someone is not obliged to perform a certain action. It literally means 'it is okay even if you do not do something.'

examples.kr: 너무 걱정하지 않아도 돼. 모두 잘 될 거야.
examples.romaji: Neomu geokjeonghaji anado dwae. Modu jal doel geoya.
examples.en: You don't have to worry too much. Everything will be fine.

examples.kr: 시험을 이미 통과했기 때문에 더 이상 공부하지 않아도 돼.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul imi tonggwahaetgi ttaemune deo isang gongbuhaji anado dwae.
examples.en: You don't need to study anymore because you've already passed the exam.

examples.kr: 우리는 다른 사람들을 위해 모든 것을 포기하지 않아도 돼.
examples.romaji: Urineun dareun saramdeureul wihae modeun geoseul pogihaji anado dwae.
examples.en: We don't have to give up everything for other people.

examples.kr: 비가 온다고 해서 그냥 집에 머무르지 않아도 돼.
examples.romaji: Biga ondago haeseo geunyang jibe meomureuji anado dwae.
examples.en: You don’t have to stay home just because it's raining.

title: 지만 [jiman] (but)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast between two statements, similar to 'but' in English.
long_explanation: '지만 [jiman]' is a common conjunction in Korean that expresses contrast or contradiction between two clauses, much like 'but' in English. The second clause contradicts or provides an unexpected twist to the first clause.

examples.kr: 오늘은 일찍 일어났지만, 학교에 늦었어요. 버스를 놓쳐서 그래요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun iljjik ireonatjiman, hakgyoe neujeosseoyo. Beoseureul nochyeoseo geuraeyo.
examples.en: I woke up early today, but I was late for school because I missed the bus.

examples.kr: 공부를 많이 하지만, 아직 이해가 잘 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul mani hajiman, ajik ihaega jal an dwaeyo.
examples.en: I study a lot, but I still don't understand it well.

examples.kr: 철수는 키가 작지만 매우 강력한 사람이에요.
examples.romaji: Cheolsuneun kiga jakjiman maeu gangnyeokhan saramieyo.
examples.en: Chulsoo is short, but he's very strong.

examples.kr: 여기 음식은 맛있지만 가격이 너무 비싸요.
examples.romaji: Yeogi eumsik-eun masitjiman gagyeogi neomu bissayo.
examples.en: The food here is delicious, but it's too expensive.
