title: ~지요 [jiyo] (Isn't it? Right?)
short_explanation: Used to confirm or check agreement with the listener, akin to a polite tag question.
long_explanation: '~지요 [jiyo]' is a sentence ending used in Korean to ask for confirmation or acknowledgment from the listener. It's often used in polite or friendly conversation to invite agreement or verify shared knowledge, similar to saying 'isn't it?' or 'right?' in English.

examples.kr: 날씨가 많이 추워졌지요? 스카프를 챙기는 게 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga mani chuwajyeotjiyo? Seukapeureul chaenggineun ge jokesseoyo.
examples.en: It's gotten quite cold, hasn't it? We should bring a scarf.

examples.kr: 우리 다음 주에 시험 있지요? 공부 시작해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Uri daeum jue siheom itjiyo? Gongbu sijakhaeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: We have an exam next week, right? We should start studying.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 친구들과 캠핑 가기로 했지요? 준비가 좀 더 필요할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumale chingudeulgwa kaemping gagiro haetjiyo? Junbiga jom deo pilyohal geot gatayo.
examples.en: We decided to go camping with friends this weekend, didn't we? I think we need more preparation.

examples.kr: 요즘 일이 많아서 힘들지요? 휴식이 정말 필요한 때 같아요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum iri manhaseo himdeuljiyo? Hyusigi jeongmal pilyohan ttae gatayo.
examples.en: Work's been tough lately, hasn't it? It seems like we really need a break.

title: ~진 않지만 [jin anhjiman] (Not exactly, but)
short_explanation: Used to express that something is not entirely true but partially or somewhat so.
long_explanation: '~진 않지만 [jin anhjiman]' indicates that a certain condition is not exactly or fully met, yet there is some partial truth or a mitigating factor. It softens the statement, showing modesty or a lesser degree than expected.

examples.kr: 네가 좋아하는 그 영화, 난 별로 재미있진 않지만 볼 만했어.
examples.romaji: Nega joahaneun geu yeonghwa, nan byeollo jaemiitjin anhjiman bol manhaesseo.
examples.en: That movie you like wasn't exactly fun for me, but it was worth watching.

examples.kr: 그가 말한 건 중요하진 않지만, 알아 두면 좋을 거야.
examples.romaji: Geuga malhan geon jungyohajin anhjiman, ara dumyeon jo-eul geoya.
examples.en: What he said isn't exactly important, but it's good to keep in mind.

examples.kr: 네가 준 선글라스, 예쁘진 않지만 꽤 유용해.
examples.romaji: Nega jun seongleoseu, yeppeujin anhjiman kkwae yuyonghae.
examples.en: The sunglasses you gave me aren't exactly pretty, but they're quite useful.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아주 유명하진 않지만 충분히 재능이 있어.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun aju yumyeonghajin anhjiman chungbunhi jaeneung-i isseo.
examples.en: She's not very famous, but she definitely has talent.

title: ~쯤 [jjeum] (About, around)
short_explanation: A postposition indicating approximation or estimation (time, quantity, degree).
long_explanation: '~쯤 [jjeum]' is used in Korean to show a rough estimate or approximation, similar to 'about,' 'around,' or 'approximately' in English. It's often used in casual conversation to give an inexact notion of time, number, or degree.

examples.kr: 회사에는 오후 3시쯤 도착할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Hoesa-eneun ohu sam si jjeum dochakhal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I think I'll arrive at the office around 3 PM.

examples.kr: 어제 그녀는 약 열 개쯤 쿠키를 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje geunyeoneun yak yeol gae jjeum kukireul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: She ate about ten cookies yesterday.

examples.kr: 여기서 학교까지 걸어서 15분쯤 걸릴 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Yeogiseo hakgyokkaji georeoseo sip-o bun jjeum geolril geot gatayo.
examples.en: It will take about 15 minutes to walk from here to the school.

examples.kr: 그는 이미 오백 페이지쯤 읽어서 곧 책을 다 읽을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun imi obaek peiji jjeum ilgeoseo got chaegeul da ilgeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: He's already read about five hundred pages, so he'll likely finish the book soon.

title: ~처럼 [cheoreom] (Like, as)
short_explanation: Used to compare two things or indicate that something behaves similarly to something else.
long_explanation: '처럼 [cheoreom]' is a postposition in Korean that draws a comparison between two things, states, or actions, similar to 'like' or 'as' in English. It indicates that one entity resembles another in appearance, manner, or feeling.

examples.kr: 그녀는 천사처럼 생겼어요. 얼굴이 매우 예쁘고 순수해 보여요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun cheonsacheoreom saenggyeosseoyo. Eolguli maeu yeppeugo sunsuhae boyeoyo.
examples.en: She looks like an angel. Her face is very pretty and she looks pure.

examples.kr: 이 음식은 어머니가 만든 것처럼 맛있어요. 집밥 느낌이 나요.
examples.romaji: I eumsigeun eomeoniga mandeun geotcheoreom masisseoyo. Jibbab neukkimi nayo.
examples.en: This food tastes like something my mother would cook. It feels like homemade food.

examples.kr: 그는 꿈에서 본 사람처럼 보여서 깜짝 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun kkumeseo bon saramcheoreom boyeoseo kkamjjak nollaesseoyo.
examples.en: He looked like the person I saw in my dream, and it surprised me.

examples.kr: 태양이 뜨면 마치 새로운 세상이 열린 것처럼 기분이 좋아져요.
examples.romaji: Taeyangi tteumyeon machi saeroun sesangi yeollin geotcheoreom gibuni joajyeoyo.
examples.en: When the sun rises, I feel as if a new world has opened.

title: ~층 [cheung] (Floor count)
short_explanation: Used to express the number of floors in a building, like 'nth floor'.
long_explanation: '~층 [cheung]' is a suffix in Korean denoting which floor of a building is being referred to. It attaches to a numeral to indicate the ordinal floor number, similar to English expressions like 'the 3rd floor', 'the 15th floor', etc.

examples.kr: 저희 집은 아파트 건물의 15층에 위치하고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeohui jip-eun apateu geonmul-ui sib-o cheung-e wichihago itsseumnida.
examples.en: Our home is located on the 15th floor of the apartment building.

examples.kr: 회사는 높은 건물의 20층에 있어서 전망이 정말 좋습니다.
examples.romaji: Hoesa-neun nopeun geonmul-ui isip cheung-e isseoseo jeonmangi jeongmal joseumnida.
examples.en: The company is on the 20th floor of a tall building, so the view is really good.

examples.kr: 엘리베이터가 없으면 10층까지 걸어서 올라가야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Ellibeiteoga eobseumyeon sip cheung-kkaji georeoseo ollagaya hamnida.
examples.en: If there is no elevator, you have to walk up to the 10th floor.

examples.kr: 복층 아파트 구조는 일반적으로 2층 건물로 설계됩니다.
examples.romaji: Bokcheung apateu gujoneun ilbanjeogeuro i-cheung geonmul-lo seolgyedoemnida.
examples.en: A duplex apartment structure is typically designed as a two-story building.

title: ~(으)ㄹ지 (Maybe, perhaps)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty, doubt, or speculation; 'might', 'maybe', 'I'm not sure if...'.
long_explanation: The grammar pattern '~(으)ㄹ지' is used with verbs or adjectives to convey uncertainty or speculation. It often appears with expressions like '모르겠다 (I don't know)', forming '~(으)ㄹ지 모르겠다' to mean 'I’m not sure if...' or 'maybe...'. It's similar to 'perhaps' or 'might' in English.

examples.kr: 오늘은 비가 올지 모르겠어요, 아침에는 맑았거든요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun biga olji moreugesseoyo, achim-eneun malgatgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I’m not sure if it will rain today; it was clear in the morning.

examples.kr: 그 학생이 시험을 통과할지 잘 모르겠어요. 공부를 열심히 안 해서요.
examples.romaji: Geu haksaengi siheomeul tonggwahalji jal moreugesseoyo. Gongbureul yeolsimhi an haeseo-yo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if that student will pass the exam, because he didn't study hard.

examples.kr: 그녀가 이렇게 많이 먹을 수 있을지 몰랐어요. 항상 조금만 먹었거든요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga ireohge manhi meogeul su isseulji mollasseoyo. Hangsang jogeumman meogeotgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I didn’t know she could eat this much; she usually only ate small amounts.

examples.kr: 저를 사랑하실지 아직 잘 모르겠어요. 그분의 마음을 아직 잘 몰라요.
examples.romaji: Jeoreul saranghasilji ajik jal moreugesseoyo. Geubunui maeumeul ajik jal mollayo.
examples.en: I’m still not sure if she loves me; I don’t know her feelings well yet.

title: ~마다 [mada] (Every, each)
short_explanation: Used to express routines or regular occurrences; 'every', 'each'.
long_explanation: '~마다 [mada]' is a suffix in Korean used after time words or intervals to indicate repetition or regularity, similar to 'every' in English. For example, 매주 토요일마다 (every Saturday), 매일 아침마다 (every morning), 매월 마지막 주마다 (every last week of the month), etc.

examples.kr: 나는 매주 토요일마다 운동을 합니다. 이렇게 규칙적으로 운동하면 건강에 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeju toyoil-mada undongeul hamnida. Ireohge gyuchikjeogeuro undonghamyeon geongange joayo.
examples.en: I exercise every Saturday. Exercising regularly like this is good for my health.

examples.kr: 그는 일주일에 두 번씩 한국어를 공부해요, 그래서 한국어 실력이 빨리 향상되고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun iljuire du beon-ssik hangugeoreul gongbuhaeyo, geuraeseo hangugeo silryeogi ppalli hyangsangdoego isseoyo.
examples.en: He studies Korean twice a week, so his Korean skills are improving quickly.

examples.kr: 우리는 매일 아침마다 만나서 함께 식사를 해요. 이게 우리의 일상적인 습관이에요.
examples.romaji: Urineun maeil achim-mada mannaseo hamkke siksareul haeyo. Ige uriui ilsangjeogin seupgwanieyo.
examples.en: We meet every morning and have a meal together. That's our daily routine.

examples.kr: 그녀는 매달 마지막 주 일요일마다 가족들과 모여요. 그렇게 시간을 보내는 게 그녀의 방식이에요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun maedal majimak ju ilyoil-mada gajokdeulgwa moyeoyo. Geureohge siganeul bonaeneun ge geunyeoui bangsikieyo.
examples.en: She gathers with her family on the last Sunday of each month. That's how she spends time with them.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 테니까 [tenikka] (So, therefore)
short_explanation: Indicates an assumption or reason, leading to a suggestion or conclusion; 'because it will be...', 'so'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 테니까' expresses the speaker’s assumption or strong guess about a future or present state, providing a reason for the following statement. For example, '배가 고플 테니까 (you must be hungry), so let's eat.' This form combines the future/assumed ending '~(으)ㄹ 테다' with '~니까 (because)'.

examples.kr: 너무 배가 고플 테니까 빨리 식당에 가서 뭔가 먹어야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu baega gopeul tenikka ppalli sikdang-e gaseo mwonga meogeoyagesseoyo.
examples.en: You must be really hungry, so let's go to the restaurant quickly and get something to eat.

examples.kr: 시험을 잘 보려면 많이 공부했을 테니까 꼭 좋은 점수를 받을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul jal boryeomyeon manhi gongbuhaesseul tenikka kkok joeun jeomsureul badeul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Since you probably studied a lot to do well on the test, I'm sure you'll get a good score.

examples.kr: 우리는 곧 이 문제를 해결할 테니까 조금만 기다려 주세요.
examples.romaji: Urineun got i munjereul haegyeolhal tenikka jogeumman gidaryeo juseyo.
examples.en: We will solve this problem soon, so please wait just a bit.

examples.kr: 내가 금방 갈 테니까 먼저 준비하고 있어.
examples.romaji: Naega geumbang gal tenikka meonjeo junbihago isseo.
examples.en: I’ll be there soon, so get things ready first.

title: ~편이다 [pyeonida] (It is preferable)
short_explanation: Indicates a personal leaning, tendency, or preference; 'tend to', 'find it better to'.
long_explanation: The construction '~편이다 [pyeonida]' expresses that something is on the side of or tends to be a certain way. It conveys a personal preference or leaning. For example, '저는 집에서 공부하는 편이에요' means 'I tend to study at home' or 'I prefer studying at home.'
formation: Verb stem + (으)ㄴ/는 편이다 or Adjective + 편이다

examples.kr: 저는 여름보다 겨울이 훨씬 즐거운 편이에요. 눈이 많이 오는 걸 좋아하거든요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yeoreumboda gyeouli hwolssin jeulgeoun pyeonieyo. Nuni manhi oneun geol joahageodeunyo.
examples.en: I find winter much more enjoyable than summer. I love it when it snows a lot.

examples.kr: 사람들과 대화하는 게 은근히 어려운 편이라서, 보통은 메시지로 먼저 연락해요.
examples.romaji: Saramdeulgwa daehwahaneun ge eungeunhi eoryeoun pyeoniraseo, botongeun mesijiro meonjeo yeollakhaeyo.
examples.en: I find talking to people somewhat difficult, so I usually contact them via messages first.

examples.kr: 어렸을 때부터 수학 문제를 푸는 편이었어요. 그래서 나중에 수학 선생님이 되고 싶었죠.
examples.romaji: Eoryeosseul ttaebuteo suhak munjereul puneun pyeonieosseoyo. Geuraeseo najunge suhak seonsaengnimi doego sipeotjyo.
examples.en: I've tended to be good at solving math problems since I was young, so I wanted to become a math teacher later on.

examples.kr: 매운 음식을 좋아하는 편이라서, 자주 매운 라면을 먹습니다.
examples.romaji: Maewun eumsigeul joahaneun pyeoniraseo, jaju maewun ramyeoneul meokseumnida.
examples.en: I generally prefer spicy food, so I often eat spicy ramen.

title: ~하다가 [hadaga] (Was doing something and then...)
short_explanation: Indicates an ongoing action that is interrupted by another event; 'was doing... then...'.
long_explanation: '~하다가 [hadaga]' shows that one action was in progress when something else happened or changed. It often implies an unexpected interruption or switch of focus while the first activity was still ongoing.

examples.kr: 저는 숙제를 하다가 친구가 전화해서 놀러 가자고 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun sukjereul hadaga chinguga jeonhwahaeseo nolleo gajago haesseoyo.
examples.en: I was doing my homework when my friend called and suggested we go out.

examples.kr: 저는 새벽에 산책을 하다가 갑자기 비가 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun saebyeoke sanchaekeul hadaga gabjagi biga wasseoyo.
examples.en: I was taking a walk at dawn when it suddenly started to rain.

examples.kr: 어제 저는 밖에서 책을 읽다가 갑자기 배가 고파졌어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje jeoneun bakeseo chaekeul ilgdaga gabjagi baega gopajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Yesterday, I was reading a book outside when I suddenly became hungry.

examples.kr: 나는 음악을 듣다가 어떤 노래가 내 기분에 맞아서 기분이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eumageul deudaga eotteon noraega nae gibune machaseo gibuni joajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was listening to music, and then a certain song matched my mood, and I felt better.

title: ~하면 [hamyeon] (If, when)
short_explanation: Expresses a condition or hypothetical situation; 'if', 'when'.
long_explanation: '~하면 [hamyeon]' introduces a conditional or hypothetical clause, much like 'if' or 'when' in English. It sets up a situation or requirement that triggers the outcome in the following clause.

examples.kr: 나중에 시간이 더 많아지면, 더 많은 책을 읽을 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Najunge sigani deo manhajimyeon, deo manheun chaegeul ilgeul su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If I have more time later, I'll be able to read more books.

examples.kr: 오늘 비가 오면, 우리는 영화를 보러 못 갈 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneul biga omyeon, urineun yeonghwareul boreo mot gal geot gatayo.
examples.en: If it rains today, we probably won't be able to go to the movies.

examples.kr: 그가 우리에게 증거를 보여주면, 우리는 그를 믿을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geuga urinege jeunggeoreul boyeojumyeon, urineun geureul mideul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If he shows us the evidence, we'll believe him.

examples.kr: 네가 학교를 더 열심히 다니면, 좋은 성적을 받을 수 있을 거야.
examples.romaji: Nega hakgyoreul deo yeolsimhi danimyeon, joeun seongjeogeul badeul su isseul geoya.
examples.en: If you attend school more diligently, you'll be able to get good grades.

title: ~하면서 [hamyeonseo] (While doing)
short_explanation: Expresses two simultaneous actions; 'while', 'as'.
long_explanation: '~하면서 [hamyeonseo]' is used to describe two actions happening at the same time or an action happening in the background while another action occurs. It's similar to 'while' or 'as' in English when describing simultaneous activities.

examples.kr: 자연 속에서 힐링하면서 사진도 많이 찍었어요.
examples.romaji: Jayeon sogeseo hillinghamyeonseo sajindo mani jjigeosseoyo.
examples.en: While healing in nature, I also took a lot of pictures.

examples.kr: 음악을 들으면서 숙제를 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Eumageul deuleumyeonseo sukjereul haesseumnida.
examples.en: I did my homework while listening to music.

examples.kr: 아빠는 TV를 보면서 저녁을 드셨어요.
examples.romaji: Appaneun tibeireul bomyeonseo jeonyeogeul deusyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Dad ate dinner while watching TV.

examples.kr: 그는 걸으면서 책을 읽는 습관이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun georeumyeonseo chaekeul ilgneun seubgwani isseoyo.
examples.en: He has a habit of reading books while walking.

title: ~하기는 [hakineun] (Though, although)
short_explanation: Used to express 'though' or 'although', showing contrast or contradiction.
long_explanation: '~하기는 [hakineun]' is used to convey a sense of contrast or contradiction, similar to 'though' or 'although' in English. While the sentence may start with an assumption or statement, this grammar introduces a point that contradicts or partially goes against the expected outcome.

examples.kr: 저는 요리하기는 좋아하지만, 게으른 편이라서 자주 식당에서 먹어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yori-hakineun joahajiman, ge-eu-reun pyeoniraseo jaju sikdang-eseo meogeoyo.
examples.en: Although I like cooking, I often eat in restaurants because I'm lazy.

examples.kr: 이 영화를 보러 가기는 하지만, 사실 기대하진 않아요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwareul boreo ga-gineun hajiman, sasil gidaehajin anhayo.
examples.en: Though I'm going to watch this movie, honestly, I don't have high expectations.

examples.kr: 친구가 가게를 운영하기는 하지만, 자주 방문하지는 않아요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga gagereul unyeong-hakineun hajiman, jaju bangmunhajineun anhayo.
examples.en: Though my friend runs a shop, I don't visit often.

examples.kr: 제가 그 사람을 좋아하기는 하지만, 그 사람이 절 좋아하지는 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jega geu sarameul joahakineun hajiman, geu sarami jeol joahajineun anhayo.
examples.en: Though I like that person, they don't like me.

title: ~하기로 하다 [hakiro hada] (Decide to)
short_explanation: Expresses a decision or agreement to do something.
long_explanation: '~하기로 하다 [hakiro hada]' indicates that a decision or agreement has been made to perform an action. It often appears in contexts describing future plans or intentions. After a verb stem, it is followed by '기로 하다' which translates to 'decide to' in English.

examples.kr: 내일 우리는 수영장에 가기로 했어요. 다 같이 수영할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naeil urineun suyeongjange ga-giro haesseoyo. Da gachi suyeonghal geoyeyo.
examples.en: We decided to go to the swimming pool tomorrow; we'll all swim together.

examples.kr: 나는 다음 학기에 한국어 공부하기로 했습니다. 한국어 능력을 향상시키고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun daeum hakgye-e hangugeo gongbu-hakiro haetseumnida. Hangugeo neungnyeogeul hyangsangsikigo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I decided to study Korean next semester; I want to improve my Korean skills.

examples.kr: 집에 오는 길에 장보기로 했어요. 식료품이 부족해서요.
examples.romaji: Jibe oneun gil-e jang-bokiro haesseoyo. Sikryopumi bujokhaeseoyo.
examples.en: I decided to do some grocery shopping on my way home, because we're running low on food.

examples.kr: 우리 팀은 이번 주에 프로젝트를 시작하기로 했어요. 일찍 끝내고 싶어서요.
examples.romaji: Uri timeun ibeon jue peurojekteureul sijak-hakiro haesseoyo. Iljjik kkeutnaego sipeoseoyo.
examples.en: Our team decided to start the project this week, because we want to finish early.

title: ~하기보다 [hakiboda] (Rather than)
short_explanation: Compares two actions or things, indicating a preference for one over the other.
long_explanation: '~하기보다 [hakiboda]' is used to express 'rather than' in Korean. It typically shows that the second action or choice is more desirable, suitable, or preferable than the first one.

examples.kr: 살을 더 찌우기보다 건강하게 운동하는 것이 더 중요해요.
examples.romaji: Sareul deo jjiugiboda geonganghage undonghaneun geosi deo jungyohaeyo.
examples.en: Rather than putting on more weight, it's more important to exercise in a healthy way.

examples.kr: 집에 있기보다 친구들과 밖에서 놀고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe itgi-boda chingudeulgwa bakk-eseo nolgo sipeoyo.
examples.en: Rather than staying at home, I'd like to go out and play with my friends.

examples.kr: 꿈을 포기하기보다 계속 추구하기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Kkumeul pogihagiboda gyesok chuguhagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I decided to keep pursuing my dream rather than giving it up.

examples.kr: 돈을 벌기보다 무엇을 사랑하는지 찾는 것이 더 중요하다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Doneul beolgiboda mueoseul saranghaneunji chatneun geosi deo jungyohadago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: I think it's more important to find what you love rather than just earning money.

title: ~하기에 [hakie] (For, considering)
short_explanation: Expresses a reason or basis for a certain situation; 'for, considering'.
long_explanation: '~하기에 [hakie]' is used to provide a reason or basis for a circumstance or decision. It can translate to 'for', 'because', or 'considering that...' in English, especially when justifying or explaining a certain choice.

examples.kr: 그의 나이에 비해 축구 실력이 매우 좋아서, 프로 팀 진출이 가능하기에 노력하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuui naie bihae chukgu silryeogi maeu johaseo, peuro tim jinchul-i ganeunghakie noryeokhago isseoyo.
examples.en: Considering his age, his soccer skills are really good, so he's trying to join a professional team.

examples.kr: 그 직업은 수입이 많지만 스트레스도 많아서, 건강을 위해서는 좋지 않을 수 있기에 주의해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Geu jig-eobeun su-ibi manhjiman seuteureseu-do manhaseo, geongangeul wihaeseoneun jotji anheul su itgye jeuihaeya haeyo.
examples.en: That job has a high income but is also stressful; considering your health, it might not be the best choice, so be cautious.

examples.kr: 재료가 너무 많아 필요 없는 것들을 버리기에는 아깝다고 느껴져요.
examples.romaji: Jaeryoga neomu manha piryo eomneun geotdeureul beorigieneun akkapdago neukkyeojyeoyo.
examples.en: There are so many ingredients that it feels wasteful to throw away the unnecessary ones.

examples.kr: 최근 날씨 변화를 보면, 내일 피크닉 가기에는 너무 더울 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Choegeun nalssi byeonhwareul bomyeon, naeil pikeunik gagieneun neomu deoul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Considering the recent weather changes, it might be too hot to go on a picnic tomorrow.

title: ~하기만 하면 [hakiman hamyeon] (As long as)
short_explanation: Expresses that if a certain condition is met, a result is guaranteed to follow; 'as long as'.
long_explanation: '~하기만 하면 [hakiman hamyeon]' means 'as long as one does something, then something else will definitely happen.' It implies a condition that, once fulfilled, ensures a particular outcome.

examples.kr: 저는 열심히 공부하기만 하면 한국어 시험을 분명히 통과할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yeolsimhi gongbu-hagiman hamyeon hangugeo siheomeul bunmyeonghi tonggwahal geoyeyo.
examples.en: As long as I study hard, I'll definitely pass the Korean exam.

examples.kr: 당신이 저를 믿어주기만 하면 상처를 치유하기가 훨씬 수월해질 거예요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini jeoreul mideojugiman hamyeon sangcheoreul chiyuhagiga hwolssin suwolhaejil geoyeyo.
examples.en: As long as you trust me, healing the wounds will be much easier.

examples.kr: 조금만 노력하기만 하면 그림 그리는 기술을 향상시킬 수 있을 겁니다.
examples.romaji: Jogeumman noryeok-hagiman hamyeon geurim geurineun gisuleul hyangsangsikil su isseul geomnida.
examples.en: As long as you make even a bit of effort, you can improve your drawing skills.

examples.kr: 사람들이 서로를 이해하려고 노력하기만 하면 세상은 더 나은 곳이 될 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Saramdeuri seororeul ihaeharyeogo noryeok-hagiman hamyeon sesangeun deo naeun gosi doel su isseoyo.
examples.en: As long as people try to understand each other, the world can become a better place.

title: ~하는 것 같다 [haneun geot gatda] (It seems like)
short_explanation: Used to express that something appears or seems a certain way; 'it seems/looks like'.
long_explanation: '~하는 것 같다 [haneun geot gatda]' indicates the speaker's guess or observation based on evidence or impressions. It can translate to 'it seems like', 'it appears that', or 'it looks like' in English. The verb or adjective precedes '...는 것 같다' to form a statement of appearance or assumption.
formation: Verb stem + 는 것 같다 / Adjective stem + (으)ㄴ 것 같다

examples.kr: 나는 그가 내 말을 이해하는 것 같아요. 그의 표정이 안도감을 보여줬거든요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geuga nae mareul ihaehaneun geot gatayo. Geuui pyojeongi andogameul boyeojwotgeodeunyo.
examples.en: It seems like he understands what I’m saying; his expression showed relief.

examples.kr: 오늘 너무 추운 것 같아요. 밖에서 사람들이 몸을 잔뜩 웅크리고 있더라고요.
examples.romaji: Oneul neomu chuun geot gatayo. Bakk-eseo saramdeuri momeul jantteuk ungkeurigo itdeoragoyo.
examples.en: It seems really cold today; I saw people outside huddling together.

examples.kr: 내 친구가 수업에 늦는 것 같아요. 학교로 뛰어가면서 급하게 문자를 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Nae chinguga sueobe neujneun geot gatayo. Hakgyoro ttwieogamyeonseo geuphage munjareul bonaesseoyo.
examples.en: It seems like my friend is late for class. She sent me a rushed text while running to school.

examples.kr: 그가 나에게 화난 것 같아요. 표정이 좋지 않더라고요.
examples.romaji: Geuga naege hwanan geot gatayo. Pyojeongi joji antdeoragoyo.
examples.en: It seems like he’s mad at me. His facial expression didn’t look good.

title: ~하는 데 [haneun de] (In doing)
short_explanation: Expresses the process of doing something, often involving time, effort, or resources.
long_explanation: '~하는 데 [haneun de]' highlights the time, effort, or resources necessary for an action. It can be thought of as 'in doing something' or 'it takes X to do something'.

examples.kr: 집에 도착하는 데 시간이 오래 걸렸어요. 차가 많이 막혔거든요.
examples.romaji: Jibe dochak-haneun de sigani orae geollyeosseoyo. Chaga manhi makyeotgeodeunyo.
examples.en: It took a long time to get home. There was a lot of traffic.

examples.kr: 올해 목표를 달성하는 데 정말 많은 노력이 필요했어요.
examples.romaji: Olhae mokpyoreul dalsseong-haneun de jeongmal manheun noryeogi pilyohaesseoyo.
examples.en: It took a lot of effort to achieve this year's goal.

examples.kr: 이 케이크를 만드는 데 하루 종일 걸렸어요. 재료 준비부터 장식까지 다 했거든요.
examples.romaji: I keikeureul mandeuneun de haru jongil geollyeosseoyo. Jaeryo junbibuteo jangsik-kkaji da haetgeodeunyo.
examples.en: It took me all day to make this cake, from preparing the ingredients to decorating it.

examples.kr: 이효리 신곡을 작곡하는 데 한 달 넘게 걸렸어요.
examples.romaji: Ihyo-ri singogeul jakgok-haneun de han dal neomge geollyeosseoyo.
examples.en: It took over a month to compose Lee Hyo-ri's new song.

title: ~하는 편이다 [haneun pyeonida] (Tend to do)
short_explanation: Expresses a habitual action, tendency, or characteristic.
long_explanation: '~하는 편이다 [haneun pyeonida]' means someone or something tends toward a certain behavior or habit. It implies that it’s not an absolute rule, but rather the usual or likely tendency the speaker observes.
formation: Verb stem + 는 편이다 / Adjective stem + (으)ㄴ 편이다

examples.kr: 나는 책 읽는 걸 좋아해서 보통 많은 시간을 보내는 편이다.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaek ilgneun geol joahaeseo botong manheun siganeul bonaeneun pyeonida.
examples.en: I like reading books, so I tend to spend a lot of time on it.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 일찍 자는 편이다. 그래서 늘 건강하다는 말을 자주 들어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang iljjik janeun pyeonida. Geuraeseo neul geonganghadaneun mareul jaju deureoyo.
examples.en: He tends to go to bed early, so people often say he's very healthy.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 늘 맛있는 음식을 만드는 편이다.
examples.romaji: Uri eomma-neun neul masinneun eumsigeul mandeuneun pyeonida.
examples.en: My mom tends to always cook delicious food.

examples.kr: 저는 일을 미루는 편이라서, 가끔 할 일이 몰릴 때가 많아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ireul miruneun pyeoniraseo, gakkeum hal iri mollil ttaega manhayo.
examples.en: I tend to procrastinate, so I often end up with a lot of tasks all at once.

title: ~하는 한 [haneun han] (As long as)
short_explanation: Expresses the meaning 'as long as' or 'while' a certain condition holds true.
long_explanation: '~하는 한 [haneun han]' is used to indicate that something remains valid or continues to be the case so long as a condition is met. It can translate to 'as long as' in English, specifying the scope or boundary within which an action or state continues.

examples.kr: 당신이 건강을 유지하는 한 큰 문제는 없을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini geongangeul yuji-haneun han, keun munjeneun eobseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: There won't be any big problems as long as you stay healthy.

examples.kr: 네가 내 옆에 있는 한 나는 행복해.
examples.romaji: Nega nae yeope inneun han naneun haengbokhae.
examples.en: As long as you're by my side, I'm happy.

examples.kr: 그녀가 진심으로 노력하는 한 목표는 달성할 수 있을 거야.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga jinsimeuro noryeok-haneun han mokpyoneun dalseonghal su isseul geoya.
examples.en: She can achieve her goal as long as she's sincerely working hard.

examples.kr: 우리가 함께하는 한 어떤 어려움도 극복할 수 있어.
examples.romaji: Uriga hamkke-haneun han eotteon eoryeoumdo geukbokhal su isseo.
examples.en: We can overcome any difficulty as long as we're together.

title: ~하는데 [haneunde] (But, and so)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or a cause-and-result link; 'but', 'and so'.
long_explanation: '~하는데 [haneunde]' is a Korean connector used to indicate contrast or provide background leading to a result, akin to 'but' or 'and so' in English. Often, the first clause establishes a situation or background and the second clause states a contradictory fact or a consequence derived from that background.

examples.kr: 제 친구는 공부를 많이 했는데도 시험에 떨어졌어요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguneun gongbureul mani haetneundedo siheome tteoreojyeosseoyo.
examples.en: My friend studied a lot, but he still failed the exam.

examples.kr: 비가 오는데 우산을 가져오지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Biga oneunde usaneul gajyeoji anasseoyo.
examples.en: It's raining, but I didn't bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 게임이 재미있는데 시간이 너무 빨리 가요.
examples.romaji: Geimi jaemiissneunde sigani neomu ppalli gayo.
examples.en: The game is fun, and time passes so quickly.

examples.kr: 이 케이크는 맛있는데 당분이 너무 많아요.
examples.romaji: I keikeuneun masissneunde dangbuni neomu manhayo.
examples.en: This cake is delicious, but it has too much sugar.

title: ~하다 보면 [hada bomyeon] (If one keeps doing)
short_explanation: Expresses that, with continued or repeated action, a certain result or realization will emerge.
long_explanation: '~하다 보면 [hada bomyeon]' indicates that if someone continues or repeatedly does an action over time, a new result, skill, or understanding will naturally occur. It's akin to 'if one keeps doing something' or 'if one continues doing something' in English.

examples.kr: 매일 한국어를 공부하다 보면 어느새 한국어를 잘하게 될 거예요.
examples.romaji: Maeil hangugeoreul gongbuhada bomyeon eoneusae hangugeoreul jalhage doel geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you keep studying Korean every day, you'll eventually become good at it.

examples.kr: 계속 연습하다 보면 예술에 대한 흥미와 재능을 찾을 수 있을 거라고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Gyesok yeonseuphada bomyeon yesure daehan heungmiwa jaeneungeul chajeul su isseul georago saenggakaeyo.
examples.en: If you keep practicing, I think you'll be able to find your interest and talent in art.

examples.kr: 헬스장에 자주 가다 보면 체력이 좋아지고 더 건강해질 거예요.
examples.romaji: Helseujange jaju gada bomyeon cheryeogi joajigo deo geonganghaejil geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you go to the gym often, your stamina will improve and you'll get healthier.

examples.kr: 매일 그림을 그리다 보면 훌륭한 화가가 될 수도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Maeil geurimeul geurida bomyeon hullyunghan hwagaga doel sudo isseoyo.
examples.en: If you draw every day, you can become a great painter.

title: ~하다가는 [hadaganeun] (If you continue doing)
short_explanation: Indicates a likely negative outcome if the current action continues in the same manner.
long_explanation: '~하다가는 [hadaganeun]' is used to warn that if the speaker continues performing the preceding action in the same way, it will lead to an undesirable or negative consequence. It carries a sense of caution or concern.

examples.kr: 이렇게 계속 먹다가는 건강이 나빠질 수도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ireohge gyesok meokdaganeun geongangi nappeojil sudo isseoyo.
examples.en: If you keep eating like this, your health could get worse.

examples.kr: 같이 일하다가는 서로 관계가 나빠질 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Gati ilhadaganeun seoro gwangyega napajil geot gatayo.
examples.en: If we keep working together like this, our relationship might deteriorate.

examples.kr: 이런 식으로 공부하다가는 시험에 떨어질 수 있어.
examples.romaji: Ireon sigeuro gongbuhadaganeun siheome tteoreojil su isseo.
examples.en: If you keep studying like this, you could fail the exam.

examples.kr: 너는 맨날 게임만 하다가는 미래에 문제를 겪을지도 몰라.
examples.romaji: Neoneun maennal geimman hadaganeun mirae-e munjereul gyeokkeuljido molla.
examples.en: If you just keep playing games all the time, you might face problems in the future.

title: ~하여 [hayeo] (~ing, and)
short_explanation: Used to connect actions or show a method of doing something; roughly 'and' or 'by doing'.
long_explanation: '~하여 [hayeo]' is a somewhat formal connective ending in Korean used to link two actions or show that the second action happens by means of the first. It can often be translated as 'and' or 'by doing' in English. This form is more common in written or formal contexts compared to conversational speech.

examples.kr: 그는 매일 운동하여 건강을 유지합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun maeil undonghayeo geongangeul yujihamnida.
examples.en: He exercises every day and thus maintains his health.

examples.kr: 열심히 공부하여 목표를 달성했습니다.
examples.romaji: Yeolsimhi gongbuhayeo mokpyoreul dalseonghaesseumnida.
examples.en: I studied hard and achieved my goal.

examples.kr: 사장님은 직원들에게 동기를 부여하여 더 나은 성과를 얻었어요.
examples.romaji: Sajangnimeun jigwondeurege donggireul buyeohayeo deo naeun seonggwareul eot-eosseoyo.
examples.en: The boss motivated the employees and achieved better results.

examples.kr: 나는 예산을 절약하여 여행 자금을 마련했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun yesaneul jeoryaghayeo yeohaeng jagumeul maryeonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I saved money on my budget and set aside funds for travel.

title: ~하여야 [hayeoya] (Must)
short_explanation: Expresses necessity or obligation; 'must', 'have to'.
long_explanation: '~하여야 [hayeoya]' is a more formal verb ending indicating something must or has to be done. It attaches to action verbs and emphasizes the necessity of the action. It's typically used in more formal or written contexts.

examples.kr: 시험을 잘 보려면 열심히 공부하여야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul jal boryeomyeon yeolsimhi gongbuhayeoya hamnida.
examples.en: If you want to do well on the test, you must study hard.

examples.kr: 비올레 코딩을 배우려면 먼저 기본 파이썬 문법을 숙지하여야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Biole koding-eul baeureomyeon meonjeo gibon paiseon munbeobeul sukjihayeoya hamnida.
examples.en: If you want to learn ‘Viole coding,’ you must first master basic Python grammar.

examples.kr: 당신은 일을 잘하려면 집중하여야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsineun ireul jalharyeomyeon jipjunghayeoya hamnida.
examples.en: You must concentrate if you want to do your job well.

examples.kr: 빠르게 체중을 줄이려면 매일 운동하여야 해요.
examples.romaji: Ppareuge chejung-eul juriryeomyeon maeil undonghayeoya haeyo.
examples.en: If you want to lose weight quickly, you have to exercise daily.

title: ~하였다 [hayeotda] (Past formal)
short_explanation: A formal past-tense marker in Korean, used when addressing elders, superiors, or in polite writing.
long_explanation: '~하였다 [hayeotda]' is a formal or literary past-tense form in Korean that can be attached to action or descriptive verbs. It's frequently seen in official documents or polite narratives, emphasizing respect or formality.

examples.kr: 나는 어제 라면을 만들어 먹으려고 집에 돌아왔다가, 아주머니가 손님들을 위해 음식을 만들었다고 하여 함께 도왔습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoje ramyeoneul mandeureo meogeuryeogo jibe dorawatdaga, ajumeoni-ga sonnimdeureul wihae eumsigeul mandeureotdago hayeo hamkke dowatseumnida.
examples.en: Yesterday, I returned home to make ramen, but I found out the lady was cooking for guests, so I helped her.

examples.kr: 그는 한국어를 배우기 시작했을 때 아무것도 몰랐지만, 이제는 토픽 시험을 준비하였습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangugeoreul baeugi sijakhaesseul ttae amugeotdo mollatjiman, ijeneun Topik siheomeul junbihayeotseumnida.
examples.en: When he began learning Korean, he knew nothing at all, but now he has prepared for the TOPIK exam.

examples.kr: 학생들이 과제를 준비하지 않을 것이라고 예상했으나, 모두 진지하게 과제를 준비하였습니다.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeuri gwajereul junbihaji aneul geosirago yesanghaesseuna, modu jinjihage gwajereul junbihayeotseumnida.
examples.en: We expected students wouldn't prepare their homework, but they all prepared seriously.

examples.kr: 우리 팀은 이번 프로젝트를 위해 열심히 노력하였고, 결국 성공적으로 마무리하였습니다.
examples.romaji: Uri timeun ibeon peurojekteureul wihae yeolsimhi noryeokhayeotgo, gyeolguk seonggongjeogeuro mamurihayeotseumnida.
examples.en: Our team worked hard on this project and ultimately finished it successfully.

title: ~하자 [haja] (Upon doing, as soon as)
short_explanation: Indicates that the second action happens immediately after the first action is completed.
long_explanation: '~하자 [haja]' is a connector in Korean that conveys immediacy: once the action in the first clause is done, the action in the second clause occurs right away. It is similar to 'as soon as' in English.

examples.kr: 문을 열자마자 강아지가 들어왔어요.
examples.romaji: Muneul yeoljamaja gangajiga deureowasseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I opened the door, the dog came in.

examples.kr: 길을 건너자마자 바로 택시를 탔어요.
examples.romaji: Gireul geonneojamaja baro taeksireul tasseoyo.
examples.en: I got in a taxi right after I crossed the street.

examples.kr: 비가 오자마자 우산을 썼어요.
examples.romaji: Biga ojamaja usaneul sseosseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as it started to rain, I put up my umbrella.

examples.kr: 책을 덮자마자 잠이 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Chaekeul deopjamaja jami wasseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I closed the book, I felt sleepy.

title: ~할 것이다 [hal geotida] (Will, shall)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's future prediction or plan.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~할 것이다 [hal geotida]' is a future tense form that indicates a prediction or intention. Formed by the verb stem plus '할 것이다', it translates to 'will' or 'shall' in English. It is used when the speaker predicts a future occurrence or announces a plan.

examples.kr: 내일은 비가 올 것이다. 그래서 우산을 가져가야 할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Naeireun biga ol geotida. Geuraeseo usaneul gajyeogaya hal geotida.
examples.en: It will rain tomorrow, so I should bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 강아지를 키울 것이다. 그래서 강아지 용품을 사야 할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Gangajireul kiul geotida. Geuraeseo gangaji yongpumeul saya hal geotida.
examples.en: I will raise a puppy, so I should buy puppy supplies.

examples.kr: 다음 주에 한국에서 콘서트에 갈 것이다. 그래서 티켓을 예매할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Daeum jue hangug-eseo konseoteue gal geotida. Geuraeseo tikeseul yemaehal geotida.
examples.en: I will go to a concert in Korea next week, so I should book a ticket.

examples.kr: 내년에 대학원에 진학할 것이다. 그래서 세부 계획을 세울 것이다.
examples.romaji: Naenyeone daehagwone jinhakhal geotida. Geuraeseo sebu gyehoegeul se-eul geotida.
examples.en: I will go to graduate school next year, so I should make a detailed plan.

title: ~할 때마다 [hal ttaemada] (Every time when)
short_explanation: Used to express 'every time when' or 'whenever'.
long_explanation: '~할 때마다 [hal ttaemada]' is used when something happens each time a certain action or event occurs. It emphasizes a recurring event or repetitive situation following that action.

examples.kr: 그는 국수를 먹을 때마다 그녀를 떠올리곤 해요. 그녀가 국수를 좋아했으니까요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun guksureul meogeul ttaemada geunyeoreul tteoolligon haeyo. Geunyeoga guksureul joahaesseunikka-yo.
examples.en: Every time he eats noodles, he thinks of her, because she loved noodles.

examples.kr: 나는 집에 돌아올 때마다 강아지가 나를 맞이해서 너무 행복해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jibe doraol ttaemada gangajiga nareul majihaseo neomu haengbokhaeyo.
examples.en: Every time I come home, I'm so happy because my puppy greets me.

examples.kr: 그녀는 그를 볼 때마다 심장이 빠르게 뛰기 시작합니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun geureul bol ttaemada simjangi ppaleuge ttwigi sijakhamnida.
examples.en: Every time she sees him, her heart starts to beat faster.

examples.kr: 할머니는 제가 방문할 때마다 특별한 간식을 만들어 주셔서 항상 기대돼요.
examples.romaji: Halmeonineun jega bangmunhal ttaemada teukbyeolhan gansigeul mandeureo jusyeoseo hangsang gidaedwaeyo.
examples.en: Every time I visit, my grandmother makes a special snack, so I always look forward to it.

title: ~할 만하다 [hal manhada] (Worth doing)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that something is worth doing or trying.
long_explanation: '~할 만하다 [hal manhada]' expresses the worthiness or value of doing an action. It often follows a verb stem. It can be used to suggest that an activity or item is meaningful, beneficial, or simply worth a try.

examples.kr: 이 영화를 보는 것은 시간을 낭비하는 게 아니라 꽤 가치 있었어요. 볼 만한 영화였거든요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwareul boneun geoseun siganeul nangbihaneun ge anira kkwae gachi isseosseoyo. Bol manhan yeonghwayeotgeodeunyo.
examples.en: Watching this movie wasn't a waste of time; it was quite valuable because it was worth seeing.

examples.kr: 그 책은 내용이 풍부해서 읽을 만했어요.
examples.romaji: Geu chaegeun naeyongi pungbuhaseo ilg-eul manhaesseoyo.
examples.en: That book was rich in content and was worth reading.

examples.kr: 저 아파트에 살아 볼 만해요. 교통이 편리하고 시설이 잘 갖춰져 있거든요.
examples.romaji: Jeo apateue sarabo-l manhaeyo. Gyotongi pyeonrihago siseli jal gatchwojyeo itgeodeunyo.
examples.en: It's worth trying to live in that apartment since transportation is convenient and it has good facilities.

examples.kr: 이 카메라는 좀 비싸지만, 품질이 좋으니 살 만해요.
examples.romaji: I kamera-neun jom bissajiman, pumjili joeunigi sal manhaeyo.
examples.en: Although this camera is a bit expensive, it’s worth buying because it has great quality.

title: ~할 수 있다 [hal su itda] (Can do)
short_explanation: Used to express possibility or ability; 'can do' something.
long_explanation: '~할 수 있다 [hal su itda]' indicates that someone is capable of or has the possibility to perform an action, effectively meaning 'can'. It is often used for skills or situations where something is feasible.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 조금 할 수 있어요, 그래서 한국에 관심이 많아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul jogeum hal su isseoyo, geuraeseo hanguge gwansimi manhajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I can speak a little Korean, so I became very interested in Korea.

examples.kr: 당신이 생각한 대로 할 수 있어요. 당신이 그 일을 제일 잘 아니까 믿을게요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini saenggakhan daero hal su isseoyo. Dangsini geu ireul jeil jal anikka mideulgeyo.
examples.en: You can do it as you think best, since you know that job the most.

examples.kr: 이것은 누구나 쉽게 할 수 있는 일이니 너무 걱정 마세요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun nuguna swipge hal su inneun irini neomu geokjeong maseyo.
examples.en: Anyone can do this easily, so there's no need to worry.

examples.kr: 주말에 시간이 있으면 제가 차를 고칠 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jumale sigani isseumyeon jega chareul gochil su isseoyo.
examples.en: If I have time on the weekend, I can fix the car.

title: ~할 수 없다 [hal su eopda] (Cannot do)
short_explanation: Used to express inability or impossibility; 'cannot do'.
long_explanation: '~할 수 없다 [hal su eopda]' means that the subject does not have the capacity or possibility to perform a certain action, i.e., 'cannot' do it in current circumstances. It emphasizes the impossibility or lack of ability.

examples.kr: 지금 너무 바빠서 친구들과 식사할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum neomu bappaseo chingudeulgwa siksahal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I'm so busy right now that I cannot eat with my friends.

examples.kr: 그녀는 수영을 잘 못해서 혼자서 물에 들어갈 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun suyeongeul jal mothaeseo honjaseo mure deureogal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: She isn't good at swimming, so she can't go into the water alone.

examples.kr: 저는 예술 감각이 없어서 그림을 잘 그릴 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yesul gamgagi eopseoseo geurimeul jal geuril su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I don't have an artistic sense, so I cannot draw well.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 너무 무서워서 저는 다시 볼 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun neomu museowoseo jeoneun dasi bol su eopseoyo.
examples.en: This movie is so scary that I can't watch it again.

title: ~할 줄 알다 [hal jul alda] (Know how to)
short_explanation: Used to express that one knows how to do something or has the skill/knowledge to do it.
long_explanation: The phrase '~할 줄 알다 [hal jul alda]' signifies that someone has learned or can perform an action or process, translating to 'know how to (do something)' in English. It focuses on practical skill or capability rather than mere theoretical knowledge.

examples.kr: 저는 피아노 칠 줄 알아요. 하지만 전문가는 아니에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun piano chil jul arayo. Hajiman jeonmunganeun anieyo.
examples.en: I know how to play the piano, but I'm not a professional.

examples.kr: 우리 아이는 이제 스스로 신발 신을 줄 알아요.
examples.romaji: Uri aineun ije seuseuro sinbal sineul jul arayo.
examples.en: Our child now knows how to put on their shoes by themselves.

examples.kr: 철수는 항상 새로운 것을 배우는 방법을 잘 알더라고요.
examples.romaji: Cheolsuneun hangsang saeroun geoseul baeuneun bangbeobeul jal aldereogoyo.
examples.en: Cheolsu always seems to know how to learn new things.

examples.kr: 누나는 요리를 잘할 줄 알아서, 늘 맛있는 음식을 만들어 줘요.
examples.romaji: Nunaneun yorireul jalhal jul araseo, neul masinneun eumsigeul mandeureo jwoyo.
examples.en: My older sister knows how to cook well, so she always makes delicious food.

title: ~할지라도 [haljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: This grammar point in Korean is used to express 'even if' or 'no matter how'.
long_explanation: The '~할지라도 [haljirado]' grammar pattern is used in Korean to indicate a hypothetical situation similar to 'even if' or 'no matter how' in English. It is used before verbs (or adjectives) to express a condition, concession, or possibility contrary to reality or expectation.

examples.kr: 어떤 문제가 생길지라도 저는 항상 최선을 다해 일을 끝낼 거예요.
examples.romaji: Eotteon munjega saenggiljirado jeoneun hangsang choeseoneul dahae ireul kkeutnael geoyeyo.
examples.en: No matter what problems arise, I will always do my best to finish the work.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 오는지라도 난 외출할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga oneunjirado nan oechulhal geoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if it rains tomorrow, I will go out.

examples.kr: 네가 그런 일을 당한 적이 있을지라도 동정하지 않아.
examples.romaji: Nega geureon ireul danghan jeogi isseuljirado dongjeonghaji anha.
examples.en: Even if you have been through such a situation, I do not sympathize.

examples.kr: 비용이 높을지라도 최고의 품질을 보장하기 위해 비싼 재료를 사용합니다.
examples.romaji: Biyongi nopeuljirado choegoui pumjireul bojanghagi wihae bissan jaeryoreul sayonghamnida.
examples.en: Even if the cost is high, we use expensive materials to ensure the highest quality.

title: ~든지 ~든지 [deunji deunji] (Whether ... or)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express 'whether ... or', indicating two (or more) possibilities.
long_explanation: The pattern '~든지 ~든지' in Korean lists multiple possibilities or choices. It translates closely to 'whether ... or' in English. It is often used in daily conversation to show that no matter which option happens or is chosen, the outcome or decision remains consistent.

examples.kr: 그녀가 오늘 밤에 도착하든지 내일 아침에 도착하든지, 우리는 그녀를 기다려야 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga oneul bam-e dochakhadeunji naeil achim-e dochakhadeunji, urineun geunyeoreul gidaryeoya haeyo.
examples.en: Whether she arrives tonight or tomorrow morning, we have to wait for her.

examples.kr: 이 일을 해결하든지 미루든지, 결정은 당신이 해야 해요.
examples.romaji: I ireul haegyeolhadeunji mirudeunji, gyeoljeongeun dangsini haeya haeyo.
examples.en: Whether you solve this issue or postpone it, the decision is yours.

examples.kr: 우리가 이기든지 지든지, 최선을 다하는 것이 중요해요.
examples.romaji: Uriga igideunji jideunji, choeseoneul dahaneun geosi jungyohaeyo.
examples.en: Whether we win or lose, doing our best is what's important.

examples.kr: 그가 참석하든지 참석하지 않든지, 회의는 예정대로 진행됩니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga chamseokhadeunji chamseokhaji anteunji, hoeineun yejeongdaero jinaengdoebnida.
examples.en: Whether he attends or not, the meeting will proceed as scheduled.

title: ~할 텐데 [hal tende] (Probably will)
short_explanation: Used to express a prediction or expectation that something will occur in the future.
long_explanation: '~할 텐데 [hal tende]' is a common ending in Korean that expresses a prediction or expectation that a certain event, situation, or behavior is likely to occur. It can also convey regret when referring to a likely outcome that did not happen. It is formed by taking the verb stem plus (으)ㄹ 텐데.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올 텐데, 우산을 가져가는 것이 좋습니다.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga ol tende, usaneul gajyeoganeun geosi johseumnida.
examples.en: It's probably going to rain tomorrow, so it would be good to bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 지금 출발하면 시간에 맞출 텐데, 너무 늦게 도착하면 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum chulbalhamyeon sigane majchul tende, neomu neujge dochakhamyeon an dwaeyo.
examples.en: If we leave now, we will probably make it on time, so we can't arrive too late.

examples.kr: 그의 성적은 좋으니 그는 장학금을 받을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Geuui seongjeogeun joheuni geuneun janghakgeumeul badeul tende.
examples.en: His grades are good, so he will probably receive a scholarship.

examples.kr: 친구가 도와줬다면 문제를 해결할 텐데, 혼자서는 힘들어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga dowajwotdamyeon munjeleul haegyeolhal tende, honjaseoneun himdeureoyo.
examples.en: If my friend had helped me, I would have probably solved the problem, but it's hard on my own.

title: ~함께 [hamkke] (Together with)
short_explanation: Used to indicate doing something together with someone or something.
long_explanation: '~함께 [hamkke]' is a phrase in Korean that implies doing an activity 'together with' someone or something. It shows a simultaneous action or condition, similar to 'together with' in English. Commonly used with nouns.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 친구들과 함께 영화를 봤어요. 영화가 정말 재미있었고 모두가 즐거웠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul chingudeulgwa hamkke yeonghwareul bwasseoyo. Yeonghwaga jeongmal jaemiisseotgo moduga jeulgeowosseoyo.
examples.en: I watched a movie with my friends today. The movie was really fun, and everyone was happy.

examples.kr: 나는 어머니와 함께 시장에 갔어요, 그리고 정말 많은 것을 샀어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eomeoniwa hamkke sijange gasseoyo, geurigo jeongmal maneun geoseul sasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to the market with my mother, and I bought so many things.

examples.kr: 나는 친구와 함께 여행을 갔고, 그곳에서 정말 멋진 사진을 찍었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chingugwa hamkke yeohaengeul gatgo, geugoseseo jeongmal meotjin sajineul jjigeosseoyo.
examples.en: I went on a trip with my friend, and we took some really awesome photos there.

examples.kr: 나는 동생과 함께 공원에서 놀았어요. 우리는 정말로 신기한 동물들을 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun dongsenggwa hamkke gongwoneseo nolasseoyo. Urineun jeongmallo singihan dongmuldeureul bwasseoyo.
examples.en: I played in the park with my younger brother. We saw some really interesting animals.

title: ~해 보다 [hae boda] (Try to do)
short_explanation: Indicates the speaker's attempt or experience of doing something.
long_explanation: '~해 보다 [hae boda]' is used when a speaker expresses trying or experiencing something, often for the first time. It is typically formed with the verb stem plus '아/어 보다.' It can be translated as 'to try (doing something)' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 한 번 한국어로 토론을 해 보려고 합니다. 그러나 어려워서 연습이 필요해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun han beon hangugeoro toroneul hae boryeogo hamnida. Geureona eoryeowoseo yeonseubi piryohaeyo.
examples.en: I'm trying to debate in Korean for the first time, but it's difficult, so I need practice.

examples.kr: 많은 사람들이 한국 음식을 한 번 해 보라고 해서, 오늘은 김치찌개를 만들어 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Manheun saramdeuri hanguk eumsigeul han beon hae borago haeseo, oneureun gimchijjigaereul mandeureo bwasseoyo.
examples.en: Many people told me to try making Korean food, so today I tried making kimchi stew.

examples.kr: 새로운 프로그램을 사용해 보려고 했지만, 너무 복잡해서 포기했어요.
examples.romaji: Saeroun peurogeuraemeul sayonghae boryeogo haessjiman, neomu bokjabhaeseo pogihaesseoyo.
examples.en: I tried to use a new program, but it was too complicated, so I gave up.

examples.kr: 나는 나이가 들어도 새로운 경험을 해 보는 것을 좋아해요. 그래서 자주 여행을 가 보려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun naiga deureodo saeroun gyeongheomeul hae boneun geoseul joahaeyo. Geuraeseo jaju yeohaengeul ga boryeogo hamnida.
examples.en: Even as I get older, I like trying new experiences, so I plan to travel frequently.

title: ~해 주다 [hae juda] (Do for someone)
short_explanation: Used to express an action done for someone else's benefit.
long_explanation: '~해 주다 [hae juda]' indicates that the subject does or did something for the benefit of another person. Commonly used in polite speech to express that an action is done for someone else. It can also show gratitude or a request.
formation: Verb stem + 아/어 주다 (하다 → 해 + 주다)

examples.kr: 저는 어머니가 아프셔서 저녁 식사를 해 주었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eomeoni-ga apeusyeoseo jeonyeok siksareul hae jueosseoyo.
examples.en: I made dinner for my mother because she was sick.

examples.kr: 친구가 시험 공부를 도와 주어서 고맙다고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga siheom gongbureul dowa jueoseo gomapdago malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I told my friend 'thank you' for helping me study for the exam.

examples.kr: 선생님이 질문에 대해 자세히 설명해 주셔서 이해가 잘 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnim-i jilmun-e daehae jasehi seolmyeonghae jusyeoseo ihaega jal doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: The teacher explained my question in detail, so I understood it well.

examples.kr: 동생이 방 청소를 도와줄 거라고 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Dongsengi bang cheongso-reul dowajul georago malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: My younger sibling said he would help me clean the room.

title: ~해야겠다 [haeyagetda] (Should do)
short_explanation: Expresses the speaker’s intention or resolution to do something.
long_explanation: The phrase '~해야겠다 [haeyagetda]' shows the speaker's firm decision or determination to do something. It often translates to 'I should,' 'I ought to,' or 'I must' in English, highlighting the importance or necessity of the action.

examples.kr: 당신이 그 일을 계속 대처하지 않으면, 제가 뭔가를 해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini geu ireul gyesok daecheohaji anheumyeon, jega mwongareul haeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: If you keep neglecting that issue, I should do something.

examples.kr: 이런 실수를 반복하지 않으려면 더 많이 연습해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Ireon silsureul banbokhaji anheuryeomyeon deo mani yeonseubhaeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: I should practice more so that I won't repeat this kind of mistake.

examples.kr: 우리는 팀원들과의 의사소통을 개선하기 위해 더 많이 노력해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun timweondeulgwaui uisasotongeul gaeseonhagi wihae deo mani noryeokhaeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: We should try harder to improve communication with our team members.

examples.kr: 이번 시험을 통과하려면 더 열심히 공부해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeul tonggwaharyeomyeon deo yeolsimhi gongbuhaeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: I should study harder to pass this exam.

title: ~해서는 안 되다 [haeseoneun an dweda] (Must not do)
short_explanation: Shows prohibition or something that must not be done.
long_explanation: In Korean, '~해서는 안 되다 [haeseoneun an dweda]' indicates an action that is prohibited. It is used with action verbs to form negative commands or strong advice, meaning 'must not' or 'should not' do something. More common in formal contexts or rule statements.
formation: Verb stem + 아/어서는 안 되다 (하다 → 해서는 안 되다)

examples.kr: 그 문서를 복사해서는 안 돼요. 그것은 기업의 기밀입니다.
examples.romaji: Geu munseoreul boksahaeseoneun an dwaeyo. Geugeoseun gieobui gimil-ibnida.
examples.en: You must not copy that document. It's the company's confidential information.

examples.kr: 어려운 상황에서 거짓말을 해서는 안 됩니다. 그것은 신뢰를 깨뜨릴 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Eoryeoun sanghwangeseo geojitmareul haeseoneun an doebnida. Geugeoseun sinryeoreul kkaetteuril su isseoyo.
examples.en: You must not lie in a difficult situation. It could break trust.

examples.kr: 시험에서 부정행위를 해서는 안 됩니다. 그것은 당신의 성적을 망칠 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Siheomeseo bujeonghaengwireul haeseoneun an doebnida. Geugeoseun dangsinui seongjeogeul mangchil geos-ibnida.
examples.en: You must not cheat in the exam. It will ruin your grades.

examples.kr: 친구를 배반해서는 안 됩니다. 그것은 소중한 관계를 깨뜨릴 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Chingureul baebanhaeseoneun an doebnida. Geugeoseun sojunghan gwangyereul kkaetteuril geos-ibnida.
examples.en: You must not betray your friend. It will destroy a precious relationship.

title: ~해야 하다 [haeya hada] (Have to do)
short_explanation: Expresses obligation or necessity (have to, must, need to).
long_explanation: '~해야 하다 [haeya hada]' indicates a strong necessity or obligation to carry out an action. It often translates to 'have to,' 'must,' or 'need to' in English, showing that there is no other choice but to do the mentioned action.

examples.kr: 집에 가야 하니까 약속을 취소해야 해요. 아니면 지각할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jibe gaya hanikka yaksogeul chwisohaeya haeyo. Animyeon jigakhal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I have to cancel the appointment because I need to go home. Otherwise, I'll be late.

examples.kr: 저는 내일 시험이 있어서 오늘 밤에 공부해야 해요. 공부하지 않으면 좋은 점수를 얻을 수 없을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun naeil siheomi isseoseo oneul bame gongbuhaeya haeyo. Gongbuhaji anheumyeon joeun jeomsureul eodeul su eopseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: I have an exam tomorrow, so I have to study tonight. If I don't study, I don't think I can get a good score.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 아빠가 병원에 가야 하니까 제가 돌봐야 해요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal-e appaga byeongwone gaya hanikka jega dolbwaya haeyo.
examples.en: My dad has to go to the hospital this weekend, so I have to take care of him.

examples.kr: 세계 평화를 위해서는 모든 나라가 함께 노력해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Segye pyeonghwareul wihaeseoneun modeun naraga hamkke noryeokhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: For world peace, every country has to make an effort together.

title: ~했더니 [haetdeoni] (After doing)
short_explanation: Used to express an unexpected result or surprise after doing an action.
long_explanation: '~했더니 [haetdeoni]' is a grammar point used to describe a discovery or unexpected outcome that follows right after the speaker performed a certain action. It can imply some causal relationship, but it mainly highlights the speaker's surprise or the unanticipated result that happened immediately after an action.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 아침에 일찍 일어났더니, 두통이 더 심해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul achime iljik ireonatdeoni, dutongi deo simhaejyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I woke up early this morning, and to my surprise, my headache got worse.

examples.kr: 그녀에게 전화를 했더니, 이미 집에 와 있더라고요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoege jeonhwareul haetdeoni, imi jibe wa itdeoragoyo.
examples.en: I called her, and surprisingly, she was already at home.

examples.kr: 나는 저녁을 먹고 숙제를 했더니, 어떻게 벌써 12시가 됐어요?
examples.romaji: Naneun jeonyeogeul meokgo sukjereul haetdeoni, eotteoke beolsseo 12si-ga dwaesseoyo?
examples.en: I ate dinner and did my homework—how on earth is it already midnight?

examples.kr: 나는 신발을 가게에서 샀더니, 집에 돌아왔을 때 발이 아팠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun sinbaleul gageeseo sasseodeoni, jibe dorawasseul ttae bali apasseoyo.
examples.en: I bought shoes from the store, but when I got home, my feet hurt to my surprise.

title: ~했었다 [haesseotda] (Had done)
short_explanation: Used to express an action that was completed in the past.
long_explanation: '~했었다 [haesseotda]' is a past-perfect-like expression in Korean, adding a sense of completion or “used to” nuance to something that happened previously. It can show that one action was finished in the past before another event took place, or that a repeated action/condition existed but does not continue anymore.

examples.kr: 결혼하기 전에 여행을 많이 갔었어요. 그런데 아이들이 생기고 나서는 자주 못 가게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Gyeolhonhagi jeone yeohaengeul mani gasseosseoyo. Geureonde aideuri saenggigo naseoneun jaju mot gage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: I had gone on many trips before I got married. But after having children, I couldn't go as often.

examples.kr: 그때 그 청춘을 돌이켜보니 정말 행복했었다는 것을 깨닫게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Geuttae geu cheongchuneul dorikyeoboni jeongmal haengbokhaesseotdaneun geoseul kkaedatge dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: Looking back at those youthful days, I realized that I had been truly happy.

examples.kr: 어머니가 오셨을 때 이미 저녁 식사를 끝냈었어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeoniga osyeosseul ttae imi jeonyeok siksareul kkeutnaesseosseoyo.
examples.en: When my mother came, I had already finished dinner.

examples.kr: 당신이 도착했을 때 비행기는 이미 출발했었어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini dochakhaesseul ttae bihaenggineun imi chulbalhaesseosseoyo.
examples.en: By the time you arrived, the plane had already taken off.

title: ~했으면 좋겠다 [haesseumyeon jotgetda] (I wish, I hope)
short_explanation: Used to express wishing or hoping for a situation to happen.
long_explanation: '~했으면 좋겠다 [haesseumyeon jotgetda]' is commonly used to express a personal wish or hope for some future or hypothetical situation. It can be translated as 'I wish...' or 'I hope...' in English. The speaker desires the action or state described by the verb.

examples.kr: 이번 시험에 합격했으면 좋겠어요. 그래야 제 꿈을 이룰 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheome hapgyeokhaesseumyeon jotgetseoyo. Geuraeya je kkumeul irul su isseoyo.
examples.en: I hope I pass this exam. Only then can I achieve my dream.

examples.kr: 내일 날씨가 좋았으면 좋겠어요. 그래야 바깥에서 놀 수 있으니까요.
examples.romaji: Naeil nalssiga johasseumyeon jotgetseoyo. Geuraeya bakkateseo nol su issnikkayo.
examples.en: I wish the weather would be good tomorrow. Then we can play outside.

examples.kr: 그녀가 행복했으면 좋겠어요. 그녀는 많은 시련을 겪었거든요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga haengbokhaesseumyeon jotgetseoyo. Geunyeoneun manheun siryeoneul gyeok-eosseogeodeunyo.
examples.en: I hope she can be happy. She has been through a lot.

examples.kr: 우리 팀이 이겼으면 좋겠어요. 우리는 열심히 연습했거든요.
examples.romaji: Uri timi igyeosseumyeon jotgetseoyo. Urineun yeolsimhi yeonseuphaetgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I hope our team wins. We've practiced really hard.

title: ~했을 때 [haesseul ttae] (When someone did)
short_explanation: Expresses 'when someone did' or 'at the time when something was done'.
long_explanation: '~했을 때 [haesseul ttae]' is used to indicate a moment in the past when an action happened. It can sometimes introduce a second clause that describes a related event or reaction. In English, it roughly translates as 'when (someone) did something' or 'at the time that (something) occurred.'
formation: Verb in past tense + 을/를 + 때 (했을 때)

examples.kr: 저희 집에 왔을 때 엄마가 저녁을 준비하고 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeohui jibe wasseul ttae eommaga jeonyeogeul junbihago isseosseoyo.
examples.en: When I arrived home, my mom was preparing dinner.

examples.kr: 그 영화를 보았을 때 진짜 많이 울었어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaleul boasseul ttae jinjja manhi ureosseoyo.
examples.en: When I watched that movie, I cried a lot.

examples.kr: 해외로 이사했을 때 처음엔 많이 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Haeoero isahaesseul ttae cheoeumen manhi himdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: When I moved abroad, it was very difficult at first.

examples.kr: 졸업했을 때 부모님이 정말 자랑스러워하셨어요.
examples.romaji: Joleobhaesseul ttae bumonimi jeongmal jarangseureowohasyeosseoyo.
examples.en: When I graduated, my parents were really proud.

title: ~했을 텐데 [haesseul tende] (Would have)
short_explanation: Used to express a hypothetical past scenario or regret.
long_explanation: '~했을 텐데 [haesseul tende]' is used for hypotheticals or regrets about something that did not happen in the past. It often appears with '만약 ~았/었더라면 (if I had done something)' or implies 'I would have...' or 'It would have been...' in English.

examples.kr: 알았다면 그런 결정을 하지 않았을 텐데, 결국 많은 시간과 노력을 낭비했습니다.
examples.romaji: Alatdamyeon geureon gyeoljeongeul haji anhasseul tende, gyeolguk manheun sigangwa noryeogeul nangbihaesseumnida.
examples.en: If I'd known, I wouldn't have made that decision; in the end, I wasted a lot of time and effort.

examples.kr: 서둘렀다면 그 기회를 잡을 수 있었을 텐데, 지금은 너무 늦었어요.
examples.romaji: Seodulleossdamyeon geu gihoereul jabeul su isseosseul tende, jigeumeun neomu neujeosseoyo.
examples.en: If I had hurried, I would have been able to seize that opportunity, but now it's too late.

examples.kr: 그때 그녀에게 말했다면 다르게 됐을 텐데, 하지만 그런 일은 하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuttae geunyeoege malhaetdamyeon dareuge dwaesseul tende, hajiman geureon ireun haji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: If I had spoken to her then, things would have turned out differently, but I never did.

examples.kr: 그렇게 열심히 일했다면 성공했을 텐데, 그래도 나는 내 선택에 만족합니다.
examples.romaji: Geureoke yeolsimhi ilhaetdamyeon seonggonghaesseul tende, geuraedo naneun nae seontaege manjokhamnida.
examples.en: If I had worked that hard, I would have succeeded, but I'm still content with my choices.

title: ~했지만 [haetjiman] (Did, but)
short_explanation: Connects two contrasting ideas in the past; 'did, but'.
long_explanation: '~했지만 [haetjiman]' is used to show a contrast or unexpected result between two past actions/conditions, comparable to 'did, but' or 'although' in English. It often indicates the second clause contradicts or does not live up to the expectation set by the first clause.

examples.kr: 저는 어제 공부를 많이 했지만 시험에서 성적이 좋지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eoje gongbureul manhi haetjiman siheomeseo seongjeogi johji anasseoyo.
examples.en: I studied a lot yesterday, but my test score wasn’t very good.

examples.kr: 그는 힘들게 일했지만 노력이 제대로 인정되지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun himdeulge ilhaetjiman noryeogi jedaero injeongdoeji anasseoyo.
examples.en: He worked really hard, but his efforts were not properly recognized.

examples.kr: 나는 그것을 지금 막 마쳤지만 정말로 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geugeoseul jigeum mak machyeotjiman jeongmallo himdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: I just finished it, but it was really difficult.

examples.kr: 우리는 정말 빨리 달렸지만 버스를 잡지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jeongmal ppalli dallyeotjiman beoseureul japji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: We ran really fast, but we couldn't catch the bus.

title: ~했다 [haetda] (Did, past tense)
short_explanation: Marks an action as completed in the past; 'did'.
long_explanation: '~했다 [haetda]' is a standard past-tense form in Korean, equivalent to saying 'I did (something)' in English. It simply indicates that the action is finished and took place in the past.

examples.kr: 어제 이해가 안 되던 문제를 결국 풀었다. 정말 기쁘다.
examples.romaji: Eoje ihaega an dwoedon munjeleul gyeolguk pulleotda. Jeongmal gippeuda.
examples.en: I finally solved the problem that I didn't understand yesterday. I’m really happy.

examples.kr: 우리는 이번 이벤트를 성공적으로 마무리했다. 다들 힘들었지만 보람이 있었다.
examples.romaji: Urineun ibeon ibenteureul seonggongjeogeuro mamurihaetda. Dadeul himdeureotjiman boram-i isseotda.
examples.en: We successfully finished this event. It was hard on everyone, but it was rewarding.

examples.kr: 나는 어제 공부를 많이 했다. 오늘은 조금 쉬어야겠다.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoje gongbureul manhi haetda. Oneureun jogeum swieoyagedda.
examples.en: I studied a lot yesterday. I should rest a bit today.

examples.kr: 지난 주말에 친구들과 쇼핑을 가서 재미있는 옷을 많이 샀다.
examples.romaji: Jinan jumal-e chingudeulgwa syopingeul gaseo jaemiinneun oseul manhi satda.
examples.en: I went shopping with my friends last weekend and bought a lot of interesting clothes.
